description:
For Mark Rothko's No.14 alone. 

But obviously also for one of the finest and most expansive collections of modern art in the world -  Claus Oldenburg, Roy Lichtenstein, Jackson Pollock, Gerard Richter, Richard Diebenkorn, Diego Rivera, Joan Miro, Rene Magritte, Alexander Calder, Andy Warhol, Jeff Koons, Wayne Thiebaud, etc. - all your favorites and more.  

Visceral and intellectual reactions welcome - lots for all to appreciate, regardless of whether you're an art history major, practicing artist, or an individual with a keen eye.
author: Cin-Yee S.

description:
A very cohesive collection that kept getting better and better as I got lost in it. I easily spent close to 5 hours here. I was so thankful that they held on to my backpack as I explored the museum. Not knowing what I signed up for, falling into the foray of Magritte, I completely lost track of everything. This was a timed event and on top of that I was also part of the docent group.

One of the most intense pieces I saw while I was there was Jeff Koons' Michael Jackson and Bubbles. I have never really thought much of it until I saw it in person. It was just intense. They had a good Twombly collection which made me appreciate the Cy Twombly gallery in Houston. I was confused thinking that I was looking at Warhol and somehow the floor transitioned from Warhol to Roy Lichtenstein and I was just bitten. Then I got to be on 13th PbFe Triangle and I had a whole new level of appreciation for Carl Andre. And I learned about Sigmar Polke. 

If you're in the area, a visit to SF MOMA is a must!
author: Zain R.

description:
Museums can be a place for relaxation and inspiration. If you've had formal training in art or not, there are always things to learn and experience in a well-developed museum with an excellent and inclusive collection of work. Not to mention, that in-person experience with an art piece doesn't compare to the experiences you've had through books or pictures online. 

For me, since I do have a personal relationship to certain works of art, I found that the collection at SF MOMA contained multiple works that I was able to really appreciate spending time with. Certain areas of this museum tend to be more sparse with guests, so the experience can be enjoyable. Other sections (such as special collections) tend to be packed, and not quite as enjoyable and even stressful. However, this is a relatively typical situation for any museum.

I'm huge on K-12 arts education. It's an often overlooked subject in school, and it tends to be rare for young children to even be able to step inside a museum for one reason or another. SF MOMA appears to have an incredibly well-developed student-education program for youngsters. They also host docent tours for adults, but I was more impressed by the ability of these educators to engage such young students in work that is typically inaccessible to any individual without much of a background of knowledge. It seemed like the youth-educators were museum staff or volunteers, but it is possible that they were trained K-12 teachers as well. 

It was so refreshing to watch an educator explain abstract art to a group of young children. The docent seemed to be able to explain the topics in such a simplistic way, that all the students seemed engaged and were able to ask some pretty smart questions. Other groups of students were plopped down in front of a work of art on a mat with museum-approved art tools. Kiddos were encouraged to replicate their own interpretation of a piece of work. 

In addition to the great collection and student programming, it was lovely to see that they kept Mathew Barney's "Drawing Restraint 14" still sketched on the wall after their renovation. I am a huge Barney fan, and it would have been quite the bummer to see this piece covered up.

Please note that works of art in any museum may not be the same every time you attend.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
SF MOMA is 7 floors of interesting things to look at.  Some very good and some not so good; but you will certainly have 3 quality hours of seeing an artistic expression of someone else's world view.

We visited the Rene Magritte exhibit.  Outstanding!

Here are the helpful thoughts to make your visit count:

- Purchase the membership option if you live close and plan to visit again within a year.
- Download the SFMOMA app for your phone - it has the explanations of the exhibits and it's all free. (Look at everything before you go.)
- Bring your earbuds to listen to the explanations using the SFMOMA app.
- Buy your tickets online to avoid standing in line (sometimes a long line).  You can do this using SFMOMA internet.
- There are restrooms on every floor.  The higher you go, the fewer people will be in the restrooms.
- Take the stairs rather than the elevator.  It is certainly faster if you are only going one floor at a time.
author: Steve S.

description: This world class museum is as nice and classy as they get.  The architecture and layout of the place flows nicely and conducive to spending as much time as one likes.  Currently the brilliant Belgium surrealist painter Rene Magritte is the headliner artist, but there are many fine works of other artists as well.  An extra plus is that they have a lovely coffee station called Spyglass.  Their baristas are artists in their own right and the coffee is exquisite.
author: Mabe S.

description:
In awe I am of the renovated SFMOMA. Yes, it was completed in 2016, yet, it wasn't till this year that I made a visit to see the exhibit of "Rene Magritte".  

I've been hiding under a stone, for the architecture and the interior of this modern art museum is well worth a trip on its own. Spacious & spectacular it is.

For all modern art lovers, 7 floors of dynamic, disturbing, wonderful, mythical, provocative, alluring, and, apocalyptic artistic masterpieces.

Already looking forward to my next visit here be it today or sometime in the near future.

CHEERS!
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
I don't know why it took me so long to visit the newly rebuilt museum.
It is fantastic.  I love the layout and the exhibits.

I thought about buying a membership.  But the cost of membership is four times the cost of one visit.  Typically I would expect 2-3 times.  I'm not sure I'll get up here often enough to justify it.  But I do hope to make it up a couple of times a year.

Oh, and if you're like one of my loved ones and think that modern art = abstract art (and you don't love abstract art), brush away that notion.  Modern art is any art in the last century or two... paintings, drawings, photography, sculpture... realism, abstract, and everything in between.  You're virtually guaranteed to find some exhibits or pieces you love.
author: Linda M.

description:
I came to see the Magritte exhibit because a friend was able to get me tickets while I was visiting town. The Magritte exhibit was pretty incredible. I was not super familiar with his work before I saw it, and his work was so versatile that if I hadn't known, I would've thought it was work done by other artists. 

That being said, a lot of the other components of the museum were relatively disappointing. The sculpture garden had a sad smaller version of the love sculpture that is in Philly and Little else. There was actually nothing on the sculpture terrace except a view of neighboring buildings. 

It was a very hit or miss experience overall. I'm glad I went but I don't think I'd pay to go back.
author: Ashtar B.

description:
This place reminds us all that 
ART IS SUBJECTIVE! 

Some notable exhibits:

The Spiders - they actually look real (especially the ones on the wall). I loved it, but my sister hated it! If arachnophobia is your thing, please don't get caught up in this web. 

The Typewriter - it was generating new stories in realtime :O 

There's a frozen snowman in a glass box outside - I'm not sure how I feel about that, but my brother thought it was rad? 

The cafe has some delicious coffee, so that's a great spot to visit if you're tired of walking! 

Parking is scarce.
We walked from Chinatown.
author: Thuy N.

description:
I love SFMOMA! I've been a few times over the years,  and every time I've been impressed.

The collection is huge--I can't take it all in in one visit. But I do my best!

The renovation looks great.  

I took in the Magritte exhibition on my most recent visit. It was wonderful. I also enjoyed their Sol Lewitt installations. And the Warhols. And the Calder stabiles. And the living wall. 

There's a Jenny Holzer. And Rothko. Lichtensteins. Hockney. Good, important pieces by the artists to boot.

So much wonderful art. It's a must-see for any visit to SF.
author: Cherie C.

description: Download the app and do the audio tour. It adds a depth to the art and there are fun commentaries. I spent an afternoon here and only covered about 1.5 of the 7floors (7th floor is closed for reno until 11/10). But I'm also one to linger too long at each artwork.
author: Lin L.

description:
The MOMA is an awesome place to visit over and over again because you will see something new every single time. There are interactive exhibits and art that interests all types of artists or admirers.

The highlights of this museum for me are the Roy Litchenstein pieces, Andy Warhol pieces, the graphic design poster exhibit, the interactive art exhibits, and the outdoor section. 

This is an awesome place to go if you are under 18 or you have kids under 18 as they get in for free.
author: Sydney G.

description:
This museum is so amazing! We came late and had only 3 hours, but we could've easily been here 5-7 hours. We went with the Go Card because we also wanted to go to the exploratorium and hit a bike trail, which made it all very affordable for a family of 4.

If you get a chance, take advantage of the special exhibit this month, which is Magritte. It is totally worth it and they have really amazing artworks throughout this museum. My favorite floor overall was the 7th floor because of all the modern art that was on display as well as some of the installations being really compelling.

Overall, don't miss out on the chance to visit, it is extremely worth it!
author: Kareem G.

description: I'm probably going to get lynched for saying this, so let me just get it out of the way now: I expected.... more. I was honestly disappointed.  My offspring thought I was insane.  So maybe I'm jaded. Admittedly I grew up having easy access to museums in Philly and New York... and I've been to the Louve and I've traveled some, but I'm not exactly  a jet setter.  I was honestly surprised by how small this museum was.  I sat and contemplated several pieces for a good 15 minutes, and yes, other rooms and walked right through because I'm a snob... but in general, I gave each room the time they deserved.  And it took me only a half a day to walk me through the museum. I was crushed. I really expected more.  But I DID see three or four pieces that Shattered me.  I'm glad we went.  Dont miss the cool park outside the musuem.
author: Joy G.

description:
I am not a big museum person but I have to say I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to MOMA. 

The grounds are so cool. The restaurant area. The sculpture garden. The greenery. 

My favorite exhibit was the display of photos from the photograph on the train escorting RFK's body to DC. The photos were of the people along the train route paying their respects to the senator. People from all walks of life. Who would've known these photos existed. There was also a side exhibit about those people who saw the train and their photos. Very touching. 

The whole museum was so neat. Made me more aware of knowing art can be anything creative. 

Please support MOMA!
author: Mitzi W.

description: A fun spot to check out if you are into Modern art. It was a little too packed so it was hard to really enjoy the pieces. It is a great place to go alone! :-)
author: Theresa G.

description:
Large, exemplary modern art museum that is worth visiting if you're ok with the admission price and - more importantly - the crowds. 

I visited the recent Magritte exhibit, which has been widely publicized throughout the city. The tickets are timed, but even with that control of crowds, the exhibit was so so so crowded. This museum would benefit from a no photo policy, which would help the crowd keep moving (and enjoying the artwork in the moment). 

The Magritte exhibit itself was quite good, though - very well curated and  many less popular images with a great narrative woven through. 

If you happen to have a membership card, be sure to have an additional ID with the member's name on it. (They don't actually seem to check the ID so much as wanting to see if you have the audacity to present one - if you catch my drift.)
author: Jess L.

description:
SF MOMA is a beautifully remodeled museum. The building itself is nice to walk through from the layout, the simplicity, the staircases, the shapes of the windows, the bridge at the top where you can see everything far down below you...

The admission at $50 is way to high in my opinion. At least kids are free. Luckily we were able to go on a free family day. Otherwise, we would probably never have gone.

Maybe I am not sophisticated enough in my art tastes, but I didn't really care for most of the art. There were a few exhibits that I enjoyed, but for the most part, I didn't understand the "oohs" and "aahs" about them.
author: Sara T.

description:
First-time visit. Highlights include:

- A variety of collection. Pop/ comic art, post-modern abstract paintings,  photography of the 1990s, huge spider sculptures (in photo below), etc. A LOT to look at, explore, and digest. At least 1.5 hours to go through all 7 floors! 

- Overall ambiance: Urban, innovative, cozy, spacious, adventurous. SF MOMA does a great job integrating its identity each part of the museum. 

From the signature IG spot--steel sculpture, to the "Designed in CA" exhibits lettered in bright orange (that introduces  & showcases all the tech inventions like Tesla, Mac iOS & their prototypes ), every gallery has its unique charm, style, and genre & invites the audience to venture into its mystery. 

- Sightglass coffee in the building! The perfect combo of an innovative cafe & playful, interactive tech facilities on the same floor. 

While waiting for your Latte, there's an interactive space designated for guests to play with. One facility snaps a photo of your face while asking you to place an item on the sensor screen. The machine then incorporates your face image w/ the item into a black & white photo print. Fun souvenir to take home. 

ALSO, it was a pleasant surprise to find a few hidden gems.

- SFMOMA Library: Open-space, kids-friendly, couches + pillow- available, modern-designed, neatly organized library near the 2F lobby entrance. **You do not need a museum ticket to enter.** 

This library offers books & magazines on Graphic design, Architecture, Photography, Fashion, as well as children illustrated books on NYC museum guides, social justice, fine art, & more. Kids can lie on the couch & big pillows to read their favorite books. This place is a perfect hangout place for young families on Summer breaks! 

- 2 Ways of getting FREE tickets: 
1) Chase Arts & Culture card: Year-round unlimited access for 2+ guests. Does not need to be the designated cardholder to get a ticket. 
2) San Mateo County Discover & Go card: Offered at public libraries (Burlingame, Millbrae, San Mateo, etc.) for 2+ guests for one-time access per year.
author: Jess W.

description: I smoked a joint and walked around this place for hours. So many cool and outside the box type artwork. I originally just wanted to see the Rothko, but I was pleasantly surprised by everything else available to see. There's a restaurant with a really beautiful outdoor patio as well.
author: Jess B.

description:
The SFMOMA is extensive as it takes up 11 floors yet 7 are open to the public as the other four floors are office buildings for workers.

Probably my favorite part of the museum was the room on the second floor right after you check in as this room features an eclectic array of what is on offer & was a good overview in a single area. This area has works by Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera, Pablo Picasso, & Salvador Dali. 

The living wall on the third floor is interesting as basically features a large extensive garden on a wall that is pretty cool.

The Andy Warhol paintings on the fifth floor shouldn't be missed & if you love books don't miss the latest branch of the San Francisco Public Library which is the Public Knowledge Library on the second floor. 

This is a non-circulating library w/ a well curated selection of books & changing exhibits. They currently have a vinyl listening station w/ a focus on music in San Francisco along w/ a card catalog from the San Francisco Main Library.
author: Shane S.

description:
This is a gorgeous space with some pretty stand out works of art. And there are a lot of ways to enjoy it without paying admission.

This museum has a lot of public spaces, particularly the coffeeshop at the 3rd Street entrance and the stadium seating at the Howard Street entrance. There's public bathrooms and it's just a nice space to hang out. 

To learn more about the works of art available to the public, take the free public space tour offered every afternoon. You'll learn about Richard Serra's Sequence, Sol LeWitt's Loopy Doopy, and Frida Kahlo's wedding self-portrait with her husband Diego. Check the website for the hours. The curator who does these tours is fantastic. It's like getting a mini lesson in art history. 

There are also a few ways to get free admission. Some local employers (such as Credit Karma) offer free admission to employees. The Chase Private Client "Arts and Culture" card also offers free admission for cardholder and one guest. You need a minimum of $250k investable assets with Chase to qualify. Unfortunately, SFMOMA doesn't offer any community free days, nor does it participate in Bank of America's "Museums on Us" program, as other museums in the Bay Area do. 

Some of my favorite works in this museum are Joseph Albers colored squares and Sol LeWitt gallery, particularly the brightly colored lines that you walk through.
author: Julia C.

description: Love this museum! Love their collection of contemporary art; although, I wish that section was bigger! All in all, they cover all the art bases and if you're a fan of museums, this is one of the better ones! I also really enjoyed their cafe! A bit overpriced, but all the desserts were in the shape of art - which was super cool! Had to indulge!
author: Jessi J.

description:
I know I'm an art person, but this museum rocks. I'd even say it might be better than the MoMA in New York. But don't tell New York!

Leave at least two hours to wander around here, ideally 3. So much to see and so much great art.

Highlights for me were the Cy Twombly pieces and cafe with outdoor seating. Also loved the neon pink and purple bathrooms!

I hope to come back soon!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Have you ever wanted to go somewhere, but decided not to because of the cost? Well for me, that's the story of my life.

Because of my anxiety, I'll rarely spend money on something if I don't deem it to be absolutely worthwhile. And since it's nearly impossible to tell whether something will be "worthwhile" until I give it a shot, I miss out on a lot of opportunities. 

The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SF MOMA) serves as a perfect example. Since hearing about the SF MOMA many years ago, I've always wanted to check it out. However, the cost seemed too expensive and plenty of "yah buts..." kept preventing me from going. 

Well last weekend, I took a leap of faith and decided to visit the SF MOMA with my girlfriend. I can't believe I'm saying this but the museum was worth every penny I paid! I'm so glad I went because the galleries were beautiful, the space was ginormous, and best of all I actually didn't end up emptying my entire wallet!

Founded in 1935, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art houses one of the world's largest collections of masterpieces made during the 1860s-late 1960s. In the museum, there are 7 giant floors filled with gorgeous, powerful artworks from geniuses such as Jeff Koons. It was a journey for my girlfriend and me to be able to conquer every inch of this museum while also learning a thing or two. 

To truly describe my "worthwhile" adventure in a meaningful way, I have to break it into 7 parts - each one representing a floor inside the SF MOMA: 

-- PART 0, FLOOR 0: THE PREPARATION --
Before every journey comes the planning. For us, we wisely decided to BART from the East Bay. Since traffic around this area SUCKED and the closest parking lot (along Minna Street) charged $4/half hour, why not do yourself a favor and walk? It's only a few blocks from Montgomery BART. Furthermore, we had bought tickets ahead of time online to avoid waiting at the booth. Omg, admission was more affordable than I had thought - $25 for adults, $22 for seniors, and $19 for those ages 19-24. I'm 24!

-- PART 1, FLOOR 1: TRANQUIL BEGINNINGS -- 
Our adventure began with the gift shop, where we spent a bit of time perusing through various items that were on sale. Unlike at most museums, this store had a bunch of neat things ranging from bike accessories to cookbooks! Before making our way to the next stage, we deposited our belongings at the check-in. NOTE: They do allow you to bring bags, but you have to wear your bag in front.

-- PART 2, FLOOR 2: A PROVOCATIVE CLIMB --
It started with a bang, as we were faced with very creative and thought provoking pieces. Even now I can't get the image of Michael Duchamp's "Fountain" out of my head. 

-- PART 3, FLOOR 3: A LOST HISTORY --
Coming in, I had no idea how impactful the art on this floor would be. But after experiencing "The Train - RFK's Last Journey" firsthand, I understood. The masterpieces here depicted people's experiences while witnessing the funeral train of Robert F. Kennedy - yep, the actual blood brother of JFK.

-- PART 4, FLOOR 4: A MUDDY MUSE --
After realizing that RFK was murdered just two months after the death of MLK, I left the third floor with a sinking feeling in my stomach. Yet, that pain turned into inspiration when we gazed intently at Robert Rauschenberg's "Mud Muse." If mud could be considered art, I can do anything!

-- PART 5, FLOOR 5: THE CHILLING CLIMAX -- 
Most adventures have an obstacle. For me, it was overcoming my fear of heights and spiders. First we mustered enough strength to cross the Oculus Bridge, a porous pathway on which one could see into hell. Then, we raced through Louise Bourgeois' "Spiders", a creepy exhibit filled with "artistic" spiders.  

-- PART 6, FLOOR 6: A STUMBLE TO THE END --
Having spent most of our energy braving the challenges of floor 5, my girlfriend and I were exhausted. How much was left? We wanted to turn back, but we knew the finish line was near. What kept us motivated was the "Designed in California" gallery, a room filled with cool tech such as the first Apple computer.

-- PART 7, FLOOR 7: UNTIL WE MEET AGAIN --
At last, we made it to the top! Our effort was well-rewarded, since this floor had an incredible view, a theater room with THREE SEPARATE SCREENS, an archaic printer that continually spat out present-day news, and a FREE POSTER! Capping off a happy ending, we enjoyed a nice elevator-ride back down to the first floor. 

All in all, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art was definitely one heck of an activity that I'm so thankful to have experienced. I can ramble on about the SF MOMA but the Yelp gods will cut me off - and I haven't even begun to describe how aesthetically pleasing the interior of the museum was. For now, I'll just say that the SF MOMA was worthy of an "Omg, I'd travel 2 hours for this" rating. Please check it out if you can!

Have fun and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
I confess that modern art is not something I understand. Still, museums are my thing when it comes to meandering through exhibits and seeing the world through a different lens.

At SF MOMA, for just $25, you can enjoy 7 floors of paintings, sculptures, interactive pieces and more. I was advised by the ticket guy to check out the new exhibit first, which is always a good idea since the run dates are limited. 

There's quite a lot to see so be sure to pace yourself. And honestly this is the kind of place to go alone so you can linger as you please. On the particular day I visited, the staff were setting up a new exhibit so only 6 floors were available to view. 

Very cool to see Andy Warhol's work and even the creepy spider sculptures were amusing and amazing all at once.

Perhaps my favorite part of the museum wasn't inside but the larger then life sculptures outside!

Always good to know that there is a museum cafe and ample bathrooms on each floor, though each bathroom was like a work of art itself. In one, the entire bathroom was magenta, another was tomato red. You'd be surprised at how your eyes imagine you're in an infrared oven.

A gift shop is on the ground floor is open an hour past museum closing in case you want a memento like a t-shirt ($28 and sizes run small) or grocery bag ($14.99). 

Definitely a fun way to spend a couple of hours on your own and soak in some culture and art! Enjoy!
author: Sharon H.

description:
I really liked this museum. It's not too big. We only had two hours but I feel like we got through a lot of it and saw some nice exhibitions. There was a special photography exhibit by one artist and it was more interesting than I initially thought. The gift store is nice and big. Wish some of the jewelry was a little more youthful. Great place to visit!

They have required/complimentary (FREE) bag/coat check locations which are actually awesome and helpful.
author: Thien H.

description:
LOVIN' SF MOMA!

This museum takes the place of one of my favorite museums I've ever been to. The museum closes at 5pm everyday except Wednesday (Wednesdays the museum is closed) but is opened late nights (until 9pm) on Thursdays.  The gift shop is on the ground floor and opened an hour later than the museum. Parking is available right in front of the museum in a parking garage, which makes it easy to walk just right across. 

The museum has a coat check, that wasn't available when we went for some reason. Tickets for this museum are $25. Free for military. Different prices for members and maybe group prices. The museum ticket they give you is also a sticker you can put on. 

I recommend starting at the top level (which is level 6 I think) and working your way down to the first floor. Some of my favorite art exhibits included the living wall, the LOVE sign, the Kennedy train ride exhibit, and the designed in California exhibit was pretty cool to see.   

Some of the coolest exhibits i saw were temporary exhibits and only there until May 1st. To check the most recent exhibits, i would check their website. 

Tip*** I recommend either starting at the top level of the museum and working your way down or starting with the temporary exhibits first.
author: Carly E.

description:
SF MOMA is a beautiful museum worthy of a world class city.  The permanent collection here is worth your time and dime.  Many modern museums are not home to such a varied, worthwhile selection. This museum puts MOCA LA to shame.
Magritte was showing when we visited - it was a beautifully curated program with depth, well arranged.  It was busy, but not claustrophobic.  
The wonderful surprise for me was the graphic arts section.  It's small, but it packed a mighty punch with posters by Stephen Frykholm for Herman Miller.  I could have looked at a graphic arts exhibit many times bigger.  The photography section as well was thoughtful...I easily recall what I saw and draw inspiration from it.  Isn't that the sign of a successful exhibit?
Even the cafes here are worth a stop!
author: Jay S.

description:
To be completely honest, I do love museums but I didn't overly love the MOMA. It is very much possible that I just don't understand modern art but a certain feeling of hypocrisy was gripping me for most of my visit. Many of the exhibits were interesting but I ended up being quite bothered by the Robert Rauschenberg exhibit. I'll go into more detail about my thoughts on it.

So, all of his artwork is meant to bring attention to poverty and the other injustices of the world, through a combination of paintings, sculptures, and fabrics. While it's great that he wanted to bring attention to this, I couldn't help but consider how silly and ironic his exhibit is. In a city so forcefully impacted by poverty, homelessness, and income divides, his artwork takes up a massive amount of room inside a huge building in the middle of downtown. I can't help but think that this space could be better used to make spaces for those who have so little so that they don't have to spend their nights out on the streets. I have a huge appreciation for artists - especially those who attempt to bring attention to those who are less fortunate - but I really believe that this is completely the opposite of what Rauschenberg would have wanted for this exhibit.

Someone did bring up to me that this could be the exhibit working exactly as hoped since I was honestly disgusted with the situation and thinking much more critically about the injustices of society... but I have a hard time believing that. I'll be doing more research on the exhibit, as well as the artist, but for the time being, I think I'll stick to appreciating the beauty of nature and history.
author: Simon L.

description:
One of the finest and largest collections of modern art not just in the Western U.S. but perhaps anywhere in the world, SFMOMA is all the more compelling these days after having reopened after several years of renovations which included the construction of a new wing.

While, like many other museums, SFMOMA does rely on major exhibitions to attract a steady stream of visitors, I found its permanent collections most compelling. The new Fisher galleries, from the founders of Gap, feature many compelling and relatable works from artists such as Diebenkorn, Calder, Lichtenstein, Kelly, Richter, Warhol, de Kooning, and more.

The architecture itself is also noteworthy, whether the original building and its prominent, circular, angled atrium, or the new building that's simultaneously edgy and curvy. 

Tickets are timed here, so it's best to reserve ahead of time online. They might be a bit spendy, but this is a museum well worth supporting. Plan to set aside at least half a day for exploring everything on offer here.
author: Vincent L.

description:
The MOMA is really a staple of San Francisco, a must see for both those visiting SF and those who live here. 

Yes, it's absurdly expensive. And no I'm not certain that it's worth it. There are a couple ways to get free or discounted admission, but it's a little hard to come by (google is your friend). But if you can afford it, do come. This is one of the largest museums in SF, and it really holds an amazing assortment of pieces. 

If you do make it in, I would HIGHLY recommend going up to the 7th floor where they house their larger scale exhibits. 

Also, if they have them while you visit, the little activity corners are great for all ages. 

Overall, I come here pretty often, and honestly I love the SF MOMA.
author: Sophie W.

description:
I go to so many museums living in NY that when I travel I only sometimes hit up a museum. Unless I'm traveling for an exhibit, that's a whole other story. I have been known to travel to Seattle and LA for specific shows. 

This time I was traveling to SF for a concert. I did do some research on museums and noticed that SFMOMA had only one of my favorites, Louise Bourgeois presenting her iconic Spiders!! I find these larger than life spider sculptures absolutely irresistible. There was no way I was going to miss these and I didn't. 

After a long day of hitting up my must see to do list. I made it to the museum. I'm so happy it was during the work week and I was able to enjoy the art without too many people.

I didn't go straight to spiders. I enjoyed the Frida Kahlo piece, the Marches Duchamp "R.Mutt urinal", the photographs from Walker Evans, the gigantic Lichtenstein and Warhol pieces. And the finally the cherry on top was the spiders. They were breathtaking as usual! They were laid out in the unusual manner, crawling on walls and scattered around. I was more than happy. 

This museum is a definite must visit while in San Francisco! I will be making sure to continue to pay a visit in every visit. 

The staff was helpful and knowledgeable, especially Erin. She even talked to me about the work she was doing for the upcoming Diego Rivera show. I like to hear about the work that goes into an exhibition.  The story of the arrival I find just as interesting as the work. Thank you for taking that time to indulge me.
author: Carolina S.

description: I spend three hours here today and was blown away by the excellent display of world quality art I had the pleasure of admiring. I only spent time at one of the floors. I can't wait to go back. I became a member. Please look at the pictures I took. INCREDIBLE!
author: Avelino C.

description:
I don't typically understand, and therefore enjoy, modern art, but SF Moma has started changing my views on it. 

I've been a couple of times now and each time I find something new and interesting to be fascinated by. The latest trip was specifically to see the Magritte exhibit.  This was an amazing showcase of his work (which you may recognize from the movie the Thomas Crowne Affair) and a must see. The interactive portion at the end is fun to play around with and let's you be part of the art. 

Aside from the art on display, the museum itself is lovely to look at and has many spots to sit, relax, and people watch. The outdoor spaces in particular, when SF weather cooperates, are a good place to hang out and admire the outdoor exhibits of statues and the living wall.
author: Joanne T.

description:
YELP 100 CHALLENGE 2018 - 93/100. 

I'm not one to have a high level of appreciation for art since I've never really been exposed to its depths. But checking out SFMOMA was a good way to kill some time on a slow Sunday afternoon. 

Coat check is free. Audio is $6/pp or FREE if you download the app on your iPhone. There were very many interesting pieces to look at. It was a delight to find pieces by familiar artists (Roy Lichtenstein , Jackson Pollack and Andy Warhol) and learning about unfamiliar ones (Sam Francis, Anselm Kiefer, Yasumasa Morimura, etc.) Some were interesting, others, not so much. (A couch covered in newspaper topped with a couple of vases? Not really sure how that's called art. But then again, as previously mentioned, I'm not one to have an eye for such things.) 

There are a couple of cafe's located on the 2nd and 3rd floors. Outside seating is best during a clear day. 

They had an exhibit called The Train which showed RFK'S final journey to his final resting place. Hubbers and I sat through most of it. It was moving and almost heart breaking. I find it strange to feel such affection for it when I wasn't even born when all that went down. Regardless, this might have been the most interesting part of my tour.

I didn't realize how quickly time went by until I looked at my watch. I guess I had more fun than I anticipated. 

There are plenty of parking lots in its immediate surroundings, but Hubbers and I opted to take Bart and walk the few blocks. 

Buy your tix online to avoid any delays at arrival.

Educational for small and big kids alike. But don't take my word for it - come check it out! You might just learn something new like I did!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I had a really good time visiting the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art with my friends this past Saturday. If it didn't cost $25 to get in this would have been a 5 star experience. However, that's just too much money for me to want to come frequently, so I will likely only go back next year or the year after. 

I haven't been to this museum in over 10 years and not only has that been an extremely long time, it has been remodeled since the last time I was here. 

I really enjoyed their permanent collection on the ground floor and saw works by Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera, Salvador Dali, etc. I spent more time than usual examining most of the pieces and reading the descriptions. I love how art forces you to think outside the box and expand your consciousness. Art definitely inspires me to think more about human behavior and consciousness and our interactions and impact on other humans and the planet. I really do think $25 is cost prohibitive for many people to have access to these experiences. 

Overall, a great day at the SFMOMA and I feel inspired to seek out more art in San Francisco.
author: Regina W.

description:
MoMA is home away from home for me. I mainly go on Thursday nights because it's quieter and there aren't many people there. I couldn't give it five starts because I would love to see more exhibits by people of color and people with different perspectives. 

This is definitely my favorite place to escape.
author: Camille P.

description:
fee-fi-MOMA.......I see a painting on the wall.

As many times as I have traveled to San Francisco, I had yet to visit the SF MOMA.  Thankfully, this past November, I had the opportunity/chance to visit the museum with my family.

The museum was just mesmerizing honestly.  One could spend several hours, or perhaps all day, exploring the exhibitions, paintings, sculptures, and open spaces of the MOMA.  However, with that being said, as with all my other museum reviews, I will try to keep this simple and short.  I'll briefly mention a few highlights of my visit:

1.  The entrance/atrium on the first floor is enormous and provides the visitor of an idea of the enormity of the vast space they are about to walk through.

2.  Robert Serra's "Sequence", or the MAZE as my brother and sister-in-law call it, is a massive sculpture in the Roberts Family Gallery.  And a word of advice to future visitors:  there are various signs advising "no touching" as though the sculpture make look sturdy, it is far from it.  Please be careful.  Needless to say, it was fun to wander thru the curves and passages of "Sequence".

3.  Louise Bourgeois' spiders.  Various spiders of shapes and sizes are spread across the fifth floor exhibition area.  According to the museum website, the artist viewed these creatures as fierce and fragile, seemingly doubling as both protector and predator.  Although some look menacing, other spiders just looked peaceful or just needing to be left alone.  And others were so tall that one could stand beneath them (though one really shouldn't as there are museum attendants present).

4.  Bill Fontana sonic shadows.  Exhibition utilizing the fifth floor oculus bridge, transforming the sounds of footsteps into acoustics blending with recording of other real-time sounds.  To be brutally honest, I mainly wanted to step across the bridge and didn't really notice the sounds or blending of sounds.  The view is scenic from the pedestrian bridge though, a cool vantage point.

5.  Photography exhibit by Walker Evans.  Two sections spanning areas of the third floor.  Though I was not familiar with the works/photos of Mr. Evans, I truly admired his candid photos from the depression.  The photos allow visitors to view the disparity facing the American population at that point in history.  And for some reason, unbeknownst to me, I felt captivated by the many photos of various storefronts, and the many candids of people on NYC subway and "people watching" around NYC.

6.  "The Visitors" by Ragnar Kjartansson.  Amazing, amazing musical interactive exhibition.  This was incredible!!  Make sure to visit the seventh floor!

7.  The sculpture garden and terrace areas were lovely spaces were one could take a break from the inside crowds.  Just an fyi, the sculpture garden on the fifth floor is much larger than that on the third floor, plus its located adjacent to the Cafe 5 restaurant.

BOTTOM LINE:
A very memorable and mesmerizing visit at the SF MOMA.  People of all ages will truly enjoy all the exhibits, art, and sculptures at this museum.
author: Michael C.

description:
A great museum! We had a lot of fun exploring its many floors and seeing the wide variety of art displayed here. There were lots of different formats of art (paintings, sculptures, multimedia, installations, etc) and something new around every corner. The top floor and seeing the Mark Rothko were our favorite parts! And picking up a kitschy fridge magnet to bring home from the gift shop. 

Prepare to pay way too much to park in a nearby structure though! But that's classic SF and to be expected.
author: Jordan W.

description:
Such a beautiful venue. I came here especially for the Rene Magritte exhibit in Aug 2018 (which I enjoyed very much), but was blown away by the venue itself. The SF MOMA was closed for over 2 years while they renovated the place and from the looks of it I can see why it took so long; it was definitely worth the wait. 

I like the 5th floor where they have an outdoor open air area. It was an awesome place to get some air after all the amazing art inside the museum takes your breath away. 

I plan on coming back many times as they showcase new artists.
author: Simon S.

description: The sound exhibit from last year (2017) was absolutely mind-blowing. SF MOMA always has something unique and contemporary that caters to the masses, and not only just for the museum enthusiast. I think what sets this museum apart is the strive for storytelling, technological expression and diversity. A great place to hang out with visitors and show off how cool SF is.
author: Theresa Thao N.

description:
SAN FRANCISCO MUSEUM OF MODERN ART (SFMOMA) has become a last day tradition when visiting San Francisco. A stay at the St Regis Hotel right next door makes it an easy in and out. 

SFMOMA was one of the first museums on the West Coast devoted solely to 20th century art. There is over 33,000 pieces of modern art in the collection. SFMOMA also houses its own cafe that serve fresh ingredients and desserts on their menu. You can dine inside or outside while looking at huge sculptural works in the cafe courtyard. 

It's a modern art lover's paradise. I highly recommend spending a few hours there. There are permanent pieces in their collection, as well as new expanding collections that are highlighted. 

The photos are a few of my favs from my visit December 2017.
author: Elaine O.

description: I really enjoy modern art and have loved the SF MOMA in the past but feel like my last couple of visits have left me disappointed. Attendants seem irritated at the crowds and aren't friendly. With free entry this isn't a bad way to spend an afternoon but come for the special exhibits (which have an additional charge) ... the rest is hit or miss. Also know that there are hour plus lines for the special exhibits and all the crowds may take away from the experience, depending on your preferences.
author: Jessica C.

description: This is a very big museum, so pace yourself or you will faint. Many of the gigantic works really affect your perspective, so take it easy. I really enjoyed the modern collection, there are not many famous works of art, but it is an interesting collection nonetheless. I also took advantage of the special exhibit, which was Rene Magritte, but I found it gimmicky and hence I took one star out. Not a must stop unless you really like Calder.
author: Julio H.

description: This would have been enjoyable except they made us wear our backpacks on the front since we didn't want to check them.  This gave both of us sore backs and we cut our visit short due to the pain.  What is the point of this restriction?
author: Susan B.

description:
To paraphrase the imminently quotable Vesper Lynd, there are art museums and there are art museums. This is one of the latter.

Consider first the sheer variety of the exhibits on display: room upon room of abstract masterpieces, a collection of early photography sure to make even the most seasoned shutterbug blush, and as if that weren't enough, an entire floor dedicated to the representation of sound as art. If that doesn't satisfy your cultural urges, there are sculptures and pop art galore, as well as a collection of mid-century activist paraphernalia that's nothing if not a fitting tribute to San Francisco's counterculture heritage.

Are certain exhibits more immersive than others? Certainly. As many reviewers have noted, "The Visitors" by Ragnar Kjartansson steals the show on the seventh floor, and the sense of post-WWII dread is palpable in Anselm Kiefer's large scale masterpieces, which dominate the exhibit on German art.

Even the building itself, all modern lines and progressive architecture, serves as its own form of art, although some of the outdoor sculpture areas were regrettably closed during my visit. However, that's a nit too insignificant to pick given the unbelievably satisfying nature of the visit as a whole, which deserves only this unqualified endorsement: 

Go here. You won't regret it.
author: Charles G.

description:
SFMOMA, I'll always remember you as the museum in which I burst into tears. Early into my first visit I stumbled into the room housing "The Visitors" by Ragnar Kjartansson. I was drawn in by the music and once inside, the immersive nature and overwhelming sadness buoyed by hope in the melody led to be crying uncontrollably. As someone who hates to cry, especially in public, I bounced after about 30 seconds and spent a solid half hour trying to regain my composure and get the song out of my head. 

As I continued to wander I found treasure after treasure - the scope of the museum is tremendous. I hadn't done any research before going and only had a couple of hours before I had to hit the airport, so my swift pace led to a lot of great pieces - Warhol's "Triple Elvis," the Live Personal Soundtrack (which was sadly unmanned when I got to it), a Rothko, Duchamp's "Fountain," and more. 

Before I left I knew I'd regret not getting the full experience of "The Visitors" - no museum piece had ever knocked me over like that before - and returned to the dark room. It was lovely wandering the "halls" and letting myself get taken over by the melody - I still cried like a baby but this time I was ready with tissue in hand. 

There's lots of can't-miss stuff at SFMOMA - do yourself a favor and block out an afternoon to enjoy it.
author: Stacey L.

description:
My 1,350th review!

On 3/26/2018 when I still roaming around in San Francisco before heading to AT&T Park, I visited to this fascinating local museum located between SoMa and Financial District neighborhoods called, the "San Francisco Museum of Modern Arts" (aka SF MOMA). SF MOMA brings various of visitors near and far to explore their collections of greatest artworks and sculptures from the past to the present every 365 days a year! The atmosphere and the concept remain the same as most modern arts museums has across the world (i.e. Crocker Art Museum in Sacramento, CA), and as for the SF MOMA, it's pretty spacious and humongously wide covering 7 stories (aka. floors) tall in a huge, big rectangular building!

The employees here are doing a great job for accommodating the customers like me a tremendous and well received service! No cons.

Now onto the experience! Since I purchased a GA entry for $25 per person inside, I explored the floors entirely from various of artists and creators. I really loved how this museum has some good collections of Andy Warhol's pop art paintings from Elvis Presley to Marilyn Monroe as well as his self-portrait painting back in 1986 too. Additionally, the Rebecca Horn's "Seufzer der Steine (Translation: "The Sights of Stones)" was extraordinarily by playing the violins eerie and wicked right directly in a mechanical turning machine. Gorgeous. The Hans Haacke's "News" is simply spellbounding to me by printing various of latest news articles from local to the world using the late 1980s style printer. I did read some articles after it was printed originally, and these latest recent events can be dramatic or sometimes, it can be fun to read! Cool concept for that display! Finally, in the sculpture area, both Dan Flavin and Sol LeWitts masterpieces are breathtaking! Dan's two illuminating lights display are lit up wonderfully by showcasing the displays on modern artwork of fluorescent lights and Sol's "Wall Grid" is simply not that bad showing every cubes on different formats of openings and bendable angles. Yes, I did spent around 3 hours inside the museum entirely, and it was an unbelievable visit covering every aspects in the building. An experience it remember!

Taking a break is an easy thing to do cause they have a coffee shop on the 3rd floor as well as the rooftop outdoor and indoor dining area too located at the next few floors upwards. On every Thursday, they have good amounts of nightlife events as well as various of artwork and displays special exhibitions too every two or three months of the year. Finally, there's a museum store inside the museum where you can shop endless of artwork related materials, books, and accessories.

Parking at SF MOMA can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street parking nor the parking garage if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

Bottom line, the SF MOMA is the most incredible and outstanding modern arts museum that I've ever visited for the very first time! Perfect for art lovers and tourists alike! A well received! My rating: 5 solid stars.
author: William L.

description:
What a beautiful museum! I mean it's hard to review museums as a whole because there are so many different exhibits, etc. but, the SF MoMA itself is a beautiful building that houses some great art! It also has great restaurants, coffee roasters, etc. 

I visited the museum last month and as a yelp employee we get free access just by showing our badge. Cool perk eh?! Anyway, I was interested in the Munch exhibit because I'm a fan of "the scream" painting and didn't know much about the painter himself. As it turns out, he's pretty dark, loved self portraits throughout his life and lived in a war torn era. There's a lot of influence from wartime conditions in his art and its haunting. 

The exhibition ends on October 9th, so get in asap as it's well curated and worth the stop. I mean, unless you want to travel to Oslo, this is your best bet.
author: Benjamin F.

description: Just went to see the Magritte exhibit. So amazing! I love the SFMoMa! I wish I lived closer. I hope you all can visit.
author: Vince L.

description:
SFMOMA, Have My Children!  Please!  You Are Gorgeous!

SITREP

Got to see some authentic Edvard Munch paintings finally! ;)
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-francisco-museum-of-modern-art-san-francisco-6?select=wbrhHAbjHk-z46jgoNdjzA&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

THE SETUP

My favorite Naval Commander Jeff R. and his awesome CSI wife, Kristie A, invited me to trek along on their journey to the SFMOMA (San Francisco Museum of Modern Art) where we enjoyed oh.so.many exhibitions and displays of fantastic art.
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-francisco-museum-of-modern-art-san-francisco-6?select=RnUBG2gbEiZMF0YLJBHxsw&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

And though this is a museum of "Modern Art", don't think that this just means within the last 50 years.  As the centerpiece exhibition of Edvard Munch these last few months indicates (and through October 6, I think?  So quick!  GO!), there is a dynamic variety of art from many different movements and cultures over the last few hundred years and from all around the world.

THE ART!

So many fantantic displays!

* EDVARD MUNCH

Talk about dark, obsessions, and depressing subject-matter!  Gripping, Tragic, Profound.  I found it all to be incredibly thought-provoking:

   THE DARK SIDE - some of his work is quite disturbing, if not downright scary:
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-francisco-museum-of-modern-art-san-francisco-6?select=Cw4pPhyo-TxC-a1nLwCAVg&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

   THE DYING - there were whole rooms that focused on his paintings of both "the sick" and "the dying" - particularly gripping:
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-francisco-museum-of-modern-art-san-francisco-6?select=qAxFR_-zMFxwDQqs3tXA6Q&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

    ART VS. CHILD PORNOGRAPHY - and in all seriousness, it's interesting to note the difference in cultural mores over different times & places when measuring how "yesterday's art" could be considered today's child pornography with the subject-matter of adolescent girls - not a judgement, but merely an observation - I think it would prove fascinating to have an ancillary discussion about whether the image here in Munch's painting "Puberty" if captured instead on film today would land the photographer in prison:
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-francisco-museum-of-modern-art-san-francisco-6?select=3IbWZekyTEp7E8O6pjB38w&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

* ANDY WARHOL

* It's always a fun trek down POP CULTURE to see the works of Andy Warhol, and luckily the 
SFMOMA has many of his works in residence here.
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-francisco-museum-of-modern-art-san-francisco-6?select=oKzeyMd0u7j_pWFmvUIRyw&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

* THE RANDOM!

    I found this picture to be GOOD ADVICE for "45"
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-francisco-museum-of-modern-art-san-francisco-6?select=Jdvxujq0xQLeEJWxNkPheQ&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

    And oh so many other artists with amazing works, though my favorite picture I took at SFMOMA was of the little cute human who wanted to be in the picture.  :D
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-francisco-museum-of-modern-art-san-francisco-6?select=7qZVRGd6-szbZ1YSlmEA1Q&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

PHYSICAL PLANT & LAYOUT

Okay.  This is where it gets real:  there are SEVEN (7) levels to this museum, and most of the time, our crew wandered up and down the levels by stairs.  And they are lonnnnng stairs.  I mean, lonnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnng stairs.  You will note immediately each floor has very high ceilings, and hence, the lonnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnng stairs.

But have no fear!  There is a great bank of elevators that you can use to jet up & down between the levels.  We just wanted the work out, and sometimes it seemed pretty rediculous to use the elevator to just go up or down one level.

The rooms are spacious, airy and very very well lighted.  There was both a tasteful blend of artificial light along with skylights.  It was interesting to note that when a heavy layer of overcast hit the sky from time to time, the interior lights were obviously synced to maintain a certain lighting level in each room as the natural lighting diminished or increased.  *Science* :)

THE LOWDOWN

Fantastic museum set-up that beautifully displays the works of art that it is entrusted with showcasing.
author: Michelangelo S.

description:
I love modern art and this used to be my favorite museum, so it saddens me to rate SFMOMA poorly.  I have an art degree and have visited museums around the world, but I can't afford to go to the museum in my own city.  The enormous LOUVRE in PARIS offers more discounts and free options than greedy SFMOMA.  

I miss visiting SFMOMA, but there are no options within my budget.  Their apparent free day hasn't been updated in over 5 months on the website so I have no way of knowing when that mysterious day might be, but at only once per year, they're hardly giving back to the community.

The inaccessible cost of admission only further increases the already dire ignorance about modern art.  I've heard otherwise intelligent San Franciscans spout embarrassingly ignorant criticisms of modern art, likely because they can't afford the cost of a ticket to inform themselves of what they failed to learn in school.  This is how a city falls into cultural decline.  

Art has a powerful impact on the culture of a city.  An institution as important as SFMOMA has a responsibility to make art accessible to all San Franciscans, not just the rich.
author: Pho Q.

description:
When you come here, make sure to wear comfortable shoes! Because it's like 7 floors of just amazing art!

I fell in loveee with this museum! It is enormous and well worth the money. They have so many beautiful pieces, this place is a must!!
author: Dayana P.

description:
There were a few good exhibits, but I would say about only 20% of the museum impressed us - the rest was incredibly boring and repetitive. 

They do a good job of interactive displays, I just wish they would do more of them. There were fantastic musical and light displays, but it was a small handful of the overall museum. 

I guess at least I got a lot of walking in  - that's a positive right? I just can't justify the $25 per person price.. maybe $15. I've been to other Modern Art Museums, and this one unfortunately falls near the bottom.

I would also not recommend purchasing tickets ahead of time online - if your flight gets cancelled and you need to adjust the date it is a bit of a headache with them. I would say wait until you are in person to get the tickets and if you can't get tickets it's not a huge loss.
author: Mary P.

description:
I was here for an event and loved the atmosphere. Did walk through part of the gallery and it was spacious and lovely. It's often rented out as an event venue and it was a very nice way to experience the museum. 

Really enjoyed the evening here and walked through some art sections. I must admit my knowledge of modern art is slim but I liked what I saw.
author: Sam S.

description:
I LOVE this place! So much so, I decided to get the annual membership. Let me start from the beginning. 

My friend saw some pictures on Instagram, and said "let's go" to me. And me, always up for an adventure said "sure. Let's go thursday because they're open late on Thursday." Best decision EVER. I've been hesitant to come up until now because I've always heard that it was super busy during the weekends, and I work during the regular work week. So the fact that they are open on a Thursday until 9 pm, just because (and not a special event night to draw bigger crowds), is a big plus. So if you ever want to go through a museum without the large crowds, Thursday night is your night. And its a nice way to break up your work week. 

If you can do it, take the stairs. It's part of the experience having the artwork reveal itself as you walk up to it. It's like having the curtains drawn at the theater. 

Also, don't touch any of the art. Some pieces are more inviting for a touch, but don't touch, the staff and security gets very angry (they scolded another patron). This also includes the sculpture bases. It may look like an anchor for the artwork, but its also part of the art. Also, don't get so close that you breathe on the art (eww). Only touch and breathe on what has a clear sign that you can touch. Keep an eye out for them, or ask if you can beforehand. There are several pieces that they invite touching. 

My friends and I walked up the first two floors, but decided to skip to the top floor and make our way down. There are eight floors of artwork to go through. I appreciate that there are outdoor balconies on every level so you can get some fresh air in between the exhibits/floors to avoid information overload. And there are a lot of pieces to go through. 

I really love sculpture pieces because of what the artist may or maynot name the piece. and the detail that they show in their work. And they're pretty amazing for instragrammable moments. 

When I look at paintings and photographs, I like to look at it up close, and from far away, and at different angles. The galleries here give me the space to do this. 

Cost: It's $25 for an adult for every visit. But they let you apply up to two general admission tickets to be applied to an annual membership. So I grabbed my friend's ticket, and applied it to my annual membership. I got the lowest tier at $100 for me and a guest, for as many times as I can come in a year. So as long as I come back two more times in the next year, I'll have come out ahead, not just financially, but also culturally. 

Pro-tip: if you're not sure you're going to like this place, get the general admission ticket for $25, and make your decision about the annual membership at the end of your trip. 

Pro-tip: Don't look at the art and say, I know a 5 year old can do better. It's ok to say you don't understand that artist's intention, and you won't always understand or know what the intention was. Also, look at the painting from several angles, and depths. Or you can make up a story about what you think was going through that artist's mind too.
author: Vicky L.

description: The new SFMOMA still feels new to me- this is the first time I have seen it since they tore down the old one, except for their signature skylight.   I wondered why they tore it down, but now it seems huge, and choc full of beautiful, thought provoking modern art.  I highly recommend it.
author: Karen F.

description:
I love you SFMOMA! You are my true love...if true love=a modern art museum. I got a membership this past March and I think it was well worth it. I have been so many times with a companion for member previews. I went to the Walker Evans member preview today. I loved the party. The John Brothers Piano Company was playing old-time music. I like the Walker Evans exhibit--so much of his work. I liked seeing Soundtracks again. I especially love Ragnar Kjartansson's The Visitors. One of my faves ever. I have seen the Munch exhibit at least 3 times. Nam June Paik exhibit is cool too. I like how there are new pieces in the rooms. I don't want to come and look at the same art all the time. Enjoy new pieces that I haven't seen before. Should have more obscure or lesser known artists.

Only problem is that there is often a reason why some security guard approaches me. Today it was because I got close to the wall. I was pointing at something and the guard told me not to touch the wall. The other time, I didn't have my backpack hanging on the front of my body instead of on my back. Ah well...
author: Denise C.

description:
Great museum!! With 7 floors of art you can pretty much spend the whole day here and not be bored. I was blown away with the collections. I have to say my absolute favorite was the temporary exhibit on the 7th floor called "soundtracks". For anyone who appreciates music this is a must!! Very cool and interactive, it's focus is in the relationship between sound and space. Exhibit is at the MoMA until January 2018 so plan accordingly, you won't be disappointed. 
Also, nice size collection of Andy Warhol- which is always a great thing! 
They have some outdoor sculptures and a living wall on the 3rd floor (I believe). These were also among my favorites!!
Overall I had a fantastic time and would come back every time I'm in S.F.
author: Lucia B.

description:
Had an excellent visit to SFMOMA today with my better half during our "hooky day" while traveling for our respective jobs. 

We asked the ticketing docent about how much time we should be budgeting, as we were supposed to meet friends after. He asked what our interests were and made excellent suggestions accordingly. 

Being a DJ, I found the "Soundtracks" collection on the 7th floor to be a real treat!  

Overall the collection is superb. Often collections are repetitive or sparse. Neither is the case here. You can get close enough to see any details you'd want to and pictures are not discouraged. 

A ticket price of $25 might seem high to some, but for us it was money well spent and we enjoyed ourselves immensely.
author: Luke A.

description:
Beautiful exhibits!!! I really enjoyed the spiders of Louise Bourgeois. The 7th floor, in my opinion, was very thought provoking of all of the themes floors. "Sublime Seas" brought me to tears along with the other video of the children being interviewed, and I loved the printer that printed the news nonstop. 
Regarding the location, very conveniently located near Bart. Plenty of parking nearby is located if you are driving. The facility was clean and well organized. I would have appreciated some more interactive/hands-on exhibits, but otherwise I enjoyed all of it.
author: Kat W.

description: We really enjoyed this place! It was very cool to see all of the cool art and the beautiful layout of everything! Not very pricy for a young adult it's 14$ the food was defiantly over priced and you cant bring a backpack in unless you were it on your front side, they do have a check or a "coat check" for your belongings, so that was nice (:
author: Erika M.

description:
If you've ever taken an art history class chances are quite a few works of art in your book will be from this museum. The artists represented here in this museum boggle the mind: Warhol, De Kooning, Lichtenstein, Matisse, Richter, Calder, Klee, Miro, Picasso, Rothko, Dali, Duchamp... the list goes on and on. I was excited to hear that Edvard Munch's works were on display for their special exhibit (Sans The Scream). Special exhibits will be an extra charge and will have to be scheduled for a certain time but you can browse through the general admission section of the museum at any time. You can reserve your time in person or online.

I was only really familiar with Munch's The Scream so it was fascinating to see the progression of his painting style from early to later days. I was also surprised to see that The Scream is actually one of his earlier pieces since it was one of his most famous paintings. 

For some of the most well known artists they only have one or two of their pieces for exhibit but I do like the variety of styles this museum represents. I could have spent hours examining each piece in person. We went to 6 of the 7 floors and focused mainly on the artists I was familiar with and spent 2-3 hours but if you really want to look at each piece available it can easily be a half day to a full day of soaking in so much talent in one building.

I had a great time and would love to go back next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Karen W.

description: Never disappointed here. The seventh floor is the best. The vegetarian food at cafe is super yummy. Store is unique and has items you won't fine elsewhere, which is rare at Museum stores. Parking was reasonable for the city and close to entrance.
author: Diana S.

description: my favorite favorite favorite exhibit is "Love is the Message, The Message is Death" film by Arthur Jafa on the 7th floor (Nothing Stable Under Heaven)  which has a collection of works addressing inequality, violence and political conflict. My second favorite is "Tilted Plane" by Jim Campbell because it's so immersive and mesmerizing.
author: Soojeong H.

description: One of my favor spot in the city. First visit since the major remodel.  The architects and designers did an amazing job. It was a very nice museum but it is a great museum now. The new design is contemporary and feels refreshing. It maybe true to all renovation job but I especially like the light palette to go with the design of some asymmetrical space. The presence of huge Warhol collection make this place a must go place in SF, at least in my humble opinion.
author: John C.

description:
"Todo lo que puedas imaginar es real." - Picasso

Everything you can imagine is real.

I'll be honest with you and admit I'm not the biggest fan of most modern art. Yes, I have my favorites like M.C. Escher, René Magritte, Salvador Dali, etcetera. Yet, I couldn't get into the child-like art of some. I know, I know, it's all about the strokes, the mood, the raw emotion, but c'mon now... my inner child could do that too, eh?

The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art aka SFMOMA is probably one of the best known galleries of it's kind on the west. It offers works from Frida Kahlo who is remembered for her unforgettable self-portraits, her pain and passion, and her use of bold, vibrant colors. Frida Kahlo has become a symbol for feminists worldwide for her depiction of the female experience and form. The museum always has an Andy Warhol or a hundred. Yes, the same Andy "Soup Can" Warhol that is well known for his iconic paintings & prints of everything and anything. I'm not the biggest Warhol fan, but when you see his art live it's like a "Wow! That's a Warhol!" Ok, it's worth it! 

SFMOMA is located in SOMA, SF. Ha! All these acronyms in our lifetime, but really it's just south of Market St. on 3rd Street. You simply can't miss the museum once you see it! Everyone needs a ticket for entry even freebies... 

General admission: 
Museum Member: FREE
Adult: $25
Senior (65+ older): $22
Young Adult (19-24 w/ ID): $19
Youth (18 & under w/ Adult): FREE 

Hours (excluding holidays):
Monday & Tuesday: 10 a.m.-5 p.m.
Wednesday: CLOSED (gift shop open) 
Thursday: 10 a.m.-9 p.m.
Friday & Sunday: 10 a.m.-5 p.m.
Saturday: 10 a.m -8 p.m.

One thing you didn't know about this museum is that back in another lifetime I interviewed for the assistant manager position in the gift shop. Y'know selling the likes of a Pablo Picasso nose mug, or maybe the eyebrow of a Frida comb. Yes, the interview went fabulous, I had a free tour too, but I think my eyes said I still prefer Leonardo. 

"Every child is an artist. The problem is how to remain an artist once he grows up." - Picasso #respects
author: Eric R.

description:
Museum are my passion. I love modern art and I like to see something new all the time. Nevertheless, it is beautiful! Such a vast amount of art and very diverse as well. The exhibitions are very organized and the space is wonderful. I definitely recommend getting an audio tour added to your ticket to get the full experience. 
SF MOMA is one of America's greatest museum, I highly recommend to visit it!
author: Elena L.

description:
Great museum!  

I love the SF MOMA.  It is well curated and well organized. Pieces are given proper area and viewing distances which can be tough as they frequently show very large pieces.  The architecture is beautiful 

My only critique is that the MOMA can get quite busy so I recommend visiting mid week.
author: aaron l.

description: A excellent ,awesome layout of gorgeous artwork . I was fortunate  and thankful to see Magritte works display there .... it was sweeet !
author: Lucy M.

description: Had a good time hanging with our teens here.  1.5 hours is enough.  Coat check is great to rid off our bags and jackets.  Outdoor sculpture terraces were closed due to rain.  Come early for less crowds.
author: Connie W.

description:
Love going to modern art museums, because you always have that feeling walking in never really knowing what you're going to expect. This was definitely no exception and the expectations of this experience has gone above and beyond. 

With the little art history that I have under my belt from taking various classes throughout college, there actually were pieces that I could identify from my textbooks! :) Such a cool feeling relating to an object on that level. There was also a really great mix of contemporary art with with likes of Yayoi Kusama, all the way to classics such as Diego Rivera. 

Massive collection and I'm so happy that the city of SF has such an amazing museum to celebrate all of art and more!
author: Micah L.

description:
I love going to modern art museums because you never know what's out there. Of course, what I love most are the unique exhibits and displays.

It was super pack the day I went and the lines were super long so I just purchased them online and made my way to the entrance. The sister and I enjoyed our time here even though we were in a rush. I'm sure everyone will find at least something they like because there are a variety of different pieces of art.
author: Anh L.

description: I thought that the permanent collection was decent but not what I would expect for a major city like San Francisco. The rest of the exhibits were poor. To have a presentation of lightbulbs hanging from the ceiling and puddling on the floor to me is not worthy of a major museum. Another poor example was a bunch of floor tiles in the corner of one room. I don't get it? Maybe I am just not artistic enough! LOL
author: Cousin D.

description:
I love the SF MOMA. There is SO much to love (7 floors of exhibits).

The selection of exhibits are always amazing and innovative. Currently, I love their soundtracks exhibit (closing January 2018). It is mind blowing to see and experience the creativity of these artists. This exhibit is also nicely interactive! 

7 floors is a lot of cover in one day. I would tend to stick to 2-3 floors per visit so that you don't get museum'd out. Maybe have a nice lunch then see another floor, if you are up to it. The food is really quite good but it is expensive. There is also a lovely Sightglass coffee location on the 3rd floor.

There are also lovely outdoor spaces to explore and this museum has one of the best museum stores I have explored. Really a great place to come for a few hours and get inspired!
author: Cindy L.

description:
Despite living in the Bay Area for years, I had never gotten around to coming here until about a month ago.

I bought the Costco City Explorer Pass, which is about $70 but includes admission to 4 attractions that you choose from a list. This was one of the places my friend and I chose. I'm sure there are other discounted tickets and promotions as well. 

There's some pretty awesome exhibits, and it's nice to lose yourself in it. I'm not one of those people that will read every single thing, but rather wander around and check out the pieces that seem the most appealing to me. I really enjoyed the pop art museum and some of the installations.

To truly immerse yourself, I think it would probably take a few visits. But you can get through the whole museum in about 5 hours.
author: Merisenda A.

description:
Really cool architectural space. MASSIVE collection. Incredible touring exhibit of Munch's work while I was there too. I just wish I had more time to explore. I had no idea the place was 7 floors or the immensity of the collection. Yes, it has the mandatory contemporary "um, this is supposed to be art?" stuff, but overall it's got to be one of the best modern art museums I've ever visited. 

One tip: The Edvard Munch exhibit is probably not for you if you're remotely depressed. Wow. That guy. So much sadness & such a talent for conveying it in his work. But SF MoMA, is it a good idea to put his exhibit so near the leap-able, outdoor sculpture garden and balcony space? Just sayin'.
author: Scott Z.

description:
It seems to me, architects made the MoMA, more about their avant-garde design than a repository of objet d'art. 

Have curators and modern artists become more like lawyers arguing black is actually white and vice versa?  It seems ridiculous to know of the time and money spent renovating what was a relatively new building only to have this in its place. How much of its actual square footage is dedicated to the display of art; certainly not much within the first two whole floors and little there after.

David Hammons "Higher Goals" could nicely fill some of that vast emptiness of those two floors. And, unlike the @#&! I viewed today, Hammons "Elephant Dung" sculptures truly redefine @#&! as modern art.

The frozen snowman on display has no coal eyes nor smile, no carrot nose nor even a pipe, no scarf nor hat and no branch arms.  How is this less than minimalist expensive icy display modern art?

Driftwood with rope and crumpled fenders with reclaimed distressed sheet steel may be... but really? 

My friends and I were more than disappointed to see such giant galleries with so very little in them.
author: Caesar A.

description:
When I moved to the city, they were closed for updates and remodeling. And now, so glad they are open. I bought a membership in February, and have been a few times since. An amazing experience! 

Love the photography exhibits, the Fisher Collection (GAP), Paintings and Sculptures (wire sculpture by Ruth Asawa - she's known for many fountains in the city. Oh, and Frida)...

Looking forward to checking out the latest exhibit: Edvard Munch
author: Amy O.

description: Saw the Rene Magritte exhibit. Go see it. It was wonderful. I think there were over 70 pieces. The paintings felt comforting while provocative and tense. Some of it was just beautiful, like the doves, and the WWII bottles. It was crowded, so was the Magritte gift shop. The MOMA never disappoints me.
author: Sammy L.

description:
This is my first time here since the remodel. I really enjoyed my visit here. My only disappointment was to find out that Blue Bottle was replaced, which means no more Mondrian cake. The layout is very nice and open. The museum itself if very clean and I like how each floor is dedicated to a specific style of art. 

I did not eat at the cafe, but the menu looked very good and everyone else seated seemed to be satisfied with their entrees. They also have a coffee bar with a wide variety of pastries.

Tip: Wear comfy shoes, I wore heels because I had not expected to stay here for 4 hours.

Images: The Chemistry of Pink
author: Christina S.

description:
Cute museum with a lot to see I noticed it was a lot of abstract art work ... 
25$ is a little much in my opinion for the entrance but at least cost check was free
 unfortunately 1 floor was closed so I didn't get to see the whole thing this is a once in a year kind of place to come to I wouldn't go often
author: Diamond Y.

description: I'm usually not a huge museum type of gal! But this museum definitely took my interest and was well worth the $20-25. The staff isn't watching every movement you make which makes it a very comfortable environment to be in unlike other museums. You get a wonderful view to look out on the side balconies that they have. This museum is instagram worthy! My favorite room was the room with the pool of bowls (I don't know the exact name). You're suppose to be quiet in this room which is why it makes it so relaxing to just sit and listen to the bowls bumping into each other (Especially after dealing with the city drivers).
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I love going to the Modern Art Museum.  It's really a sense of calm in the storm of eye insults around the world.  I can rely on the permanent collection to lift my spirits like seeing old friends. I feel like we have should be thankful that SFMOMA has collected these works for us to view. The collection is smaller than some but important. We own major art works from Picasso to Freda Khalo.  I love the fact that we own Paul Klee and Matisse originals.  

I was very sad to be without the Modern for a year plus but happy to see the new and improved sites and visit my permanent collection friends like Stills and Stella.  MOMA puts together interesting revolving exhibits that keep up refreshed with colorful, dynamic works of art.  I fully support this Modern Museum and hope they keep the doors open for years to come.  

I have a fondness for the interesting jewelry in the store from paper watches to glass beaded necklaces.
author: Veda F.

description:
SFMOMA, you are beautiful.
