I can't stress enough how everyone should visit the MOMA! It's a beautiful 7 floors and I suggest you start from the top and walk down so that way you won't have to deal with the elevator or stairs every time. To keep this simple, I'll just list things you shouldn't miss out on!!!!!!!:

-Every floor's bathroom is a different color-fun fact
-the living wall outside is a spectacular wall thats, well, living
-don't miss out on Sequence, don't laugh but I missed it the first time I visited even though its so large......
-the cafe is also beautiful, so it's perfect for lunch sitting along the sculpture garden
-FYI the ticket allows reentry for that day, so if you wanted to grab lunch or do something elsewhere, you can leave and come back 
-as for parking, we found a garage and payed for it online ahead of time 
-give yourself enough time to see everything! Even the bookstore/gift shop will take a handful of time to go through!!!!
-save time and buy tickets ONLINE
author: Maleah M.

description:
I would have loved to come in and see the wonderful exhibits that this institution offers, but alas did not. I guess I'm just spoiled by the fact that most museums in New York (and elsewhere) offer suggested donations, artists discounts or a suggested or free night, so everyone can see the work. 
Alas, the guy at the ticket counter said no such thing existed. Because of that, and the principle that you're showing work of artists who wouldn't have even been able to afford to enter this establishment at the beginning of their careers made me turn around and leave.
At least the gift shop is free.
author: Alicia G.

description: The revamped museum is amazing. There's a coat check, museum store and modern restaurant In Situ (it really matches the modern ambience) on the first floor. Second floor right off the staircase is usually where the new exhibition is. It usually has two parts divided by a coffee bar and multimedia lounge in the center. The coffee bar serves beloved local Sightglass Coffee! Watch out the museum closes on wednesdays! The upper floors host the permanent collections with an incredible gallery for artist portraits that include a painting of Frida and Diego! Very San Franciscan indeed. Our favorite thing to do is taking funny selfies in front of all the bizarre and inspiring modern paintings and art works. These galleries make amazing selfie spots. There are earlier and lesser known works by Andy Warhol too.
author: Dilys S.

description:
This was my first visit to SF MOMA, so I'm not able to compare the new renovated building with the prior version. The building was beautiful and I really enjoyed the outdoor spaces nestled within. There is a seventh floor balcony facing east and there are the living wall patio and the sculpture courtyard next to the cafe. I also enjoyed walking across the catwalk several stories above the lobby.

I realized that modern art is not my thing. So, take this review with that in mind.
author: David F.

description: My boyfriend & I spent an afternoon here. You can buy tickets online and skip the ticket line - highly recommend doing so! Ticket prices are steep. Magritte exhibit was beautiful, and the staff were very helpful and professional.
author: Alex R.

description:
SFMOMA is a real treat. Seven floors of modern art for you to spend a day and get lost in. This museum is easily one I want to return to. There's so much to see! If you're a local and art is your scene, I suggest purchasing a membership since it pays for itself and the art on display is ever-changing. Plus you get to bring a friend for free and be popular.

With all it has to proffer, SFMOMA's admission is worth at least one visit. On the steep side, yes, but free for 18 and under. Great for family, dates, and hangouts alike. I've been to my fair share of art museums in SoCal and I am very impressed by SFMOMA. I got lucky with Sunday parking at a meter spot right in front, and there are metered spots around the block. It's smack dab in the city though so we know how that goes.

The ticket line can get long - save yourself the trouble by purchasing them online in advance. Also, as I was making my way out of the museum at closing, there was a gnarly line for people getting their stuff back from coat check which I would probably avoid as well. 

The day I went was rainy so they closed off access to the living wall :( But rain doesn't damper the experience since everything else is indoors. Rain or shine it's a great time.
author: Candace L.

description:
Go for the exhibitions, as the permanent collection is somewhat lacking.

For context, I'm comparing SF MoMA to my favorite modern art museums:  the original MoMA, the Whitney, the Guggenheim, the modern art collection at the Met (all in NYC), and the Tate Modern in London.  Each of those houses an impressive permanent collection, whereas SF MoMA's collection (at least the part that's on display at any given time) is modest by comparison.  

That's not to say it's not worth a visit.  Some of the exhibitions, including a current one on post-WWII German painting, are exceptional.  So go for those, and if you're looking for something more, book a trip to NYC.
author: Scott H.

description: I decided to go the other day and enjoyed the Art. But Even though I paid the full price, they still wouldn't let me in to see the Magritte paintings. So you have to pay to get in, and then once you're in you have to pay even more to see certain sections of Art. Really? I'm an Artist, Surfer and Skateboarder and don't have a lot of money. All I wanted to do was quietly go about my tour of the Art, which I did after being wallet-reemed. And Most Importantly, the only art you will see is what politically fits the city's views. Goodbye to Art being something for everyone.
author: Zack M.

description:
4 stars because the parking is such a pain (as expected in the city). However, the museum is a fun activity that will last a couple of hours. I went with some friends for a birthday, and we had a blast looking at the museum. Even for someone who does not have an interest in art, I was intrigued throughout the whole museum. Each level was different- some floors more interesting than others. 

Definitely something to try at least once, and there are a couple decent restaurants nearby if you are hungry after!
author: Lauren C.

description: much bigger than I thought it would be, 7 floors! Exhibitions are fun, store is especially interesting.
author: Rong Y.

description: Possibly one of the most engaging and beautiful modern art museums in the world. I love taking everyone here and it's so huge that I always feel like there's something new. They rotate exhibitions frequently enough that I feel like it's really worth getting a membership.
author: MiNa C.

description:
I planned on coming here the second I knew I was going to San Francisco but I didn't realize how vast and beautiful this museum was. Even just walking through all of the floors and the exhibits without reading the text or staring at any of the pieces too long, it took me 2 hours to see everything. 

The ticket prices are definitely steep at $25 for an adult, $19 for young adults, but free for teenagers and below. However, there are 6 floors full of art pieces that are thought provoking and beautiful. A true art lover or even an amateur one will be awed by how much there is to see.

Two tips I read on yelp were to buy the tickets online to skip the line and to start on the 7th floor and work your way down to avoid getting tired from the gruesome stairs. Definitely follow those tips! 

Overall, this is a great place to visit in SF and I highly recommend it if you get a chance to go. Prepare to spend a nice 2 hour chunk of time here!
author: Ashley D.

description: Great museum! Loved the variety of art displayed on each floor. The open space made for a nice experience and interactive as you could get closer to exhibits. And the living wall was beautiful
author: Celeste C.

description: This place is HUGE - but absolutely amazing. With 7 floors of incredible and interesting art... you're bound to find a piece you really like. I bought the year membership pass which allows for me to bring 3 guests for free each time I come to the visit. So worth it! My favorite place to go hangout if I need to pass some time in the middle of the work day or in between plans on the weekend. MOMA is a must see for any SF visitors!
author: Emily M.

description:
I've been a member of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art ever since it was over on Van Ness. Personally, I liked the overall structure and presentation abilities at that facility better. There was something very grand about that building. It's still there, it's just used for something else. But, the great art exhibits have continued since it has moved to this newer location.  

There are a few things to take into consideration before you come to see an exhibit here. What is perhaps the  main problem, which is very commonly the case all over  San Francisco, is that parking can be a bit of a problem. Yes, they have some lots and some street parking around the area, but it is not easy. And, let me spell easy with a E. :-) 

This being said, there are very few museums in Northern California or all of the Western United States for that matter that come anywhere close to the grand level of ever-changing and ongoing art exhibits that the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art presents. Thus, it is one of the must see art museums in California.
author: Scott S.

description:
I have been to the Moma and the New Whitney in New York. I find The Moma San Francisco and the De Young to be quite comparable.

This is a great Museum. I like this collection of modern art. Even though I am not as learned as I would like to be in modern art I certainly appreciate the collections up here in San Francisco.
author: Keo N.

description: Bleh.  Not as sweet as other comparable museums in other cities. Twice as expensive. Worth the experience if you're hitting the tea gardens across the way... but if this was something you were considering chopping off your list to do something else; do it.  Great for little kids- if you have kids definitely do it. No kids= there's much cooler shit to do.
author: Jeff J.

description: Came in for some extra credit for my intro to humanities class. I was very lost in the beginning but after asking for some help I was directed to the right spots . It definitely helps to not drive to this place because there is no parking . Overall I learned a lot
author: Max P.

description:
The SFMOMA is seven floors of priceless art work and worth the $25 admission price.  Whether you are from SF or a tourist, visiting MOMA is a great experience for all who appreciate art.  

Your visit: Ticket prices are currently $25 for adults, $19 for ages 19-24, and FREE for 18 and under.  SFMOMA is open Friday to Tuesday 10am-5pm and Thursdays 10am to 9pm.  They are closed on Wednesdays.  With your ticket you can join the free public tours guided by the museum personnel.  The "daily tours" guided tours last about 45 minutes and the "spotlight tours" last about 20 minutes in length.

Exhibits: The exhibits constantly change throughout the year and there are many different works of art for all to enjoy.

Note: If you have an iPhone, download the SFMOMA app.  You will be able to see and hear guided narratives throughout the gallery.  Unfortunately it is not available on android.  Audio devices are available to rent at from the service desk.
author: Peter C.

description: I am not a big fan of modern art, so I had low expectations for the exhibits here. I was pleasantly surprised, it's actually a pretty well organized and nicely designed museum. The building is modern and beautiful. The exhibits range from interesting to laughable to cool to blah to funny to interesting again. All in all cool experience, worth a visit.
author: Dennis L.

description: Really loved this museum. San Francisco is much more than the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz & this gem proves it!
author: Sarah L.

description: Amazing place to see art and have fun. Variety of art styles and it can take hours to go through the entire museum.
author: Juan V.

description:
Fantastic museum with 7 floors to experience. We visited on a Saturday morning at opening. It was raining out so this was a plus that it's 95% indoors. We parked in the parking garage at 588 Mission St. ($15 when you use the ParkWhiz app or $20 for drive up) It is technically valet, be prepared to give up your keys) It wasn't a far walk to SFMOMA from here. 

The museum opened at 10am. Tickets for adults are $25 each. Complimentary coat check is available. I suggest this if you don't want to lug around a heavy jacket or bag. You'll be here a while. Also the bathrooms in the lobby are awesome! The women's is SO cool. You'll have to see for yourself. Not sure about the men's but I'm sure it's awesome too. 

Each level brought something new for the eye to capture. Each exhibit is nicely laid out. You'll just have to see for yourself!

Be sure to pay attention to the signs of areas where photography is not allowed or if you have kids, make sure they aren't touching anything. (They are watching you!) Me personally, I'd take my kids to the Exploratorium so that they can touch things. 

You will spend hours here! Highly suggested if you can appreciate art and keep an open mind.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
What an amazing museum. We came in to see the Edvard Munch exhibit and explore/wander another floor or two. 
I love a good museum but after an hour or so, I get overwhelmed and just have to take a break. There is so much to see you seriously cannot do it all in a day.
When I make another trip down to San Fran I would like to come back and explore another floor.
author: Bryan M.

description:
The new San Francisco Museum of Modern Arts, at 151 Third St., is an amazing gift to the public. Open daily til 5 pm (closed Wednesdays), Thursdays til 9 pm. Adults $25 - Youths 18 and under are ALWAYS free.  

The iconic, wavy design/build was created by Norwegian architectural firm Snøhetta, known for its art spaces. Now featuring nearly 3x the art display space, the new SFMOMA replaced the previous museum building, which stood a scant 28 years before falling to the wrecking ball. Art buffs may remember the original SFMOMA, which opened on Van Ness Ave. in 1935 as the first modern art museum on the west coast.

Visitors may pre-select their arrival times online. Yes, admission is steep at $25 - but movie tickets for two are approaching $30+ and Imax is $40, attending an NBA game will set you back $200+ and golf for two at Spyglass is $400+. And, how much did you pay for those sunglasses ya lost after wearing 'em a month? C'mon! And kids are always free!

Parking is available a the adjacent garage or try your Best Parking app for nearby parking availability.  For your best experience, shoot for weekday visits; allow 3 hours so you may casually explore the ten floors of works.

We arrived 30 minutes before our scheduled time and were surprised to find the entry process easy and well organized. The museum offers self guided, interactive tours which allow you to go at your own pace and wander freely.

The café is one of the best we've seen in a public venue. We were delighted, and surprised, to be offered free refills of our capuccinos - who does that?  On another note, my daughter spotted "Where's Waldo?" on the SF skyline while strolling the café patio. Can you find him?

Notably, SFMOMA offered a free admission night in December '16, following the tragic Oakland rave warehouse fire. Class move.

From March 11 - May 29, 2017, California artist Richard Diebenkorn will be featured alongside iconic Henri Matisse works. Matisse was one of the first artists featured at the original museum and remains a staple of SFMOMA.

First class.
author: John H.

description:
What an all-around amazing experience. My friend and I spent 3-4 hours here on a cloudy Saturday afternoon and were simply exhausted by the end of it. There are works here to challenge your imagination, creativity, wisdom, complex emotions, and more. It is an immersive experience if you let it be. There are certainly more crowded exhibits than others, but I never had to wait to view an exhibit. I would like to come back and do the audio tour to learn more about particular artists and their background that influenced their pieces. 

The other awesome part of going to the MoMA for a day is being able to head over to Lemonade (a 0.2 mile walk away!) for a delicious, savory meal. You can't go wrong with this plan!
author: Julia Y.

description: Went to the grand reopening of SF MoMA's grand reopening and, WOW!!!! The beauty!!!! So many great pieces of art. The expansion is truly massive. I mean, MASSIVE!!! The artists' work are extremely creative!! I love the fact that this beauty is right in the middle of the city. So much to see and do nearby. I need to become a member!!!!
author: Ali R.

description: If you have a library card of SF, you can get a free ticket through online. Check it out.
author: Keisuke W.

description:
I had been to the SFMOMA about 6 years ago when I first starting coming to SF for work, and that day wandering around, exhausted and exhilarated and feeling like my whole life had been flipped upside down and modern art was the only thing that made sense, is burned in my memory. I waited eagerly through the years of renovations to be able to return, and this year time and life complied so I got to spend a few perfect hours here with some of my favourite people. 

The staff were exceptional and kind and knowledgeable and peaceful and welcoming, of course. 

I went straight to the 7th floor to see Ragnar Kjartansson's The Visitors, and it was as stunning and heart-soothing as I had hoped. 

For the rest, I wandered happily, following where my eyes felt happy, and finding so much to love. I can't wait to go back and spend more time.
author: Risa D.

description:
Hard to rate art museums since I don't visit too many around the area but SFMOMA is really cool! I went in around 2pm on a weekday and it was full of people, tourists, and students which is great! SFMOMA is HUGE. There are 7 floors and the floors are so big and spacious. Seriously going to get your walking cardio here. They have multiple cafes, with one that could be half indoor and outdoor which is nice on a warm day.  They have other art installments outdoors which is a cool way (literally) to cool off and change your visual environment. 
You'll find many different types of art pieces depending on which floor you're on.  Whether it's paintings, lights, pieces of fabric/clothing, sounds, and the list goes on! 
Definitely a well worth visit if you're into seeing (and walking) around and taking cool museum pics.  I feel like they change their art pieces pretty often so if you haven't paid a visit in a while the time is now!
author: Tiffany Z.

description:
My favorite museum I've ever visited!! That's saying a considering I've visited Rome, Paris, Croatia, Austria, Hungary, the list goes on. 

There's something for everyone at this museum. Some parts represent serious problems in society, but some pieces of art are quirky and just fun to observe. 

The reason why I'm giving this place 5 stars is because I love the 7th floor which displayed like audio art!! It was so different and so interesting to observe, I would definitely come back.
author: Lilly H.

description:
Came here to burn some time before dinner time. Compared to other museums like the Seattle Museum of Pop Culture (MoPop), it was just OK. None of the exhibits really stood out or were that memorable to me and waiting for the elevators seems like an eternity. It was also a bit stuffy in the museum so leave your jackets behind! 

Anyway, overall the facility is clean, well run and a great place to check out art if you're interested in the current exhibits. Unfortunately, nothing caught my eye the day I went.
author: Christine K.

description:
I want to give a higher review for this place - it's such a revered and gargantuan SF institution, after all. But 3 stars is all I can muster. Like most museums, it's just meh. Or blah. It's just not all that cool or interesting. 7 floors open to the public, and they still can't manage to put anything that good in there. It seems a little dated, and most of the art seems more appropriate for a small regional museum with a much lower admission fee. For while, the new SFMOMA was $30, but it looks like it's recently been lowered to $25. Better, but still steep for such an average place. At least it's lower than the Academy of Science's whopping $40 entrance fee - as of now, when I just checked their site. Now that's really not worth it. SF museum admission fees have been going through the roof these days - reflecting the ridiculously overpriced cost of living in this city. 

Museums these days seem heavy on the airiness and feel, and less focused on actual art, or science, or whatever the museum is about. That's the same with Cal Academy, too - so much less science-oriented than the old museum. 

The least unmemorable part of the museum for me were actually those protest posters on Floor 3. I was showing an out-of-town friend everything about those angry marches, tenant rallies, strikes, and Black Panther stuff. He wasn't familiar with this SF/Berkeley brand of angry, overwrought activism, so that's why talking about those posters stood out in my mind. I remember seeing a similar collection of angry protest posters at that Berkeley museum - the BAMFPA, which no one knows about, for good reason. 

There's a trendy Sightglass coffee bar smack in the middle of one of the  levels. It's odd the cafe is just right there, in the middle of the floor, instead of having an obvious separation, like a separate room. The cafe has a similar feel to the previous SFMOMA cafe - a little dated, smacking of the late 2000s, upscale but edgy and chic. This is what it says on the SFMOMA site: "The coffee bar is located adjacent to the Photography Interpretive Gallery, combining coffee with contemplation." Pretentious, like everything related to SFMOMA and modern art museums. 

On one of the higher levels, there was a couple of wooden "man" sculptures, maybe like a very tame version of Burning Man. Those bland sculptures reflect everything else about the museum - just boring and uninteresting, nothing new or fresh. Maybe Calder is a big name in sculptures, but I find his abstract mobile-like "sculptures" unbearably unappealing. 

There's some fairly lame spidery sculptures on a top floor, with that little bridge with the slot floor than lets you look down into the abyss below. It's not that interesting - we remember something very similar from the old SFMOMA. 

I don't know if it's just me, but it seems the beauty and passion of the old SFMOMA is missing from the new one. Same with the old and new Academy of Sciences. I remember some of the art so fondly at the old SFMOMA - the Wayne Thiebaud, Diebenkorn, Eva Hesse, Michael Jackson & Bubbles, Ellsworth Kelly, and Roy De Forest. But this new SFMOMA, even probably with some of the same art - just seems so underwhelming.
author: Valle H.

description:
I was captivated from the start of my journey through all the floors, never had a thought of I'm bored. One of the curators at the front told me to start from the 7th floor and work my way down and that was really good advice.

It's my first time coming to such a museum and I didn't really have any expectations. The abstract and minimalist exhibits really hit me. I've usually heard people bash on these saying, "oh I can do that, it's so easy." Well, seeing it in person and seeing how big some of these pieces are you really just get lost in them and see it for what it is. The ability of the artist to translate and evoke emotion, translating it onto a canvas through brush strokes, colors, and light is a humbling experience. 

The Sublime Seas exhibit where they have three screens simultaneously playing videos and sound was a real trip, in a good way. It made me feel small and insignificant in the world of wonder and beauty. It does send also a powerful message as well, but I don't want to spoil that here. I highly recommend seeing it. 

Tickets are not cheap $25 for adults, but who would not want to support a musuem like this? There is a parking structure in which part of the money paid goes to supporting MoMA. It's off of 3rd and Minna, literally at the side of the museum. Maybe hard to squeeze your way into this side street if you're not familiar with the city as the bus/taxi only lane may throw you off. Google map and street view it in prep for finding this parking garage. 

They are very strict about beverages including water bottles of any kind in any of the exhibits. If you're holding a bag they prefer you keep it in front of you so you don't accidentally back it up to something. Some exhbitis you can interact with and some are only allowed to be 18 inches away only.  So read the signs, and when in doubt ask. 

Date spot? Yes definitely! Would I go back? Yes, already did twice in one week to show other people this cool place!
author: Arik A.

description: I love that members get to bring friends in for free! There's a lot of great pieces here and I really enjoyed the sounds floor more than I thought I would. It can get a little too warm in here but given the cold weather of the day, I can't complain too much. You'll have to come for yourself to check it all out, spent about 2 hours to see everything , it was great
author: Cynthia H.

description:
I love the SFMoMA and would give it a solid 5 stars but I just can't because the horrible interaction with an extremely rude docent on the first floor today. Please note: all the other docents were pleasant and professional. 

This docent (male, older, with a heavy Eastern European accent) suddenly approached me quite belligerently, got right in my face, and angrily told me that, '...I told you three times to wear your backpack on the front!!!' 

I was quite confused, as I did not have a backpack (I have a small sling bag) and also I had been in the museum with my family for at least 20 minutes and had never seen this man and never spoken with him, which is exactly what I told him. 'I have never seen you before and I do not know what you're talking about.' He then said that he spoke to my child about it (my child was next to me) which was even more bizarre. 

He continued to harangue me, getting in my face, so I took a step back, held up my hand to keep him away from us and stated firmly, 'Do not speak to me in this manner, do not approach me, and step away from my child.' 

The docent was again trying to get in my face when he suddenly stopped. I heard my husband's voice behind me calmly asking, 'What's going on here?' The docent stopped his approach, started babbling, and stammered an apology. We moved on, because we were there to see the museum.

Both my children asked why 'the man was acting like that' and it was really difficult to answer their question because the interaction was just so unnecessarily negative and inexplicable.

And to top it off, we'd just renewed our membership. 

NOT looking forward to another visit!!!
author: Anna G.

description:
After the big remodel the place is too large to see in a day. Great airy spaces, rarely crowded. Not the least expensive Museum by far - some special exhibits run $30+.

If you go more than once with a group, become a member - save a few 

Excellent permanent collection in rotation
author: David L.

description: They have awesome collections, and just reopened after renovated this May. Therefore, architecture is new and excellent. Their seasonal exhibits are wonderful. I like to spend time at their cafe too.
author: Yumiko H.

description:
This place is huge. Like huge, huge. 7 freaking floors of art and so much walking space, you seriously have to spend at least 2 hours here to really appreciate it. 

Personally, some of the floors aren't that intriguing and kind of seem like fillers, but the personal favorites are the 3rd floor modern art and 8th floor (Warhol, sculptures, etc.). If you want to take a break, there's sight glass coffee on the 3rd floor or you can get some wine, coffee, and snacks on the 4th floor. Only sad thing is you can't take drinks around the museum. 

Besides the variety of art, the overall Customer service and re modernization of the SF MOMA is timeless! I just bought membership recently and they are so so lenient with bringing guests and it's a quick process to get in! Highly suggest getting a membership if you plan on bringing guests regularly!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description: This is a pretty solid MOMA. There was a good variety of mediums, pulling from well-known artists, and artists I had never heard of. Make sure to stop by their cafe, its very cute and charming. A bit pricey, as I've been to more extensive MOMAs for cheaper or discounted prices. I probably wouldn't come back for awhile til I knew they rotated some new exhibitions or art in.
author: Lexi L.

description:
Came here on a Saturday morning after brunch and i'm so glad we did. Definitely come as early as you can here because right when we left at around 2PM it was packed and the lines were long. It's also better to come early since it'll take around 2-3 hours to really explore the place without feeling rushed since there are 7 floors. 

I love how they have varying prices for tickets. As a young adult under 24, the ticket was only $19! They give you a hardcopy ticket and once you get it scanned, the ticket actually turns into a sticker that you have to wear around the place. Usually you start on the 2nd floor of the building since that's where you buy tickets/where the permanent collection is. We started on the 3rd with the living wall and where Sightglass Coffee is located. 

As a fan of museums, i'm surprised it took me this long to explore. The museum is huge and the exhibits beautiful. We started on the 3rd floor and then ended up starting at the 7th after and just went down.

My fave exhibits were: 

- Neon lights Exhibit  - What's not to love. They had a mixture of blinking lights and pieces that were constantly on. It was a great change from other parts of the museum.

- The City Scape Exhibit - I enjoyed this exhibit. It's only a small portion of the floor but I enjoyed how the artist made maps based on various photos he took of the area. 

- Cloud Cities Exhibit - I think this is one of the newer ones, but it was amazing. Definitely reminded me of being in a spider web and it's cool in the sense that it's made up of black string tied across the walls and mirrors. 

Come early so you can have enough time to beat the rush and so you can take all the insta worthy photos you like.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
GREAT ARTISTS ARE HISTORIANS

Several years ago I majored in art history at UC Berkeley. My emphasis was on mainly on French Impressionism. When I was a junior in college I enrolled in an art history course - American contemporary art from the 1960s and onwards. One of the assignments of that class was writing a 10-page paper a single piece of painting at the old SF MOMA. I don't recall the name of the painter however I remember the name of the painting "White". That painting had different variations of white with visible brushstrokes. Just imaging writing a 10-page paper on this painting? Yeah it was that difficult especially since I'm not a fan of contemporary art. There was something intriguing about SF MOMA when I was at college. However when I went to the old SF MOMA I felt the layout of museum was dated and unorganized as some of the galleries didn't highlight the exhibition or artwork. Maybe that was why I did like contemporary art. The last time I went to the SF MOMA before it was renovated was in 2007 to see the exhibition "Pablo Picasso in American Art". This was best modern art exhibition I have ever seen because it not only showed Picasso's art but also other American artists that he had influence on.

When the SF MOMA opened after its renovation I wanted to go here especially since the museum is about less than a 10-minute walk from my work. I admit when it comes to visiting a museum it is due to the exhibition. During the Memorial Day Weekend there were two exhibitions that were on the day after Memorial Day - "Monet: The Early Years" at the Legion of Honor and "Matisse/ Diebenkorn" at the SF MOMA. Claude Monet is my favorite painter of all time. I do believe in order expand my repertoire of art appreciation I needed to go to the SF MOMA for that exhibition. Before I decided to go I did some research. I heard about Henri Matisse but not Richard Diebenkorn. I discovered he graduated from Stanford in 1949. That is the reason why I decided to go to the exhibition because as a novice art historian who graduated from Cal I wanted to see works from an artist who graduated from Stanford. I was very glad that I decided to go to the SF MOMA that weekend. From looking at the Diekenborn's paintings you progressions from throughout the works. Even though he graduated from Stanford you see his paintings from his Berkeley series how he interprets the layout of the city. What I liked about this exhibition is you see a painting from Matisse side by side of a painting from Diebenkorn. Even though the paintings are not exact you see how Diebenkorn referred to Matisse when it came to shades of color. The similarities of the paintings would involve the same subject matter however each artist interpreted differently the subject matter such as Henri Matisse's "Woman with a Hat", a painting of Matisse's wife, or Diebenkorn's painting of his wife. Going to the SF MOMA for this exhibition challenged me and I was glad for it.

Working in the Financial District in SF I would pass by the Academy of Art and sometimes noticed some of the artworks. I felt these students would try to become like Picasso with his cubist style. Well to understand how Picasso became Picasso you have to understand what was his influences. If artists who aspire to become Picasso then have to study Diego Velázquez, who Picasso studied a lot from to incorporate his works. For aspiring artists the SF MOMA is a great access as it is downtown SF and is close to Bart. In the future if there are other exhibitions like "Pablo Picasso in American Art" or "Matisse/ Diebenkorn" I say it is a prerequisite for aspiring artists who want to progress because history is influential in art.
author: Gerald R.

description:
Came here on a rainy Saturday in SF which was nice ! The admission is pretty steep at $25 per person and there wasn't any discounts online that we found either :(

However we still really enjoyed the entire museum! There's 7 floors so we started on the top! We took our time with each floor and it was so awesome ! My favorite was the exhibit on the 6th floor with these black wire & mirror pieces. 

Even though we're not very museum people, the bf & I really enjoyed all of the exhibits and we were entertained for hours here !! There's also a cute cafe on the third floor which had delicious coffee & cookies if you want to stop by. They also had the "motion lab" on the same floor which was cool to check out.

Definitely something to do at least once while in SF!!
author: Isabel L.

description:
Finally made it here (7/20/17) after their renovation. We were totally blown away with the exhibits and the sheer size of the facility. Make sure you wear comfortable shoes and try to pace yourself. Admission fee was around $56 and included the Munch exhibit. It is true - you get what you pay for. Just to make sure we were paying attention, they painted the restroom on the first floor a very bright orange! 

The Munch exhibit was terrific (but don't come looking for "The Scream") but don't expect it to be uplifting. He was seriously depressed and his work showcased it well.

The overall design and architecture is very impressive and we were exhausted at the end of the day. Well worth the admission and we will return in 2018.
author: Dave W.

description:
I haven't been to the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art since the remodel. When I first walked in, I recognized the high ceiling and the multi-level layout. But then looking around, I noticed a lot of empty space in the foyer. There was plenty of room to display more art on the first floor.

We were going to bypass the long line for the elevator and take the stairs, but then we noticed those were for exit only. The line for the elevator was also where they scan your ticket. Once we had our tickets scanned, they let us make a beeline for the stairs.

This museum runs the gamut of modern art. Photographs, paintings, sculptures, media. There is something for everyone, but I am sure you will find things you do not like and/or do not consider art. 

I especially liked the works by René Magritte and Henri Matisse, as well as the Ansel Adams photos. The Nigel Calder sculptures were cool, especially when a breeze permeated the room. I was amused by Mike Mandel's baseball cards. If they were for sale at the gift shop, I would have bought some. 

The special exhibition features works by Edvard Munch, famous for The Scream. Admission is timed here, and yes, they are scrutinizing your ticket time.

My only complaint was that so many areas in the museum were closed to set up their next exhibition. I didn't get to see the terrace on the 7th floor, or cross the Oculus Bridge. I guess I have to go again...
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description: The workers who oversee the Koret Educational Center on the Second floor are extremely grumpy for no reason. I brought two of my classes here to use the public education center and share the writing they did, and the worker told us not to move these tiny little footstools, saying they were "supposed to be like that", even though the previous week they were in completely random different places in this room. And then after telling me I couldn't move the little footstools, he sat there on his phone the entire time, occasionally glaring at whomever walked in. As a member of this museum, it's a big kick in pants to see the workers treating visitors poorly. I was in the education center last week, and this other grumpy worker did the same thing. I attaches a picture of the footstools. Don't treat the visitors like crap.
author: L. J.

description: Updating again to add that the SFMOMA does have an app to view the work. A good answer to their headsets running out of battery life. So bring your earbuds.
author: Jane F.

description:
I'm not experienced in modern art, but of course I do like art. I found out that some expositions are pretty good, but the rest are not interesting, because it is incomprehensible.

In many places you can sit, relax. Every floor has restrooms, but I checked only one on the 7th floor and it is colored in vivid green. I'm wondering, do they have different colors on every floor?
author: Nick N.

description: Great way to spend a rainy day in San Francisco.  We weren't planning to visit the MOMA, but our outdoor plans were rained-out and this place was within walking distance from our hotel.  There are lots of options in this part of town
author: Sabrina M.

description:
I get to the SFMOMA a couple times each year. Not only is this a stunning modern museum, but they have rotating special exhibits that make coming here more often feel like it's all new each time. The staff is informative and nice. 
On this visit, we were here to see the Edward Munch (Edvard Moonk) exhibit. You would know his most famous piece "the Scream", which by the way was NOT on exhibition...  Extremely interesting and educational tour (get the headsets!).  Why are all these great artists so "F'd" up psychologically and emotionally? ? ? It was all so astounding and interesting to learn about him. I took my Xanax with an espresso just to get into the correct mood. LOL
author: Greg S.

description: What to say that hasn't been said already? This was an excellent way to spend a Sat afternoon. You definitely want to get there before 3:30p as they start closing down exhibits and telling folks they can't go to certain places (the security guards were a little extreme in this regards). It wasn't excessively packed which was nice and unexpected. Best sections were the Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein exhibits which I thoroughly enjoyed. Oh and be sure to spend a little time sitting on the patio if it's nice out
author: Neechi M.

description:
It is nice and big, clean and open.  On this Monday morning it was peaceful and not crowded. Staff is everywhere, and helpful.

I only saw a few pieces that called to me.  3 dimensional and photography were my favorites.

The show of Japanese Photography was haunting.....a must see.

I will not be running back, but I did enjoy it. Thank goodness we went with friends who felt the same
way.
author: Katherine F.

description: By far the worst MoMA I've been to in my entire life. Clear winner in this nomination. Most paintings are without any clear idea or quality standard. Photographs is a failure, my instagram newsfeed is much better. Furniture? Better go to ikea. OMG it's so bad.
author: UnTone F.

description:
As a young adult, I love the opportunities this museum presents a student like me. I've bought a membership and visit at least once a month. There are a lot of hidden perks to having a membership-- like skipping the lines and having a free ticket every new day I visit. 

There are a ton of artists who continuously​ create new exhibits. There's always something new and captivating each time I visit. I also recommend​ checking out their outdoor patio which is covered with live plants. 

I love the diversity of art from modern Andy Warhol to expressionists like Edvard Munch. The curators know what content captivates a vibrant audience like San Francisco.
author: Jasmine M.

description: My husband and I love to visit art museums and We were so happy to visit Moma in SF. Lots of amazing art works and we even got to see two of our favorite works. We wanted to visit again but didn't have time to make it happen. Anyway, a must visit place!
author: Kim P.

description: This trip left just an indelible impression! If you like modern art (photography, painting, sculpture) - go urgently. So many masterpieces just a sin to miss. The museum is rather compact, so you should not be afraid of being lost in its depths, as in the same subway system.
author: Anna C.

description:
If you're visiting SF and wondering which one of the many museums to stop by, I recommend SF MOMA. 

Third time coming to MOMA, and finally found four exhibitions that I absolutely loved. 

Most favorite exhibition was a dark room with several screens showing individual musicians on each but all playing at the same time (like the Youtube orchestras). It felt very intimate. Even though each musician was recorded on video, it felt like we were standing on the stage of a live concert. The music itself was very moody but felt comforting.

My second favorite exhibition was a statue of wire segments pieced together in a shape of a human. It was something that you would see at Burning Man! I had lots of fun taking photos with it. 

My third favorite exhibition was a reddish-brown installation that reminded me of Antelope Canyon. It was like a fun, mini obstacle course for adults. 

My fourth favorite exhibition was Noguchi's Playscapes. The models, sketches, set designs, and archival images of playground ideas gave me a newfound respect for architects and urban planners.
author: Jenn H.

description: I am very fond of modern and abstract art. This place is amazing for all art lovers. My personal fav is floor 6 and 4. Loved the work and all the colors. I Recommend this place to all those who love abstract art
author: Namisha G.

description:
I am excited to write my 100th review for SFMOMA because it is indeed a perfect 100 in my eyes. 

To be honest, I never really imagined myself as a membership carrying museum type of gal. However, after my first visit in June with my friend (when we had a time crunch of 1.5 hours to zip through the museum before closing- it was obvious a membership was necessary for me to come back and enjoy the art). And indeed, I did come back several more times already to wander with various friends to admire all the modern art starting from Level 7 all the way to the ground floor.  I'm not going to spoil each floor for you, but I've always enjoyed Floor 7 and most recently, Tomás Saraceno's "Stillness in Motion -- Cloud Cities". 

Since it is fairly popular, I recommend coming on a weekday with a pair of comfy sneakers. I made the mistake of coming on a rainy weekend and it was super crowded. Also, depending on fast you walk, it will take approximately 2.5-3 hours to look at the entire museum. If you are a SF- Bay Area resident, I recommend buying a membership so you can come back and enjoy the museum in small chunks and go back to exhibits you might have missed the first time around. The best part about membership is that you can always bring a free guest (and reserve your tickets online beforehand!).
author: Eva L.

description:
This is most certainly one of the better museums I've visited. 

The prices for adults are a little high in my opinion, but anyone underage gets in free. That being said, it's not a particularly interactive museum, so it might be boring for younger kids.

Overall, there are 7 floors of varied and interesting exhibits to check out. Because of the emphasis on modern art, there's sure to be plenty of abstract shapes, lines, and colors.

There are constantly exhibits being removed and added, so no two visits may be the same. I was especially impressed with the Edward Much exhibit when I visited (yes, I like sad art haha).

The gift shop is pretty expansive, so there's definitely something interesting to find there. 

Overall, this museum is definitely worth a visit if you're going to SF.
author: Daniel M.

description:
Now that I'm a member of the remodeled SFMOMA I've been going more often.  Membership is $100/yr but you can bring 1 guest so it pays for itself over time.

My favorite exhibit currently is Tomas Saraceno now thru 5/21/17 on the 6th Fl!  You gotta go see it, it's a trippy art that people do video, selfies, pics.  MUST SEE!

I liked the Japanese Photography

I missed seeing Paul Klee at Play 2nd Fl now thru 5/14/17.

Will be going back soon.
author: Ann L.

description:
It doesn't seem like it when you pass by the entrance but this place is huge! There are about 6-7 floors (depending on if the 7th is open) and you can spend HOURS here looking at all the artwork. Sadly, my attention span for museums is about 3 hours max, but I saw everything I wanted to see. The MOMA has a lot of good variety of art from paintings to contemporary sculptures to pop art to classics. I'm more of a pop art/contemporary/modern art type of museum goer so I like the top few floors. In case you stay a bit long, there are a couple cafes and plenty of benches for you rest and enjoy the artwork. 

Overall, I would recommend for anyone to check it out and spend a day being inspired by creativity.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
The SFMOMA is reopened to a brilliant and remodeled interior that is over 7 floors, and has a massive collection that cannot be viewed without having several hours to complete the museum. Yes, the admission is a little pricey at $25, but the collections is awesome, and just looking at the building in itself is a work of art. There are 7 floors of art, and some say to start on the 7th floor and work your way down, but you are free to explore and meander in any way you see fit. 

In addition, they work in various coffee or cafe's into the floors, and make it convenient to take a rest and strategize your next move. Be sure check whether your employer is a corporate sponsor, as we got in complimentary as our employer was a corporate sponsor. That made is so nice to save the $25 admission fee.
author: Gregg R.

description:
Lovely collection.
Clean, spacious, bright.
Beautiful exhibition spaces. 
Modern café on the 3rd floor and a nice sculpture garden oasis on the top floor.  

My favorites were the Fisher Collection of German art, the modern photography, and the 2nd floor collection of various modern paintings.  So sad that we just missed the Edward Munch exhibition by a week! 

It is kind of pricey without any discounts but worth a visit!!!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
This museum is spectacular - according to one of staff, it is total of 7 miles to explore the 7 story full of exhibits. I was extremely happy to see Andy Warhol and Roy a Litchenstein when I visited. Also an exhibit of some incredible German artists! 

I visited on Monday, and the place was fairly busy. I spent about 3 hours and skipped 2 stories of exhibits because I needed to get to somewhere. But I ended up spending another hour at the gift shop downstairs. I definitely could've stayed longer and enjoyed the place.

The gift shop was fabulous! So many unique items - kitchen gadgets, house decor items, apparel, some electronics, books, kid-related items, unique jewelry, etc. I grabbed a few Christmas gift here. 

I would definitely go back when I'm in SF again!
author: Kim L.

description:
So many floors. So many people. So little time.... Seven floors of exhibits and open spaces. I really liked it although I wish we had more time to carefully see it all. I have to thank Rene B for her Yelp advice of taking the elevator to the 7th floor and making your way down from there. Hopefully against most of the traffic.

SFMOMA is big and attracts a lot of people so pick and choose your entry time accordingly. I would say you will need at least 3 hours to enjoy everything without taking time to eat or sip anything. Haha. There really is that much to look at and soak in at this museum. 

I really enjoyed the Gerard Richter pieces. His use of colors was mesmerizing to me. The works of Glenn Ligon whose works I have seen at the Broad in LA are also special for me to see. The Warhols were great. The oculus bridge was cool and the living wall was HUGE. I really was just marveling at it for a while. Like I said, there are so many exhibits to see and I cant possibly list or remember them all. You just have to see for yourself. 

We parked at 5th & Mission as that's a parking structure I am quite familiar with. Parking rates vary depending on the time of day. That's the city for you. No choice if you have a rental like we did. 

Tickets for SFMOMA are $25 for adults. Not cheap, that's for sure.We chose an entry time of 2pm and we finished up a little after 5pm. Enjoy the museum. It's a great addition to the city. SFMOMA in SOMA. Say that 3 times fast.
author: Chuck D.

description: My daughter wanted me to go with her to this museum for a college paper.  I took my 8 year old with us.  I paid 25 for me and my 18 year old and 8 year old were free.  I was surprised how much I enjoyed this museum due to the fact that modern art is not my favorite.  There were exhibits that seem silly to me and unnecessary and others that I really liked.  I was happily surprised that i liked more of the exhibits than I thought I would.  And it took us longer to get through the museum than I thought we would.  All in all, it was well worth the money!
author: Kyra S.

description: My friend has a membership and she got us in for free. It was my first time there since renovation. The museum is about twice the size now and with lots of sun lights. We had lunch in a cafeteria and the food was also good. I'm not sure though if I'd pay $25 to get in. I've been to museums all over the world and that kind of price is for the museum with at least twice the size as SF MOMA.
author: Yoko S.

description: Today as a class we visited the Museum of modern art in San Francisco. The Museum is very interesting created. A huge number of objects of completely different art. There is a lot of space for review and a place to relax. I don't really understand a lot of art nicknames here,but I think a lot of people will appreciate it. I especially liked pop art. Amazing exposition!!!
author: Sofya K.

description:
On my Friday off, I decided to check out SFMOMA.  I went to the NYC MOMA and really enjoyed it.  The SF one is excellent as well, and seems to have better indoor lighting and nice terraces and outside sculptures.  It's 7-floors worth of art.  For some reason, I tended to enjoy the exhibits on floors 5 to 7.  A few of the areas are still under construction.  Overall, 4-stars for me.  My favorite exhibits were:

British Sculptors - There was this one cool figure that looked like a bunch of nails forming an image of a man.

Lilith - Creepy!  Imagine the X-Men character, Mystique, but all black except these eyes staring at you.  

Apple Core - Maybe its a dig at NY MOMA - taking a bite out of the big apple. 

The Cop - I thought he was real!  Very realistic mannequin and funny how folks coming up and down stairs bump into him and do a double take.

Its a fun museum and is definitely a must visit place.  Even the men's restroom are artsy - I went into one that was entirely painted in red.
author: Daniel C.

description:
The latest exhibition is the Matisse/Diebenkorn which runs through May 29th.
My only complaint was it was too crowded. It was difficult to see the paintings due to the
crowd of people around the paintings. 
    If you are a fan of Matisse, this is the show for you.
author: Gayle G.

description:
I won't bore you with my thoughts on the 7 floors of galleries and exhibitions...BUT I had a fantastic 2 hours here during Family Free Day! (Yes, screeching kids who surprisingly did not break anything...)

PRO TIP 1: save yourself time and buy tickets online! 

After you get your ticket scanned, you can wait in line to head up to the 7th floor OR you can always take the stairs up/down. 

PRO TIP 2: If you actually want to learn more about each painting, definitely download the audio app (or rent a machine at the front). 

Lots of paintings/sculptures/art work don't have individual descriptions, but the galleries in general do (ie: artist, inspiration, type of art, etcetera). Sometimes I would walk up to one that I really liked and have no idea what to perceive. Then again...that's art for you right there! 

PRO TIP 3: Sunday street parking for free! Or, if you plan to visit other parts of the city, I would park in the parking structure right beneath the museum.

Rates: $4 for every 30 minutes, $26 maximum 12 hours, $33 for lost parking ticket. Too bad SF MOMA doesn't validate...

Personal favorites: Matisse (floor 1), neon lights, Ai Weiwei, Sleeping Woman, Japanese Photography from Postwar to Now (exhibit), Mondrian, Picasso, and GERHARD RICHTER (Two Candles, dancing girl, etcetera). 

Whoever the Fisher family is..thanks for contributing greatly to this museum!
author: Hurjane V.

description:
I think that everyone should come here at least once.  

I'm probably one of the most uncultured individuals out there, but I still had a great time.  The museum itself is open and airy.  The exhibits are interesting (and bring up a lot of questions like HOW IS THIS ART).  

This place is also a basic person's dream come true.  So many places to take nice pictures!  Seriously, just look at instagram if you're feeling lost haha.
author: Shannon L.

description: Not my favorite genre of art but so much to see, in a gorgeous, expansive space -- even on a crowded weekend day, you can get up close to the beautiful work. And the cafe is worth a visit for the views alone.
author: Carl B.

description:
Enjoyed the museum, thought the price was on the higher side ($25 ticket) and didn't notice any student discounts. But the amount of art here is a lot and you get your moneys worth. They have a few outside patio areas where you can get views of the city as well. Definitely feels like you're in a large urban city. They have one spot outside with a lot of green vines which was a popular picture spot. 

Some of the "art" in this museum was questionable to me, felt like a kindergartener could have painted or put the shapes together and made the "art" lol but some of the pieces up-close definitely took a long time and the attention to detail is unreal....it varies though. Recommend visiting at least once if you're in the area. Close walk from many union square hotels. Also, we bought our tickets in advance with a set time, there were huge lines at the ticket counter for people buying at the door, the same day. Save yourself some time and buy them in advance.
author: Kent V.

description: Seven floors of all sorts of art work from many different eras. Very therapeutic to walk thur. We spend 4.5hrs. without noticing the time.
author: Johnny M.

description: Spent a whole day there with my student day pass. And got to see the Munch special exhibit. What a joy! Every floor offers something new and I especially loved the sound exhibit on the top floor. It took the focus off the eyes and to the ears. What a nice idea to mix it up. Bathtub singing guitar dude is what I least expected and needed most that day.
author: Jen S.

description: I visited this museum on a slow day as it didn't seem too busy. Was able to see most of the displays on each floor. Overall it has different varieties and what you like depends from person to person. I would recommend visiting at least once.
author: Prasheelta L.

description:
I only got to see the lobby and Building structure as I did not have time to actually go into the museum.. But the building is absolutely beautiful and the free art for everyone to enjoy inside lobby, and outside was absolutely amazing! Even if you have a few minutes over lunch like I did, go in and check it out! 
I did get a chance to check out the Museum Store as well which is really great and the staff was super nice! 
I can't wait to get back and check out the whole museum when I have more time!
author: Patrick T.

description: We arrived 30min before closing... and still paid $60+ to enter. Definitely not enough time to see the art. Instead of charging full price maybe the last hour should be reduced OR stop taking entries one hour before closing. Every area we visited the staff was eager to tell us they were closing. Wasn't the best experience and overall the art and the building were not that great. Not worth $60.
author: Samantha P.

description: Vertigo Sea, the video essay exhibit, currently at SF MoMa is worth the entire $25 admission price. 48 minutes of the most thought-inducing images you will see in quite a while. Limited narration and text leaves you to sit with your interpretations of what you are seeing. It's not overly politicized. Just humanized. I highly recommend it. Then you also get to see Louise Bourgeois and Dan Flavin and Agnes Martin and Lichtenstein and many other masters since you are already inside. Time well spent!
author: DiscerningDeb M.

description:
I am a huge lover of art museums, and if I could give SFMOMA 5 stars just for the art, I would, but the rude staff and poor customer service left me a terrible impression. 

From the start, I felt like the worker at the ticket counter who helped me was short and just didn't want to be there (fair enough, he probably deals with hundreds of people per shift). He said, "that'll be $25" and reached out his palm for my payment. Cool, I just assumed he was in a bad mood and walked off, thinking $25 was a little steep, but SF is known for insane prices.

Enjoyed the 7 levels of SFMOMA - loved The Visitors concert experience and it wasn't until my friend said, "wow that exhibit alone was worth the $19," that I stopped in my tracks. She let me know that there's a $19 charge for young adults (19-24), which we both are. I got to the help desk around 4:45 and asked two workers for help. They both looked very annoyed to have a customer walk up to them within the last 15 minutes. 

Explained to the two workers (forgot to ask for their names because I was so upset) what had happened and one answered in a short manner, "well you should've read the sign." The other, "no, sorry. We can't all know how old everyone is." I was stunned at how short they both were and asked, "I mean, can't you just ask the customers?" One of them responded, "no, you should've read the sign. The ticket *points at my ticket* clearly says no refunds." Me: umm that seems... Her: sorry, no refunds. Me: alright, thanks. Her: yeah no problem *in the rudest tone. 

I mean, What???? I understand it was the end of the day, but there were 15 minutes left and what happened to prioritizing customer service? I asked a security guard downstairs and he quickly told me to talk to someone at the help desk because "that's messed up." So I did, and an older gentleman at the counter gladly helped me - with no hesitation and with a smile. The two girls looked at me from the end of the counter while the gentleman processed my refund. 

I would've given one star just for their attitudes and poor customer service, but the gentleman was kind to me, so I decided on two stars. 

Seriously, SFMOMA please hire people who don't treat customers like trash -- some of us just want to enjoy some awesome art and have a great day.
author: Tina T.

description:
Seriously. If you have lived in the bay for more than a year and not gone to this museum, ya failed homie. 

I'm not going to sit and tell you about each floor and my fave pieces or artists. I'm just gonna say shut up and go. 

A dozen trips later. I guess it's time I review it. This is actually the first time I have been since it went under some construction (which seemed like forever but was maybe a year or so?!)

They have a healthy blend of everything. It is IMO the best art museum in Northern California. Plan a day here. Bring a snack for the park nearby. Or take a midday break and visit the 5th floor cafe and sculpture garden. I have personally never eaten there but they do have a solid menu and food looks tasty. 

The museum bookstore is epic. They have a fantastic selection of prints, books, clothing, accessories, and fun household items. 

Ok, stop wasting time and plan a trip there. Thanks bye.
author: Sean M.

description: Oooooh. Ahhhh. This place was crowded when we went! Make sure you have enough time on your schedule to visit all the rooms. It's huge! I enjoyed that they have a cafe inside in case you're dying of lack of sleep (which was what happened in my case). The exhibits were interesting and of course a modern art museum wouldn't be complete with your paintings that had a white canvas and a blue square lol. I enjoyed the assortment of art (including some videos and sound art). Good place to check out! Entrance is 25$.
author: Natalie M.

description: Adore this museum! There is a huge variety of art, including some favorites - Ellsworth Kelly, Sol LeWitt, Chuck Close! Rotating & interactive exhibits keep the museum fresh & interesting.
author: Chloe J.

description: Good to visit especially on a gloomy day.Make sure you take the free guided tours.I took the arcitecture one and it was great!
author: Cristian A.

description:
Fun | Good variety | Good location
$$

Went online to get our tickets ($25 each for us being 27 and 28 years old). Glad we paid for tickets online instead of waiting in line when we showed up. 

Lots of art to see! 7 floors. 
Wear comfortable shoes because you'll be walking up/down stairs a lot. 
Indoor and outdoor installations in various mediums. One thing I liked were some pieces incorporating visitors to make their point. Some pieces were too abstract for me, so I think I completely missed the point they were trying to make. Then other pieces I felt really unsettled and moody, but overall I enjoyed the experience. Lots of perspective. 

One thing I will note is that it was unclear where to start (we purchased our tickets already, so we weren't given any direction where to begin). Apparently there are many entrances to this place, and there's no real starting point. I think this may be intended, but it was something that I saw as a common thing with other new visitors. All was good after we went up to the help desk. 

Location is good. Walking distance to other museums (i.e. Metreon), restaurants and shops. 

Parking -- streets are crowded. You've got Fifth and Mission, which is a huge lot and it's cheap. If not, you can park at the designated parking lot for SFMOMA. 
147 Minna St.
One way, narrow street, but you're right next to the museum. Expensive -- $4/half hour. Narrow stalls. Remember to pay on first level before getting in your car to exit garage. 

Restaurants nearby: Super Duper Burger, Grove Yerba Buena
author: Lauren F.

description:
During a recent vacation to SF, I went to the Museum of Modern Art for a few reasons:

1. To give myself a break from the wind that's constantly blowing in the city
2. It was July 4th and a lot of things were closed
3. I love modern art

It just to happens that they had the Edvard Munch exhibit on display.  What a treat!  In addition, they were doing a small tour with a guide on this exhibit.  We used headsets, which worked out pretty well.  We were able to have a small amount of dialogue with the tour guide without making too much noise, and it was great to hear his perspective.

In addition, they have some wonderful exhibits, from pop art to modern art to sculptures.  I didn't get to explore as much as I wanted to, but I would certainly recommend this place for the more artistic visitors out there!  They are also open on most major holidays, so if you're visiting on a long holiday weekend, they are most likely open.
author: Jeannine S.

description: Very cool place ! Planning to go here more. 10/10 recommend. Great place to hangout w/ your friends and check out cool art pieces.
author: Summer S.

description: I had not been here in a few years, especially since the new wing opened.  I had less than 2 hours to check it out:  high speed viewing!   I mostly checked out the new wing which is beautifully done from the inside and outside: the art spaces keep your focus on the art, are well lit and minimize distraction outside the works.   The stairways are fun, with all kinds of odd angles depending on the shape of the building at that level.  The lobby is massive and contains a huge Serra in the far corner, what a great headspace, and there are nice views of the city from various porches laden with art.  I barely had time to run through the old museum again which is still great too.   You could spend most of a day here, I will visit again next time!
author: Brandon B.

description: What a wonderful museum.  So much to see!  Let me start with the giant spider sculptures!  Amazing.  Louise Bourgeois' spiders are surprising and strangely beautiful.  The exhibit of German artists was so impressive!  My favorite was the Katharina Fritsch, Kind mit Pudeln (Child with Poodles), 1995-1996.  Something mesmerizing about poodles surrounding an infant.  Also liked the neon light installations.  And Chuck Close was fantastic!  I had not seen his work before.  It's like giant pointillism!  I loved walking up close, and then backing up to see when the portrait "gelled" into a face.  And of course there were Andy Warhol pictures and Roy Lichtenstein pieces that were interesting, as well as tons of other stuff.  And don't get me started on the calder pieces!  So many!  And the living wall outside, with the sculptures.  On top of the art, you've got nice cafes and coffee and a really great gift shop.  I had such a good time here.
author: Alex M.

description:
Finally made a trip to check out SF MoMA! It's a great museum and you could easily spend the whole day here. I feel like they have a wide range of exhibits to peak anyone's interest. I really liked their living wall and their Andy Warhol collection. 

There's plenty of benches throughout so you can sit and take in the art or just take a break if you get tired. There's definitely a lot of walking, standing, staring, and posing for selfies involved. My only annoyance were the elevators. Takes forever since there are so many people. I guess just take the stairs!
author: Cindy K.

description:
I had no idea SFMOMA was remodeled.  I remember coming here years ago.  I even saw a statue on the 4th floor that was in the little sculpture garden when I visited in the past.  Ticketing is a little crazy.  They encourage buying online.  There's a large coat/bag check that's free which is nice.  

We only made it up to the 4th floor exhibits.  There was a really interesting exhibit from artist Bruce Connor.  So much so, photography was not allowed.  But my favorite thing to do, was sit watch and listen to the others.  So called "art intellectuals" who use big words...and not matter what deep meaning you have managed to let everyone around you hear, it's just two orange squares to me...LOL!

Another neat thing about MOMA are the walking works of art.  The way some people dressed ranged from classic and interesting to amusing and downright comical.  Foreign visitors have no concept of personal space or that there are others around them.  There were a number of young people who were reprimanded for either standing too close or touching the art.  

Definitely worth checking out.
author: Mikey H.

description: I was so excited to come here and was not disappointed by a lot of the art pieces here. So many good ones on each floor that you are not expected. The place is also big enough that it was not crowded when you go through each floor. I like how each floor is designated for different types of art so you get it all here. The floor is also nice and open plenty of space to walk around. The only disappoint thing is the mirror and string piece on the 6th floor is being uninstalled. Also beware that if you wear a backpack that day you will have to carry it in front of you or on your side. We also got discount for being under 25, we paid $19 each.
author: Thanasri T.

description:
Great addition to central city in SF!

Intriguing art designs, photographies, filmographies and paintings.

There are 7 floors, each themed, to peruse through.
author: Tiffany D.

description: This was my first time back here since the remodel, and I have to say it is beautiful! Not just the exhibits, but the building itself is quite stunning as well. We went at around 12pm on a Thursday we're able to get through the whole thing by around 4pm. The exhibits contain a nice mix of canvas work, sculpture, photography, and displays in alternative media. We were lucky to see a special exhibition when we were there called sound waves which, like you'd expect, was an exhibition on art involving sounds. My favorite was one room where they had videos of people playing instruments by themselves, but the music each person was playing worked in concert with what the other people were playing. It was really beautiful and such a cool idea! And of course they have a nice selection of pieces by Pollack, Lichtenstein, and other big names in modern art as well which are really fun to see. We approached our day by taking the elevator to the top floor and then working our way down by taking the stairs. This was recommended to us by one of the staff members, and I enjoyed going about it this way since it also gave us the opportunity to appreciate the architecture of the building itself! Overall, had a wonderful day here, and I'll be back to check out some of the other exhibitions that come here!
author: Rachel D.

description:
Chun P's Thoughts while going through SFMOMA...
"What the F%$K?" (most popular, not in a bad way)
"That's awesome!"
"That is stupid."
"That is really effing dumb"
"Dafuq?"
"Really effing weird...but I like it!"

I'm sure you'll feel the same way...I'll say it...this is my favorite "art" museum in the whole FUCing world. I've been to the Uffizi in Florence, Louvre in Paris, National Gallery in Oslo, and other fancy schmancy museums...  they're all great too...but I love WEIRD!  Weird rocks my world.  I am weird!

$25 isn't cheap, but we spent a solid 3 hours here, so I think I got my money's worth. The cafes are pricey too, but again its San Francisco...the kids's mac n cheese was delish! Parking sucks...but thats San Francisco.  $4 every half hour adds up quick! Not sure if there's cheaper options elsewhere.
author: Chun P.

description:
This is one of my favorite museums. Actually it is my favorite museum. This museum just gets better and better. It is one of those places I know I will keep coming back to and not get tired of.  There's so many floors and the floors are so big. Every floor is dedicated to art so properly. There's that one famous floor that's dedicated to only photography. 
I love this location to right by the Gold club and alot of hotels. Shoot it's right in the peak of downtown.
author: Luke S.

description:
Finally decided to check out SFMOMA after it completed renovations. Luckily, my mom has membership and was able to take me as a guest.

Pros:
-7 floors of modern art, but even as a casual museum-goer I didn't feel overwhelmed by the number of pieces
-Some fun interactive pieces such as the #SelfComposed photo booth near Sight Glass coffee shop
-Plenty of natural lighting so the museum feels much more open than it already is
-Art isn't all squished together so even with a lot of ppl you won't feel claustrophobic
-Efficient layout of the exhibits. I didn't feel like I was missing out on seeing anything because everything "flowed" very well

Cons:
-An army of security guards are positioned at every corner. They are not afraid to bark at you if you even get a little close to the art pieces. A tiny bit more cheer and friendliness on their part would make a world of a difference
-Same goes with the "greeters" at the very entrance. The first thing I hear when I step foot inside the museum lobby (not even in the exhibits or ticketing area yet!) should not be "PUT AWAY YOUR WATER BOTTLE PLEASE!!"
A "Hello, welcome to SFMOMA" followed by a reminder to put away liquids would contribute to a much more pleasant experience.

I'm honestly not the biggest fan of modern/contemporary art so I wouldn't personally pay $25 for admission, but I'd say it's still worth visiting on one of their free days.
author: Sylvia Y.

description:
I was very excited to check out the MOMA after its recent renovation. I was underwhelmed. For starters, I was hoping to spend some time on my own wandering around the museum, but when I called, they were unapologetic about being unable to offer anywhere to pump. Thankfully, I was able to drag the entire family so that I could go (and breastfeed when needed).

When we walked in, the temperature was suffocating. I don't know if they were trying to compensate for the cold outside, but it was horrible. The lines to get tickets, even in the membership line, were also long and slow. 

A couple of the exhibits themselves were interesting, but I thought it was lame that they are rotating political posters in phases (please, come spend more money so you can see the other ones!). Most of the exhibits were just OK, and none were really interactive. Needless to say, this is NOT a kid-friendly museum. 

Finally,  the cafe was absurdly overpriced. For $15, the least you can do is add a little salad to the small and sparse sandwich. And my daughter's meal was about a half a teaspoon each of peanut butter and jelly on 2 Hawaiian rolls. For $7.50. I spent more here for less food than I have ever spent at any museum or zoo, and we were all still hungry! 

There are so many great museums in SF. I'll go to them.
author: Amy B.

description: The MOMA is accessible to the layman while still pushing the envelope. Their exhibits are world class and the facility is beautiful. It was recently renovated. The Museum hosts special events with DJs and cocktail bars at night which is free to members. The MOMA is the heart of the Museum District and we San Franciscans are proud to have such a cosmopolitan collection.
author: Jeromy C.

description: A few things I recommend that others do not have in their reviews. WEAR nice walking shoes! This museum is 7 floors and we easily walked 10,000 steps. PAY the EXTRA price to your ticket online and show up at the predetermined time to see the special exhibitions. We came and saw an exhibition of a surrealist painter and seeing most of the work of an artist as well as a speaker discussing this artist was the highlight. The building this museum is in is amazing and I loved the vertical garden. This museum has almost every important modern artist of the modern era even if it may only be one painting. We spent four hours here, but I could see us coming back when the exhibitions change. Next time, I will bring my headphones and try the MomaSF app you can download to your iPhone. I think doing some reading on the artists beforehand and listening to the app may help me understand parts of this museum better.
author: InPopeWeTrust P.

description: Haven't been here in about 15 years.  The exhibits were okay, nothing memorable to me probably because I'm not a big photography person.  Overall, it's a beautiful museum.  My advice, take the elevator to the top floor and then descend on feet, it's much easier :)
author: Dennis H.

description:
My friend invited me to go to MOMA with her and I was like why not? Im not a huge fan of modern art mostly  because i dont really understand it, but its important to support freedom of expression regardless!!

Entry fee is $25  and  well worth it, this museum is 7 floors and you can spend a good 4 hours in here. Each floor has  a different focus and theme, my favorite  pieces were probably the  living wall and the neon lights. 

Be sure to walk outside the building when you are on the top floors for extra exhibits plus an amazing view!!
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Oh man I love this place. It has a perfect mixture of confusing art that makes you wonder why people even consider this art and beautiful art that you can just stare at forever. There are some pretty big name people like Andy Warhol and Lichtenstein so people who aren't well versed in modern art can also enjoy the museum. As for me, I fan girled over the Lee Krasners and the Frank Stellas. 

The museum itself is really nice with multiple floors that are clean and new. You do have to buy tickets and they're like $19 I think. A little pricey in my opinion, especially after going to the Met in New York. I definitely think that everyone should go!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
This is by far my favorite museum in SF, in California, on the entire West Coast. If you're a local (within an hour, really), the annual membership is definitely worth it. It's pretty much paid for after a few visits, and you can bring a friend for free any day of the year! Easy friend points right there!

The super Instagram-worthy museum is newly remodeled, so expect bright clean lines and unfortunately, crowds on the weekends. I actually stopped by for the Matisse/Diebenkorn exhibit on a Friday and BOY WAS IT CROWDED. The museum has seven floors, plenty of stairs/elevators, and an ever-changing collection of work. 

Since it IS 'modern' art, don't expect much in terms of greek statues or idyllic European landscapes, but prepare to have your mind opened by the tastefully curated exhibits they have on display.
