Expect to see everything from breathtakingly abstract statues to pits of sand, from a plush green living wall to 'cloud cities' that appear to be forever suspended in the air, from the likes of Dali (my favorite!) to the famous Warhol (& I can't forget Lichtenstein!) himself. 

Membership is free if you're under 18, and I believe they have a few free days every once in a while. There's a cute coffee shop inside, and overall this museum is spacious and fun to get lost in. Unlike some other museums (east coast, I'm talking about you), it's hard to lose track of your friends/family here for too long; you'll run back into them eventually! Come with an open mind, and enjoy! 

(I finally made it to 500 reviews! This obviously had to be a 5-star milestone haha)
author: Christine L.

description:
This place closed down about 3 years ago due to some renovations and they have finally opened up! We decided to spend a decent chunk of our Memorial Day here. We didn't buy tickets online as I figured there would be a student discount at the door. Never found out, as an older gentleman and his wife couldn't make it that day and they were selling their tickets for $20 for the pair! Saved me $30 bucks! Now we are talking. 

The place was pretty packed on a day where SF was actually pretty empty. SF is normally a zoo, but today it felt fresh and clean. Well certain parts at least. This place is huge and there are 7 floors. Also be on the lookout for Waldo. Hint hint. He's not actually inside the building. 

You will see everything here, including a crucified Jesus frog. No joke, but awesome nonetheless. If you're a modern art fan, then this place is worth checking out. Go for it!
author: Benny H.

description:
SF MOMA is an absolutely wonderful museum to go to. If you haven't gone at least once, then you are missing out. For starters, parking is atrocious but once you get past that, you'll be in for a treat. Prices are quite reasonable and if you're 18 or younger, it's free, so all you youngsters, get at it. It'll be difficult to finish MOMA in a single trip but I'd go again.

SFMOMA has a plethora of exhibits and artworks ranging from Diego Rivera to light exhibits to modern art and sculptures. With a whopping 7 floors, there's more than enough art to appreciate; note that they're always adding/changing exhibits here and there so be aware of that. 

In conclusion, come here at least once if you're in SF, then come again, and again.
author: Derek T.

description:
I was bummed when SFMOMA closed three years ago not because I would miss all the art but because I wouldn't be able to hang out at the sculpture patio with my Blue Bottle in tow. Y'see, I'm just not deep a person. In fact, I kept wondering why they felt a need to expand a perfectly respectable museum within a very constrained space around the W Hotel. However, when Jamie W. bought memberships for us, we got to have a preview look last weekend. I was startled at how impressive the results of the renovation are.

It felt like this was the original intention all along, 170,000 square feet of exhibition space that seamlessly weds Mario Botta's original  brick-laden building with the white Nordic crinkles of the Norwegian design firm Snohetta (photo: http://bit.ly/228JSuO). Another entrance has been built on Howard Street where you start on the second floor with a sweeping view of Richard Serra's massively elliptical sculpture, "Sequence" (photo: http://bit.ly/1sngZz9). We started on the seventh floor where multi-media artworks are on display (photo: http://bit.ly/23QET18). There's a narrow sculpture balcony that overlooks much of SoMa (photo: http://bit.ly/1Xav6D5).

Walking down to the sixth floor, we saw a lot of graphic design and contemporary German art. The familiar starts to show up on the fifth floor where Roy Lichtenstein's pop-comic art is given its space as well as Andy Warhol's "Triple Elvis" (photo: http://bit.ly/1Or4goq) and "Double Dolly" (photo: http://bit.ly/1snhkSl). You can now walk over a bridge to Cafe 5 where the Blue Bottle Cafe used to be, and the sculpture patio has thankfully been left intact (photo: http://bit.ly/1TdwTlY). The fourth floor focuses on abstract works and pieces from less familiar artists, while the Alexander Calder mobiles show up on the third floor.

There's also an adjacent outdoor space featuring a living wall and a lot more sculptures (photo: http://bit.ly/1Otuf9F), as well as a Sightglass coffee area to rest your feet from all that stair climbing (photo: http://bit.ly/1ZRe0cu). The second floor is where they made the restrooms a vivid red  and placed many of the modern paintings I've missed for the past three years. Yes, I know you think I'm an art ignoramus, but yes, I remembered those pieces fondly like...uhhh...ummm. OK so now that I'm a member, I'll be coming back more often after the crowds die down and maybe wear a beret and sip a white wine spritzer.
author: Ed U.

description:
Amazing art pieces!
Lichtenstein, Warhol, Haring, Rivera, Tamayo, Orozco... the best artists! However they do have 6 floors of amazing art pieces of different styles and pieces from different styles. From paintings to sculptures and installations.
author: Christine B.

description:
Finally I had a chance to visit SF Museum of Modern Art after years. The museum had been remodeled, now, still has the same look from outside but all are new and beautiful inside. I remember how excited I was at my first visit there over ten years ago. The later visits were a bit less agitation. This time, the same feelings from the first time were bqck. Just "wow", "wow", and "wow" at the entrance and at many parts on every floor (depending on the exhibitions). I stayed there for 1 and a half hour but could not finish all 7 floors. I spent quite a while at exhibition of Walker Evans photographer with powerful black and white photos. 
I have one concerning which was about the quality of material that they used to remodel the museum. Personally, looking at the pieces of marlbe formed the stairs, I thought the quality was not compatible to this iconic museum. I don't think it is a seamless integration between the new design and Mario Botta's. 
Juat a thought. 
I must come back soon and must check all the 7 levels.
author: Mintar H.

description:
Came here for a field trip for my marketing class and it was probably the worst experience I have ever had with a museum. 

I had high expectations for this museum based on the reviews on Yelp. When I first got there the person giving my teacher the tickets was extremely rude and seemed rushed. 

After waiting awhile for our tickets, my classmates and I were walking around looking at the "art" (some of the art pieces were literally just canvases with one physical color on the entire canvas) when the security yelled at us for having our backpacks on our back. they kept hassling us to put our backpacks in front of us. I understand that there are certain policies that need to be followed but there is no need to yell and be disrespectful to people who are causing no harm or disruptions. Along with them being very rude to us, a lot of the exhibits were closed down so there weren't many things to look at. 

Overall one of the worst museums I have ever been to. Do not waste your money here, for the price that other people pay, it's not worth being treated like garbage. I would recommend the Legion of Honor museum. Not this sad excuse of a "museum" (no like actually, who considers a block of Burgandy art???)
author: Luis L.

description:
The SF MOMA just reopened in May and it is beautiful! Seven gorgeous floors of jaw-dropping art. I want to explore every inch of the museum- it will take me months so I just got a membership. The memberships are affordable- $150 for an annual dual membership (got it with my fiancé) allows us to go whenever we want and bring guests. They also have a great iphone app with interactive podcast-like tours that range from a quick 15m to an hour. They explain the art in a fun, creative, entertaining and memorable way. I'm lucky that I work right next door- hope to go a lot this year and learn as much as I can! 

Also they have a great cafe where you can grab lunch, coffee, or some pastries and enjoy the nice weather on the outdoor patio.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
It's just my luck that SFMOMA closes for renovations when I started working in the city, and then they re-open when I leave my job in the city. At least my new job provides free Caltrain rides up to the city!

Stephanie S. and I got dual membership at the museum ($150) which allows us to get unlimited free admission, free entry for an additional guest each, priority tickets for special exhibitions, 10% off at the store, and more! Otherwise, a single ticket is $25. 

Open everyday from 10a - 5p (but Thursdays stay open until 9p), you can spend a few hours exploring multiple exhibits. There are 7 different floors, and every floor has tons of beautiful art. With so many pieces, there's bound to be a painting, a sculpture, or even a photo that captures your eye!

Get your steps in and enjoy a day at the museum!
author: Christine S.

description:
The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art is back bigger and better than ever. Known colloquially as SFMOMA, the museum was closed for a long time for a massive remodel and expansion. The museum is now open for business with the same entrance on 3rd Street in SoMa near the Yerba Buena Center.

This museum is now massively large and expansive. I have been to many museums, and this one is now a monster with galleries on seven floors taking up a large section of the block. Several of the new galleries have some really avant garde art including multimedia experiences that really stretch the viewers mind and views of art. With such a large collection and travelling exhibits, it is hard to describe the installations since they may change when you read this review.

The museum itself was designed as art. The old entrance now takes you directly upstairs for ticketing and the main entrance. Electronic ticketing is available and recommended. A lot of people head to the elevators to go up to the top and slowly work down, but I kept bumping into people working their way up, so there is no official plan. The museum is now just too big to attempt in one session, so I recommend planning several visits to fully explore the collections.

Nestled amongst the exhibits are several food and drink options including a café and coffee bar. There are also several patios and a great vertical garden continuing the experience in good weather. Expect the place to be crowded for some time as locals and tourists rediscover the exhibits.

Admission is pretty pricy making an annual membership potentially the better bargain. Crowds will be a fixture for a while, but people watching is part of the fun! Who knows, maybe you can meet that special someone looking at the same painted urinal?
author: Kristian D.

description:
SFMOMA is back and better then ever. It was worth the wait as far as I'm concerned. While I will miss the charm of the classic SFMoma it's still there and I can come visit that side often enough. The new side of SFMoma offers visitors more gallery space and contemporary design. It's breathtaking. It really fresh, its totally worth the price of admission to go check it out. 

San Francisco is fortunate to have such a wonderful space for modern art. 
The new entrance and design seem to fit seamlessly into the surrounding neighborhood, as I pass bye I feel like I could be in any world class gallery in any other major city in the world. It feels correct.

I was there on the last day before it closed down and I am super excited to have it back again.
author: Ben M.

description:
To celebrate one of my BFF's birthdays, we visited SFMOMA on the day after their opening day on May 15, 2016.   We showed up around 11:15 am and their first available slot for entrance was anytime after 12:45 pm which was great because we would have time to eat at Vitrine next door and then pop on over.  

The place was crowded when we entered.  There's a total of 7 floors with each floor having a theme. We started on the 7th floor which was the "The Campaign for Art" exhibition and featured modern and contemporary art. It was very crowded on this floor on the day we went but overall had some cool art pieces. 

After this, we trekked on to the the German After 1960 floor and it was one of my fave exhibits.  This floor was very calming.  I loved the piece by Gerhard Richter which is a beautiful picture of the ocean.   Taken from SFMOMA's website, this exhibit is "German artists emerging after 1960 explored the postwar landscape--situated between recent disaster and emerging prosperity--with a combination of skepticism, uncertainty, and excitement to begin anew. Drawn from the Doris and Donald Fisher Collection, this exhibition features single-artist galleries devoted to leading German artists such as Georg Baselitz, Bernd and Hilla Becher, Anselm Kiefer, Sigmar Polke, and Gerhard Richter." 

Another fave of mine was the California and the West exhibit. I was raised in San Francisco so I loved all the pics of CA and the many different pieces in this exhibit.  My friends loved this exhibit as well.  

We checked out the cafe but the line was out the door so we didn't get to try anything. 
We spent about an hour and a half at the museum before running over to our appointment at Remede spa next door so we didn't have time to check out the entire museum.  I will definitely be back soon though.  Definitely worth a visit!  Y
author: Christine P.

description:
Huge museum and a great way to spend half your day! The great thing about art is that it is open to interpretation. With that said, my friends and I had a blast interpreting the pieces. It took us about 4.5 hours to walk through all floors, at a leisurely pace with several breaks in-between. My favorite was the California exhibit, as they showcased vintage photographs of San Francisco. It was also interesting that every floor's restroom was painted a different color. This is a great place to easily gain 10,000 steps for those of you attached to your Fitbits/activity trackers! :p

I advise purchasing tickets online ahead of time. You don't get to line up at the elevators until your allotted time. Therefore, it's not too necessary to arrive 30 minutes beforehand unless you wanted to do coat check, and even then the lines shouldn't be too terrible. Definitely choose an earlier time slot. The place got horribly crowded between 1pm and 4pm while we were there on a Saturday. Take public transportation as SF MOMA is only a short walk away from Bart or Muni. Parking is horrendous otherwise. Highly recommend!
author: Kristi T.

description:
SF MOMA is now one of the largest modern art museums in the U.S.

There's 7 floors full of art - both indoor and outdoor. It took about 3 hours to go through all 7 floors. Started from the 1st floor and as we went up, I felt like the work on each floor kept getting better and better. There's also a Sightglass coffee inside on the 3rd floor for anyone who needs some caffeine to help get through the entire museum. The staff is pretty strict about not touching or getting too close to the work, so be prepared to get yelled at or watch people get yelled at if they get too close.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Came on opening day, May 14, 2016, and had a blast. My buddy got free tickets for the first day, so I had to check it out. There are seven floors, each floor with a different general theme. We started on the top floor working our way down. Not only were the exhibits cool, but I also find it interesting just people watching. The type of fashion you see from the artgoers can be almost as interesting as the art itself!

The museum is in a really nice area of San Francisco in the Soma district so there's plenty to check out before and after. I felt almost overwhelmed by all the different exhibits here: sculptures, film, pop art, minimialism, abstract, the list goes on. Heck, they even have palm pilots, google glass, and the very first iPhone here. So if you come here, you can be sure to say the iPhone is old enough to be in a museum. 

I've heard there's also a really good app you can download to get more information on a lot of the pieces. Photography is allowed here as long as you don't use flash, and food and drink are a big no no. They have a place to check your coat and/or any bags, and a cafe here on the 5th floor in case you get hungry. Definitely worth a visit at least once
author: Kenny L.

description: This was the first time I experienced an exhibit at SF MOMA with a few young children who were visiting.  We did the Spiders! tour, Louise Bourgeois's Spiders and it was terrific!  The kids were engaged, I was fascinated, and her work is  stunning, whether you like spiders or not!  Also, do try the video series The Country Dog Gentlemen Travel to Extraordinary Worlds -- that dog is the perfect ambassador to introduce young ones to art.
author: Frank S.

description:
Some people say that they are not "modern art people" and just "don't get it." I would encourage those people to come give SF MoMa a chance because it really is 7 floors worth of amazing things to see. I got the basic $100 membership knowing I'd come back and perhaps bring different friends with me (for FREE).

I came here on a Sunday afternoon and after 3 hours of browsing I was only able to get to 3 of the 7 floors. (My friend and I really got wrapped up in the typography section, and browsed at sort of medium-slow pace)

The curators have done a great job of choosing a variety of mediums and artists to showcase in such a a beautifully redesigned space. The ceilings are high and they've organized the space well so there is great flow. I really enjoyed a lot of the rooms that were showing video and a really mesmerizing zoetrope. 

Enjoy the terrace on the 7th floor and the sculpture garden connected to the cafe if you find that the exhibitions are not your cup of tea.
author: Candice C.

description:
Great date place to go (only if you come when they open!!!) we arrived around 10:30am and it was pretty empty. We bought tickets online so we went straight to the elevator on the second floor to get to the 7th floor. Definitely start from the top, and work your way back downstairs as it's less crowded. 

They have a free coat room on the first floor. It gets pretty warm in the museum so I recommend checking in your coat. 

The price was pretty steep- $25 per adult. But I think it's worth checking it once if you are in the bay. 

I'm not a big art snob nor do I know how to analyze different art pieces. I laugh at the paintings with one single color and question why a toilet bowl is art. There are quite a few questionable "art" pieces but it's still pretty fun to walk around. My favorite has to be the pop art section. We were here for about 2 hours and by the time we left at around 12:30pm the place was completely PACKED. 

Cafe was extremely overpriced ($15 for a sandwich what?!) so we stayed hungry until we found somewhere to eat outside the museum. 

Come early! Buy tickets online to skip the line!
author: Sarah I.

description:
Love it 

It is my 2nd time visiting the museum  
And wow.   There is some art work I never saw in my life.   So nice.  

I am
Not huge on museum.   But moma is a beautiful place to visit if you visit San Francisco.
author: Comrac L.

description: So beautiful! This is the first museum in a long time that I am truly inspired and fascinated in all of its work! If you love art you have to come here! There are so many interactive exhibits as well
author: Alexis C.

description:
Went around 3:45 and they close at 5 so I decided to just get the yearly membership ($100) since you can bring a guest for free and thus pay for it in two visits. 

Beautiful building and spaces (love the sculpture garden and living wall + large sculptures on the terrace). I wasn't as crazy about the paintings. Loved the Chuck Close and Warhol pieces though. 

We didn't try any of the food but the cafe space is cute and great on a sunny day. 

We visited diRosa in Sonoma a while back and I have to say that's now the standard for modern art for me. I was definitely more drawn to that collection. Excited to see what else the Moma has to offer. We did the 4th and 5th floors and the large sculptures so I'll be back when I have more time to see the rest of the floors.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Parking : Take BART. It's less of a headache. Parking is a challenge because it gets backed up to get into the surrounding garages and it's either $5 hr or $20 an hour. 

Museum: a pleasant variety of mediums and artists. There's 5 floors. They have elevators/handicap friendly. Coat check available on different floors. 

Bathrooms : big. Bright. And clean. 

Events : fun events for members. They sure know how to get down and have a good time. 

Food: they have little delights and drinks but you can't walk around with your drink or food in hand. You have to finish it where the little bar / cafe is at. 

They have outside seating with sculptures and lighting. 


Definitely a date night place to chat and get to know each other a little better while enjoying some art to help with the conversation.
author: Trinidad M.

description:
It's been a long wait (4 years?). Stopped by yesterday with the member preview ticket and it was worth every penny. The new SFMOMA is now one of my favorite museums to visit. 

Their Ellsworth Kelly collection is amazing, and the building itself is one giant piece of art. 

Don't miss the Richard Serra piece on the first floor. Walk through the concrete walls and feel the path twists in front of you.

I'll be back. Prob multiple times a week. Thank you SFMOMA and the philanthropists behind it who made the whole thing happen.
author: Joseph L.

description:
A beautifully designed building that houses one of the best collections of modern art I've seen in quite some time.  Manageable without being overwhelming and with several outside areas and cafes.

I went on a Sunday afternoon and assumed it would be packed with people (like MoMA in NYC) but it was pleasantly busy.
author: Kate P.

description:
What I said in a review about the SF Ballet, certainly applies to SFMOMA as well: the arts our food for our souls. Lots to feast on at SFMOMA.  

The renovation makes SFMOMA more open than I remember it being in the past. Also the gift shop is much larger and offers many very appealing items.

I visited SFMOMA with two family members with a goal of seeing the Diane Arbus exhibit. Excellent.

We also enjoyed taking our time in a few other galleries, but did not begin to cover what we wanted to see. I joined SFMOMA (a good rate for seniors) and plan to visit again soon -- and often.
author: Elaine P.

description: By far, my favorite museum for modern art.  I've been coming here for years now and I still do not believe that I've seen it all (if I'm not mistaken, I think there are over 7 floors).  Favorites have to include the 90s art and of course, the pop art from the 60s and 70s. A must see if you are in SF!
author: Rey W.

description:
Oh MOMA - job well done on this amazing upgrade!!!

Been going here since I was in middle school (yep, just dated myself!) and to see seven floors of amazing art work... simply amazing! 

Biased... but my favorite exhibit was the Typeface to Interface. If you're a graphic / visual designer... definitely check it out. The collection was informative and definitely made me proud to be apart of the community!

Highly suggest reserving your ticket online... it gets packed on weekends of course so maybe weekdays would be better if you can. 

If you're in SF and a fan of art... Must. Visit. !!!
author: Cath M.

description:
Buy the membership if you live in SF or work in SF. Zero downside. I love to pop in for one set of paintings or just a cup of coffee on one of the terraces. 

The new MOMA gives me so much joy. I have only been twice but I am so thankful for everything the Fisher family has contributed to providing art to the city of San Francisco. 

Don and Doris only purchased pieces they both loved. The MOMA is nothing but love on every floor. 

From the cafes to the multiple balconies that overlook the city - you can't go wrong. 

Thank you, thank you MOMA for reopening - I missed you!
author: Alison C.

description: Great museum. We got to see the Edvard Munch exhibit, but it was disappointing that 'Scream' wasn't there. We spent 3 hours checking everything out, and they had very interesting/disturbing videos going on in a couple of the rooms. I couldn't stop watching, so that's a positive.  Definitely check out In Situ restaurant while you're there.  Also, this place will always have a great memory since it's where I met boyfriend.  Cue the 'awwwws".
author: Ha D.

description:
Probably my 3rd visit. Lucked out and got tix to the Edvard Munch exhibit- ( minus the scream) an excellent variety of his work- and the audio supplied was great- so much additional insight and information about this artist and others- with nary a hiccup- you just had to be within spitting distance for some of the selections to rise to the top of the devices screen.

Glad to get my dose of culture in my brief visit to the city. And they monetized his work with art for sale right outside the exhibition..

He indeed captured sickness and grief in no other way that i have witnessed.  A bit disturbing, but not meant to br more than a haunting reminder of death being an ever present part of this life.  Surreal and ethereal, his work is very emotional.  

Unsure of how i'll sleep tonight..
author: Greg B.

description: Whenever I am in the city, I make a stop here just to have some me-time. I don't quite comprehend modern arts most of time but being exposed to art definitely adds sparkle to my life
author: Ronni K.

description:
I want to love this place, I really do! I eagerly anticipated the re-opening of the SFMOMA, as my husband and I love modern art. My favorite art museum is MOMA in Manhattan. Second favorite is the Museum of Modern Art in Paris. Maybe my expectations are set too high. 

The building itself is new (surprise!), clean, and full of light. It has about 5 floors or so. Ticketing wasn't an issue the day we visited. We are reciprocal members, so that may have made a difference. There is a fairly large parking deck situated on the side of the building, so parking is expensive, but rather easy if spaces are open. For me, the issue is that I didn't even see one thing that excited me. And this was in the months right after the grand re-opening. As exhibits rotate, maybe I will find things more appealing? What am I missing?
author: Amber L.

description: Only go here if you appreciate abstract art. And by abstract art I mean scribbles on a paper.
author: Jade L.

description:
I was so excited to come back to San Francisco Museum of Modern Art after their reopening this year. SFMOMA is huge! We got in for free since the Mr.'s company is a sponsor. You could spend nearly a day here but we figured a few hours to roam around at San Francisco Museum of Modern Art was plenty. We ended up taking Caltrain in so parking wasn't an issue for us. A few blocks to walk and we were here. Arrive early and beat the crowds. We'll come back soon to appreciate the arts at San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

2016 Review #63
author: Stephanie G.

description:
As a casual museum guy, this is definitely a worthwhile place to visit once if you live in the Bay Area. If you are tourist, this is a worthwhile place to visit if you are running out of things to do. It would not be necessarily high on my to-do list.

As a budget conscience guy, $25 adult general admission as quite pricey, but there are pieces from Warhol and Diego Rivera that might be worth it.

But if you decide to go and want to find parking, look up the Moscone Center garage for affordable prices and a good location.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Tickets are $25 if you're 25 or over. 
$19 for those 19-24. 
FREE if you're 18 or under!! You don't often hear the word "free" in SF. 

I was the only one who had to pay $19 in my group of friends since they were 18, but the person who scanned our tickets didn't even check our IDs for our ages.. so I could've saved $19 if I knew :( 

Moving on to the museum, there are 7 floors & each floor held a different exhibit. The place was huge and one could spend hours here but if you aren't really into art, I'd say 1-2 hours here will get you through the entire museum. 

Overall, I'd recommend SFMOMA if you're into art and are willing to pay the steep admission price. If it's free for you, you should definitely plan a visit while you can and save money!
author: Ha P.

description:
I'm officially a member at SF MOMA and last weekend I had a chance to check out the new version of the MOMA and was totally impressed. 7 floors of modern art, amazing!

And if you're local and like modern art, I recommend becoming a member. It's $100 for the year and you can bring a guest for FREE (a day pass for adults is normally $25 each, per day).
author: Heather J.

description:
I love SFMOMA.  

I guess the only issue I have is that everybody else does, too. (It gets packed!)  Great date place, people-watching spot, and if you can find your own niche, a lovely area to chill. Plus, I hear there is artwork as well.

The Living Wall must be mentioned.  The gorgeous city views and breeze through the greenery are bound to relax even the most tightly wound individuals. (Totally not speaking from experience or anything.)

Also, do yourself, and this beautiful facet of the city, a favor and become a member.  You'll save 10% every day at the fantastic gift shop (20% during periodic member sales) and you'll always get to bring one guest for free. Share the love!
author: Pernicious J.

description:
Stopped here for an hour stayed all day.  Sat in the two Kentridge exhibits for hours.  They will consume you looking for every detail and wondering how they accomplished some of the effects.

Everything art you love to love and love to hate.  Go ahead and see it anyway, you might learn to love it.  Except maybe for the sandbag.  Is it a sandbag or is it art?  It's art.

Loved: Stillness in Motion - Cloud Cities
Loved: Fisher collection
author: Keith S.

description: Ok, I admit. I don't know much about modern art. But this review isn't about he art. It's about the employees who work there. I was at an interactive exhibit and I saw a child wearing and holding headphones near the exhibit like everyone else. She wasn't getting to close or anything and she kept holding the headphones to her head because she was afraid to drop them. She looked about 3 or 4. One of the employees came over and grabbed her by her arm and yanked her away from the exhibit. First of all, you do not grab someone's child like that and second you don't yank them so hard, enough to break her arm. Anyway, the kid wasn't standing so close to the structure (even in comparison to the adults) and she was holding her headphone cautiously. So, what happened was that the parents came over. And tried to explain to them that their child wasn't doing anything, which since I saw the whole thing, is the truth. The man first said she was standing too close, which more people came by and stood closer and touched the exhibit in front of him as he was shouting at the parents. Then he looked at the people around him staring, and he shouted at the kid that she was going to break the headphones, which was impossible because she didn't really walk and had too hands holding onto them trying hard not to drop them. Plus, the parents were standing close, watching her movements. First you hurt a child, then you lie. I'm incredibly disappointed! I DO NOT WANT MY MONEY TO GO TOWARDS THIS KIND OF PERSONNEL! Later in the museum, I was looking for a restroom and was separated from my partner who had the map, and. So I asked someone. She rolled her eyes and told. Me to just look at my map. Seriously? If I had a map I would have looked at it instead of asking you. Conclusion? She didn't answer me and ignored my question and walked away. Oh! That is NOT the end of it! There was a high-schooler (not confident of age) holding a DSLR and walking past an exhibit. So, usually people meander slowly in front of the painting at a snail's pace, but she wasn't walking very fast, it was around a slower than normal pace, but definitely looking for someone. And the personnel didn't just say "hey, slow down." No, instead he grabbed the strap of her camera, and it almost fell to the ground. Really? What was she doing wrong? There wasn't even an interactive exhibit to run into in the area. Just because you work at MOMA doesn't mean you have to be so pompous! Did I mention? During an exhibit, there was a pair of two employees pointing around at random visitors who walked by commenting on how they look and gossiping about how bad they look. Yes, I noticed. Remember me? I'm the girl with the "ugly shoes that didn't match her purse." YOUR STAFF NEEDS TO BE RETAINED FOR MANNERS. I will ABSOLUTELY NOT come here again!
author: Francis S.

description:
Art while it is subjective and at times difficult to comprehend or even relate to, it is often not within a stone's throw of our daily lives. The SF MoMa is in fact relatively accessible from most anywhere in the Bay Area and provides its visitors 7 floors of conscious altering, psychologically intriguing, puzzling and sometimes downright spectacular visual forms of subjective interpretation.

Admission is normally $25 and for this relatively paltry sum you can take your time to stop, ponder, analyze, or just quickly move on to the next piece to do it all over again.  You'll notice some that are taking this journey on their own or some in groups, couples of all ages, on dates, you name it, no one is excluded nor should they be. 

You could park at the Fifth and Mission garage which is relatively inexpensive and hoof it over here without any trouble. It is a joy and privilege to have this museum in this grand city.
author: Dennis W.

description: I dont understand modern art. But vets get in free with their familes, so thats cool.
author: Ruben E.

description:
Absolutely love this place! Seven floors of beautiful art, and a really nice gift shop. 

Every 3-4 years my company hosts our largest meeting in San Francisco, and we traditionally hold our Saturday evening President's Reception here. Cocktails and food stations throughout this lovely venue, coupled with a live band and dance floor!

Yet outside of the party, it's a great place to visit if you appreciate art. I'm posting some of my favorite pieces from this trip.
author: Joani O.

description:
Big fan on the new museum. 7 floors, hundred of photos, sculptures, painting and exhibits, and lots of excitement!! The only reason for the 4 stars, is that it's not the caliber of the National Art Gallery in DC or museums overseas. I guess I've been spoiled when it comes to museums! Other than that, I have no complaints. 

It's bigger than the MOMA in NY (but I heard NY was going to close for renovation, so I guess it's an arms race lol). Here's what you need to know:

-Some company's offer free tickets for their employees (+1 guest) for the first couple months after the reopening. Check with your employer before purchasing tickets.
-You have to buy timed tickets. This means that they sell tickets for entry times every 15 minutes. This does not mean that your visit is constrained by time. Also, you can enter (and re-enter) anytime between your entry time and closing. 
-Best to purchase tickets online because they have been going quickly. With that said, you can still get tickets at the admission desk the day of--but, you may not get the time you perfer.

Enjoy!
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Came in as a visitor from LA, and bought myself a dual membership the day of. Came to see the Edvard Munch show, which was very impressive, however I was absolutely blown away by one particular piece in the sound exhibition on the 7th floor. "The Visitors" by Ragnar Kjartansson blew me away. It literally brought me to tears, and I sat there for 2 whole hours (it's a 1 hour video, so I saw it twice). 

Very impressed with the new SF MoMA since it's renovations.
author: Jin C.

description: I'm going to be honest, a lot of pieces here I wouldn't even consider art. There was this spider exhibit which was cool but what was weird was these ladies were rolling around the floor and telling these people to close their eyes and as the people were closing their eyes the ladies continuously rolled around the floor and then they creeped up to the people and told them to "open" [their eyes] and they were like "WOW" like idk man. There were some cool pieces of art but seeing crap like that just makes me think like what the hell is going on in this world. It's 2018 not 500 B.C
author: Preston N.

description:
We had wanted to go to the museum soon as we have been anxiously awaiting the re-opening, and we just so happened to have a friend who had snagged several grand opening day tickets! 

We had a 1:15 entrance time so sauntered over after a great meal at Samovar. Word to the wise, make sure you allocate a full day at the MOMA because there is A LOT of art to be seen! Upon entrance, the greeting staff had recommended starting on the top floor and working our way down. So we took the silver elevators all the way to the Floor 7 and began our art viewing. 

As no art expert, I found the whole experience still very enjoyable. We spent probably 2 hours on the first three floors before taking a break at the appropriately named indoor/outdoor Cafe 5 on Floor 5. Here, you can get unlimited spa water or order anywhere from lunch to small desserts, coffee, lemonade, wine and more! 

Some of our favorite pieces were Charles Ray's sleeping woman, typeface to interface exhibit on Floor 6 (which I believe is a temporary exhibit and perfect for all who are interested in digital/graphic design and computers and stuff), Gerard Richter's photo paintings, the chair exhibit, and the lush living wall. By the end of the day, about 4 hours after we had entered, we got a little tired so we called it quits without some of seeing some of the galleries on Floors 2 and 3 - an excuse to return! 

Pro-tip: be sure to come early and wear comfortable shoes because there will be lots of walking!
author: Sarah N.

description: Nice museum, but the day we went, lots of construction and empty exhibit space. Expensive to get in. Had to pay even more to see the Edvard Munch exhibit. $87 for 2 adults & 1 student. Just to get in the door.  Gift shop was really just a book store with some overpriced jewelry thrown in. Yawn. The best part of our day was a tip we received from one of the employees. He told us the bathrooms are all painted a different color on every floor. So of course, we had to visit every bathroom & take a pic. That was super fun. The 7th floor sound exhibit was incredible. By far, the best exhibits in the museum. Fun, interactive, thought provoking. It's a nice museum, but the museums in So Cal are much better. (Getty, Getty Villa, Norton Simon, etc...)
author: ZenMama C.

description:
There's so much to see in here, to be clear, 7 floors worth of modern art. Not gonna lie, I was pretty tired by the end of our visit. Plan to stay more than an hour. My favorite were the Roy Lichtenstein pieces and the one sculpture of the cop that I hadn't even noticed was a sculpture at first. I noticed there were a few stuff I saw at The Broad here too. There's just so much in there you have to find something you like.

I like that the museum incorporated outdoor areas - Living wall terrace (wall of plants), area outside on the top floor with a nice skyline (look for the painted Waldos! Yes, there's more than one hehe), and the cafe/restaurant. There's also a cafe inside too on one of the floors. 

My friend also mentioned that with purchase of membership you can take friends in for free. If I lived in SF I'd definitely be down to get the membership. There's so much to see and just a nice place to spend time. I would definitely recommend you come visit if you're in SF.
author: Jane K.

description: I really loved this museum. What an amazing collection. I traveled a long way to visit SF and this museum was the highlight of my entire trip. I would definitely love to come back here. There is lots to see, you can easily spend the whole day here. All of the staff was super friendly. There's even a restaurant and a little coffee stand. The Magritte exhibit is a must-see if you can spend the extra $$. Beautiful museum with incredible views.
author: Marie J.

description: We had a great time at the museum. They have a lot of exhibits that I would never call art but they have a number of exhibits that I throughly enjoyed. The exhibits that were awesome made up for the other ones that are just filling space. They had a great Edvard Munch exhibit that is worth a visit.
author: Josh Z.

description: We visited the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA) when we visited San Francisco in May 2017.  It's conveniently located within walking distance of Union Square and rivals even the NY MOMA, in my opinion. We specifically visited the Matisse/Diebenkorn exhibit, which was at the museum between March through May 2017.  I'd seen Matisse pieces previously, but it was nice to see the work of Diebenkorn, who was a 20th century artist and whose works were heavily influenced by Matisse.  Though Matisse's works were distinguishable (and, in my opinion, more appealing), I thought the exhibit was artfully and thoughtfully done and we enjoyed it.  We also enjoyed viewing Matisse's works in the permanent collection, as well as the works of Frida Kahlo, Georgia O'Keeffe, James Rosenquist, Rihard Tuttle, Adaline Kent, etc.  They have an impressive permanent collection and very interesting visiting exhibits.  I would love to visit again in the future!
author: Pegah Y.

description: Huge museum, and had some of my favorite exhibits I've ever been to. Love the Soundtracks pieces up on the 7th, super innovative and interactive artwork. You can easily spend 3-4 hours here just wandering around.
author: Kevin N.

description:
The SFMOMA is amazing. I'm lucky enough to work and live across the street from the MOMA so frequent it quite a bit.

The art is beautiful. If you appreciate art, especially modern art, this is a place you have to visit - and maybe stay for a good part of the day. If you live in the city, I highly recommend getting the membership. I love being able to drop in for even an hour to enjoy the art and grab a coffee (even work) in their cafe. Even the food is good...and beautiful.
author: Katie R.

description: I love MOMA.  I have visited the museum twice this year alone.  The art is beautiful, absolutely stunning pieces.  Great place to visit and a must when in SF.  Took my nieces and nephew there in February and they really enjoyed it.  I was worried that it isn't a place for young teens but they had an awesome time.  Will forever be a fan of MOMA.
author: Anna K.

description: Came on a weekday morning. There is a public parking garage a few streets down from the museum, I think rates were $24 for 12 hrs. We spent about 3 hours at the museum. There's 7 floors but currently the 7th floor is u see construction and will reopen sometime in mid July. Even on a weekday morning, the museum was pretty busy. I recommend buying tickets online prior to coming to avoid standing in line to buy a ticket. The Edvard munch exhibit was open when we went. Regular admission tickets are $25 for adults and $33 if including the Edvard munch exhibit. We had lunch at the cafe on the 5th floor and they had a modest selection of pasta, sandwiches, and salads along with pastries and drinks.  You have the option of dining inside or outdoors in the sculpture garden next to the cafe. There's also a coffee bar on the 3rd floor. Overall, a great experience. There's a wide variety of modern art exhibits ranging from sculptures to paintings and photographs.
author: Helen J.

description:
This expanded museum is now world-class with seven floors of art that provokes thought, conversation, and inspiration.

The art includes modern, pop, abstract, and contemporary. There are always important photography exhibits as well as multi media works. There is a good mix of challenging art by lesser-known artists and well-known pieces by famous artists (e.g. Warhol, Matisse, Calder, Dewitt, Arbus).

It can get crowded, and it really is too much to see in a day. Membership fees are reasonable. If you are local, this is a museum to love and be proud of. If you are visiting, plan out what you want to see and plan breaks at the two fancy cafés.
author: Sagruilla P.

description: Saw "Lawrence of Arabia" in SFMOMA's Phyllis Wattis Theater, my first time in this theater. Theater is small, simple, basic, adequate, with a small red(!) gem of a women's restroom. I entered the building through the main museum entrance on 3rd Street, walked through the lobby to the theater doorway where a staff member scanned my ticket, and off I went. During my 5 hours there, I wound up interacting with about 7 staff members, all 5-star interactions, without exception. Asked basic directional questions of 3 uniformed guards, one gave a useful answer, the other two were surprisingly negative experiences for me. Theater snacks for sale included a brownie and a sweet-potato-&-goat-cheese rollup that looked yummy but was priced at $5, so I passed. 5-star staff, 2-star guards, theater adequate and clean with 5-star restroom.
author: Ari T.

description: Best place to go on a free museum day hands down, everything they have is mind expanding to say the least. Take the time out of your busy life to stop and smell the roses, culture is one of the cornerstones of our postmodern universe, feed your mind with creative images and the rest will follow...if you don't like, you don't understand, it's all good...either way it's the best show in town.
author: Scott P.

description: Wonderful place and spot. Store also very beautiful. Art is in many streets in SF but there, it's the boulevard !
author: Marie-Claire L.

description:
I have to admit that I'm partial to SFMOMA.  This is where my boyfriend and I went on our third date and where my heart began to feel a flutter for him.  

It began with a piece located outside on the second floor that simply looked like 2 zig-zag shaped walls made of metal.  "What do you feel when you walk through it?" my date asked after I walked through. "Nothing." I respond, "I don't get it."  

"There's no right or wrong answer." he says "It's about YOUR interaction with the art and how it makes you feel.  When I walk through, I feel a sense of claustrophobia.  The way the walls are shaped would trap me into a tiny space if they were to close in on me." 

I look along the outside, and see that the 2 metal walls are shaped so that they would create small, boxed rooms - only large enough to fit a standing person each - if they were to close in on each other.  I also notice that they are clearly bolted in place to the ground so that won't happen.  

"Doesn't the bolts detract from that feeling?" I ask.  My date just shrugs.  I wish I could experience it from his point of view but was having difficulty.  "Hold on!  Let me run through it again to see if I can see what you're seeing." I say before racing back in.  

"So what did you feel?" he asked again, once I was out.  I wished I could say something profound but it just wasn't in me so I answer back honestly:  "Like I'm reaching." 

I am not artsy by any means and I don't usually think to go to a museum. But this museum has something for everyone and is, at the very least, thought provoking and emotion inducing.  

At first, some of the things just might seem stupid.  A urinal fastened to a wall will always look like a urinal to me.  I mean - I read the explanation and I guess I get it (the thought provoking nature and the sexual suggestiveness of a urinal) but I just didn't buy it (why would that urinal be worth more than any other).  

"So how do YOU value art?" My date asked as I expressed my annoyance with the urinal.  "By how aesthetically pleasing it is and whether it matches my decor.  I like stuff I'd hang on my wall."  I answer.  

"Let me ask you," he says while pulling me back towards a photo I was walking away from "would you hang this on your wall?"  I look at the photo of a drag queen with her lips pursed in an "o."  

"No," I whisper back, embarrassed "it reminds me of a blowjob."  I say, as I envision the photo being hung over the urinal instead and being used accordingly.

"It gave me that impression too." He responded.  I'm pleased with his response.  Maybe I'm getting it more than I think I am.  

Abstract art is only a small part of SFMOMA.  There is something for everyone here.  Other art wasn't so hard-reaching for me and I ooohed over the skill and medium used in some pieces and surprised myself with the intense emotion triggered by others.  

SFMOMA is an experience.  It's an opportunity to step back and look at seemingly ordinary things in a new light or extraordinary things in an extraordinary light.  I would highly recommend going here and seeing what it is that you see.
author: Linda H.

description: Finally had a chance to come here after the renovation and reopening and the building is stunning!  I'm not a huge fan of modern art, so I won't review the exhibits themselves (honestly, I wouldn't really know what to say anyways), but the space is really, really well done.  My only complaint is that when you enter for the first time, it's a bit hard to navigate exactly where to go (assuming you have tickets already).  Turns out you can use either the stairs or the elevators, but a few more signs would definitely be much appreciated.
author: Jeff A.

description:
A great place to check out whether you live in SF or just dropping by for a few days. You can purchase your tickets online, and use the convenient cloakrooms located on the 1st or 2nd floor to drop off any baggage.

MOMA is a pretty big museum wih 7 floors to go through, so expect to stay at least 2-3 hours here. I personally recommend to take the lift to the 7th floor and start from there and work your way down. Remember to take a MOMA booklet with you to prepare yourself as each floor (even the bathrooms) has something special to offer.
author: Ben C.

description: MoMA is always a treat for photographers and art enthusiasts. As a photographer I can spend an entire day at these exhibits without getting tired of them. Modern art can be hard to appreciate but I think MoMA offers a good spectrum of art that everyone can find something they enjoy.
author: Ian L.

description:
Beautiful! The inside of the building in breath taking, and really adds to the experience of modern art viewing itself.
There are several locations that are constantly changing, and I believe only one location where the exhibit is only available to "members". 
There is a large variation of art/styles; ranging from paintings, sculpture, photography, and even some interactive installations. 
This is absolutely a wonderful outing that needs to happen while you're in the area.
author: Denae L.

description:
World class museum - the art, the building, the mobile application - all of it. My first visit was a wonderful experience and I look forward to returning. Currently contemplating a membership. 

I walked in with high hopes but low expectations. $25/person seemed a little steep. I had eagerly awaited the opening of the new museum to open but thought the price was too high. I now understand why. This museum is on par with the NY MOMA, the Tate, and others.  While the mentioned museums have MORE art, The SF MOMA has similar QUALITY art.

There's the artwork then there's the building itself, which is itself a beautiful piece of design and architecture. It's noteworthy that even the bathrooms are works of art - I felt like the bright red mens room was something out of a Kubrick film.

One of my favorite compliments to the museum is the SFMOMA mobile app. I really enjoyed the audio commentary on many of the art pieces.

Despite the steep price tag, I thought it was well worth it, and I look forward to returning.

I'm also proud that my adopted city has such a high-quality art museum.
author: David S.

description: My favorite modern art museums out of the 10+ I've been to. Beautiful architecture and a changing collection on display
author: Andrew P.

description:
I just got a membership to the SFMOMA. Today I used it to visit the museum for the first time. 
After an extremely frustrating visit I have requested a refund for my membership. 
I do not want to give my hard earned money to a museum that is so unfriendly to seniors. 
Horrible signing. Not enough seating for seniors. I was in exhibits where you were expected to watch a video but had to sit on the floor if you wanted to watch it. 
I wanted to see the Richard Serra on the first floor but couldn't get to it. When I asked at the information desk they told me I had to go out the front door and walk around the building to get there!!! WTF!
I discovered later by myself that there was an elevator right there that the staff knew nothing about and there was NO signage for that elevator either!!
THE NEW SFMOMA DOES NOT WANT SENIORS VISITING!


Sent from my iPhone
author: derik v.

description:
Am I allowed to say that I was a little disappointed?   Because I was.

Well, the positives are that there are some good things here in terms of art.   It offers a nice cross section of modern art.   Also, the new addition is very pretty to look at.

Now on the negatives:

- Price:   $33 to see everything and no student discount (isn't SF already bleeding people dry enough?!?!)

- Rain:   Want to see that fabulous living wall?   Well, I did, and if it is raining don't bother.   Despite the fact that there is a giant overhang outdoors where the living wall resides, and is completely dry, they had a "closed due to rain" sign in front of the door.   Apparently, when you walk through the doors of the MOMA, rain makes you melt or something

-Layout:   The building itself is very difficult to navigate.   Nothing is intuitive.  It is difficult to find the stairs.   The elevators take forever.

- Curators:   no one seems to know what is going on here.   They are very quick to tell you to not carry your backpack on your back, but when you need directions somewhere, they look at you like a deer in the headlights.   Also, many of them had VERY heavy accents that I wasn't able to understand.

- Crowds:   This place does NOT know how to handle crowds.   Upon walking in, it was confusing which lines were for what, and there weren't any employees to clarify.   People kept asking us what line we were in because they didn't know either.

- Lines:   We waited in line for 30 minutes to get our ticket, and then there was another 30 minute long line to wait in to get up to the next floor.   Again, everyone kept coming up to us, asking what line we were in because there was no rhyme or reason to it.   There was no employees telling people where to go.   Once we get to the bottom of the steps there was ONE person checking people's tickets, which is why the line was stretching all the way to Montana.  Once we got up to the fourth floor, there was yet another long ass line to wait in to get into the special exhibit.   There was one employee checking our ticket at the beginning of the line, and then another employee at the end of the line before we were let in doing the same exact thing.   Wouldn't it make more sense to NOT have two people doing the same exact thing when there was a massive need for bodies down on the first floor to deal with the chaos of the crowds??

- Confusion:   The gentleman at the bottom of the steps in the lobby ( you know, the ONE person letting everyone in?) told us that we need to wear our backpack on our front or carry it ONLY in the special exhibit, however, once we got up to the second floor, some gentleman came up to us and told us that we needed to have the backpack in front or carried by hand in the entire museum.   I explained to him that that is not what the gentleman down below told us and that they were not all on the same page as to what the rules were.   Had we known that we were going to have to awkwardly carry a heavy bag with us the entire 3 hours we were there, we would have checked the bag in.   There was also ZERO signage in the lobby stating that "backpacks are not allowed to be carried on the back in the museum" like there are at most other museums....if they were, we sure didn't see them.   The man harassing us about our backpack told us that we were welcome to go back downstairs and check our bag, however that would involve waiting in that atrocious line again to get back into the museum.   Also, we entered an elevator from the second floor to get up to the 4th floor where the special exhibit was, and when we got up to 4th floor, they had all of the elevators blocked.   Apparently they didn't want people coming up THAT way.   Again, a simple "please use the other elevators to get to special exhibit" sign in front of the elevators BEFORE we entered would have been helpful.

As for the special exhibit, there were two artists featured:   Matisse and Deibenkorn.   It was presented in such a way that was supposed to show the influence that Matisse had on Deibenkorn, however, the correlations were a real stretch in most circumstances, and when, I left the exhibit, all I could think was, "ok, so Deibenkorn was a total hack that had no ideas of his own??".   It was weird.


Basically, I am bitching because, out of the 12 or so museums I have been to in the last 5 months, this is by far the most expensive and the most disorganized.   I also felt like the staff only existed to reprimand people and not to actually be helpful to the customers who paid to be there.

Get your shit together MOMA!
author: Christian C.

description:
I absolutely loved visiting the revamped SF MoMA this past weekend, but I am actually super thankful that the 7th floor is currently closed for installation because my husband and I could barely make it through floors 2-6 in time for our energy to just burn out completely.

There are a TON of things to see with loads of nooks and crannies to explore, so if you're simply a casual art enthusiast who can only take in a small handful of exhibits I might recommend you skip the MoMA and go to a gallery elsewhere instead, or perhaps just consider tackling one or two floors here. I'm not sure if that will justify the price to everyone, though - while we were happy to pay the general $25 each since my husband and I are both "over 25" (an interesting question to be asked though I hope you get a discount if you're under 25!), that price may not be right for most who only plan to spend a limited amount of time looking around.

It was amazing to get to see the works of Susan O'Malley, Ellsworth Kelly, and even Andy Warhol in person, though I am not particularly a huge fan of the latter. There was a comprehensive number of different artists on display for each movement in every exhibit, which caused everything to become almost too overwhelming. Our plan of attack was to start on the 6th floor and work our way down, but by the 3rd floor we were in sprint mode, and after exiting the building my husband was ready to leave the city altogether. We certainly plan to come back, and now that we've been here once, we might have more wits about us to tackle it all another way.

Having this resource to view amazing art in San Francisco is, quite honestly, a blessing. Maybe I'm more inclined to look on the bright side than I ever was before, especially after how heartbreaking and trying this week has been, but I'm certainly glad we made it here this past Sunday because if taking in masterpieces from a variety of movements soothes you like it does me, this will be like therapy - and trust me, I know therapy.
author: Emily S.

description:
This place is HUGE. My friend and I did not give ourselves enough time to get through everything. This is an all day trip and given how expensive it is, I would give yourself the time to get your money's worth.

They had interesting, beautiful, and provocative pieces. Highly recommend.
author: Victoria R.

description: Exceptional! When I come to San Francisco, I want to see funky and crazy. SF MOMA definitely gave me what I came for! From Frida Kahlo to a pile of dirt surrounded by mirrors, the MOMA delivered traditional to obscure. I would recommend going early to beat the crowds and enjoy your time through the installations.
author: K S.

description:
I've visited many museums in New York, and this one simply does not compare to its metropolitan counterpart.  Many of the galleries were closed, and made us regret paying to get in.  They've changed their policies on what organization members they give discounts and passes to (if you are in the American Alliance of Museums, you get nothing) so make sure you really want to go here.  

In short, overpriced and filled with art collected by one family, for the most part.
author: Tom T.

description: Of, course, great art. Appreciated flow of galleries and intimate feeling about it.
author: Leslie K.

description:
This is the most impressive modern art museum in the US. Yes, it is much more of an experience than the grand dame MOMA in NYC. Having recently visited both, I can compare directly. MOMA may have more super-expensive paintings, but the galleries are just much less than at SFMOMA. What is especially wacky at MOMA is how much square footage comprises areas not open to museum visitors. A huge pavilion there is an "Education" wing. Which makes no sense, since, unlike the Art Institute in Chicago, MOMA does not run an art college. 

Now for a direct comparison. At SFMOMA, I spent about 5 hours, until I was dead tired, and saw maybe 35% of the galleries. At MOMA, I spent 3.5 hours, and saw every single thing that I thought might be worth seeing. Yes, I did skip stuff that I knew had no interest to me, but still the contrast is huge. There's maybe 4 times as much art to see at SFMOMA, as at MOMA. (In fairness, MOMA is currently--2017--putting on another addition. But I don't have high hopes for this, since they went through a similar hoopla when they opened the Education wing, and that proved to be a zero for the public.). Unlike at MOMA, at SFMOMA, you never get the idea "well they have a lot of space, too bad I can't go in there."

It also should be pointed out that the SFMOMA architecture does make efforts to be artistic. You might say, Well, shouldn't any art museum? No, consider MOMA: the building could be the headquarters of a detergent manufacturer. The original, small building had some modest elegance, but it became engulfed by completely anonymous corporate office complex type of spaces. 

My only reservation with regards to SFMOMA has to do with the food service. Originally, they had a lovely cafe on the ground floor which was an excellent place to grab a good, nutritious lunch. Well, in the expansion it got replaced by one of those Napa Valley restaurants where if you have to ask what something costs, you can't afford it. Crazy high prices, intended for folks who want to have a place where to exhibit their affluence. They did put up a more affordable cafe on the 5th floor however, so there is a place to eat, but it's no longer so easy and convenient.
author: George K.

description: Solid museum with great architecture. Exhibits were interesting, especially one containing German artists. That last sentence is hardly informative, but I assure you it was worth it. Great location here. Enjoy.
author: Sean B.

description:
SFMOMA is modern art at it's finest. What's NOT to love about this place?

It's exceptionally beautiful! I recommend starting at the 7th floor and working your way down.

There are so many cool paintings, pictures, sculptures - and the live wall - let's talk about the live wall. It's amazing! It's gorgeous, it's worth visiting this place just to sit and stare at the live wall alone!

This is the perfect day date for the artist in your life, or even just a really cool way to spend a day alone!
author: Beverly E.

description:
Highly recommended. Perfect rainy day activity too.

I am not quite the artsy person nor really appreciate art works. I was really surprised how much I enjoyed this museum.

We spend approx 2.5hours and only made it through slightly more than half of the exhibits. Definitely a place where you can easily spend the entire day, especially if you take it slow and take a break at one of their cafe options.

I was too excited to get through as many exhibits as I could so we didn't stop at any of their cafes. They have a nice outdoor cafe on the 5th floor and a Sightclass cafe on the 3rd, and a fine dining restaurant on Level 1. The 5th and 3rd floor cafes are only accessible by ticket holders, while the Level 1 restaurant is not.

We brought a backpack along which was not a great idea. They require us to carry the backpack in front or holding it in our hands, my guess was that they wanted to ensure we are not turning and hitting into artwork when it is on our back.

Overall, a really enjoyable museum. Highly recommended activity to do! Look forward to visit again when they have new work :)
author: Cindee T.

description:
So huge! This museum has up to seven floors and could even take the whole day if you include reading and the time you spent on a particular art.

I don't want to spoil what's inside so I'm going to be very vague about this. First, there's a lot of abstract, weird and fun arts. Every section of the room has one open art where you can get very close to the art- even close as 2 millimeters or if you dare go for one, but no touchy touchy~! It's very tempting, but you guys should know we respect these creative modern arts and plus there are securities everywhere, so it's best to behave =p 

Also, on Thursdays there are open to public until 9pm ! Great way to spent your Thursday relaxing and just admiring those artistic creation that was stored in people's mind. 

Second time posting this, accidentally posted On the wrong department XP
author: Hye L.

description:
I suggest that you spend a few hours at the SF MOMA, at least once.  First, the remodel is a great upgrade.  The floor layout and building design made my visit that much better, with plenty of room to circulate between the exhibits.  The staff was very helpful and friendly.

The art is also amazing with a wide range of styles.  While I don't fully appreciate some modern art, most I found to be very interesting and impressive.
author: Dean B.

description: A few keystone pieces make it worth a visit. Rooms are spacious and has a good flow. Free wifi and SFMOMA app are super cool - the geo-location technology is pretty accurate in determining which piece you're in front of and you simply click on the picture for the narrative. Although the collection is not quite at the caliber of the best modern museums in the world, this is still a lovey place to spend the day. You will walk away with a wonderful experience and having learned more about modern art.
author: Puay K.

description: Great museum. Always something to look at. If I'm bored in the city or need something to boost confidence, this is the place to go. Lets me think I'm an intellectual because I'd like to think I'm always right about the meaning of the artwork. If someone ever says I'm not, they can go back to looking at classical.
author: Ernest M.

description:
This is a world class museum that rivals other contemporary art museums in the US like the MoMA in NYC and the MCA in Chicago.

I had been waiting for SFMOMA to reopen for over two years. And the wait may have been worth it. Not only is the 7 story building a work of art in its own right, the treasures inside did not disappoint.

I spent around two hours here on a Friday afternoon and it was barely enough time to see everything.

Highlights for me include the Calder sculpture garden with adjacent gallery of Calder works, an impressive collection of works by Warhol and Close, plus an exhibit dedicated to communication devices, from the typewriter to the iPhone. The rooftop decks offer fantastic view of downtown (that gorgeous Art Deco building is Yelp HQ). It's kinda weird to say, but even the restrooms had a comforting aesthetic that was unlike anything I've experienced.

If museums are your thing, SFMOMA will not disappoint. Well worth the $25 admission.
author: Will S.

description:
I love the idea of spending my afternoon in great museums and art museums happen to be my favorite! This, however, happened to be my first one featuring modern art and it was freshly reopened after a massive expansion. 

Two pieces of advice that enhanced my experience:
- Take the elevator to the top then make your way down SEVEN FLOORS of exhibits. Everyone is moving in the opposite direction and climbing seven steps of stairs may be a great pain to some.
- Allot yourself two hours or more to explore this place because it is HUGE! Two hours isn't even enough to take everything in if I'm being honest

Ticketing/Parking Logistics:
Ticket process works so that you buy for a certain time slot so that they don't overcrowd the museum (there are TONS of people). Teens and under get in for free while adults have to pay. You can do this online and definitely in advanced, earlier in the day. Parking can be crazy since it's in the busy Powell area. We decided on just parking at the Metreon and walking a few blocks.

Some of my favorite pieces/exhibits:
- Their LIVING WALL. A huge and beautiful plant wall projected to be the largest of its kind in SF
- Andy Warhol section: loved National Velvet featuring Elizabeth Taylor
- Oculus Bridge: my knees wobbled just seeing down through the grates at the floors below
- Neon Lights exhibit: especially this piece by Dan Flavin that gave me Hotline Bling vibes haha. They also had these blinking neon light signs, including the inverted America sign I've seen on Instagram before
- Pop Art exhibit: includes a really cool Lichtenstein and is where you'll find the Warhol section
- Alexander Calder Motion Lab: a room full of beautiful mobiles and intricate pieces

There's plenty to discover here for everyone since it encompasses painting, photography, sculpture, performance art, film that it even warrants multiple trips! For instance, I walked into this place blind about what it included and found out later that I missed a work by Frida Kahlo, one of my all time favorite artists. Honestly, I cannot wait to go again and fill in the gaps of my first experience or see some new exhibits!
author: Rene B.

description:
How can you not give SFMOMA 5 stars? The remodeled museum is humongous (7 stories and 7 miles long, a guard informed us) and filled with a broad range of modern art - surely something to interest even the pickiest or most apathetic museum-goers.

If you're ambitious enough to conquer it all in one go, give your mind and back a break at the cafe or Sightglass coffee shop.

Much thought was put into making a great experience: easy advanced booking, friendly staff, wifi, charging stations, and a free app with additional information and audio tours (plus cool features like location tracking and syncing the audio with your friends).

It's open late on Thursdays and likely less crowded than on the weekends.

Even if you're not going to buy anything, definitely swing by the gift shop (the bigger one is on the ground level) - lots of fun, interesting things that would make great gifts.
author: Cristina S.

description: It you really need to kill sometime in SF, give or take a couple hours. This is a place to consider, I was amazed at what is considered "art" these days. They had some good pieces from Picasso to Andy Warhol and I did like the German exhibit, but then there were some questionable pieces that had no place. Like a mirror with a pile of dirt on it.
author: Joseph L.

description:
MoMa is back with a vengeance. After impatiently watching the re-model go on for the past few years, it's so good to be able to see their exhibits again. Even better, there is SO much more to see! Don't fool yourself into thinking you can see the whole museum in a day. One or two floors at most is enough to keep you absorbed for an afternoon. My personal favorites are the brilliant Abstract works in the Fisher collection. But really, you can't go wrong on any of the floors.

Stop for a coffee/tea/wine/beer in their cafe area, and take it all in nice and slow.
author: Jon T.

description:
I first visit SFMOMA in 2012 as a UC Davis student, checking out an exhibit related to my Asian American studies coursework. I've loved the museum ever since! I went a few more times before the remodel and fondly remember enjoying a slice of the famed (though no longer available) Piet Mondrian cake. I finally went back in May to see the newly reopened MOMA (thanks to Michelle N. for the member's freebie!). It did not disappoint! Being a coffee shop bopper, I also love the addition of Sightglass Coffee, but do miss Blue Bottle's rooftop outpost. 

The Snohetta designed entry is a fitting welcome to the museum. Don't miss the walkway to get a view from the top. Love the outdoor spaces as well. When I visited, they had a Calder exhibit which is fantastic. You will see lots of great work, from Matisse, Rothko, Van Gogh, Kahlo, a wide-ranging photography exhibit and even a room dedicated to UC Davis art faculty contributions (go Aggies! go Wayne Thiebaud!). I recommend dedicating a few hours of your day to take it all in and fully explore. It's also very social media friendly, which is apparent when you check out the #newsfmoma tag on IG. So, get your camera out (or not), hop on BART, and get ready for a day of artwork, exploration, and inspiration.
author: Edwina D.

description:
An impressive gallery. Very impressive architecture. Impressive collection of art. .

MOMA is a lot bigger than I thought it was going to be. Spanning over 7 levels, this is a whole day venture and worth the entry price. To save time at the door, order your tickets online to get in fast. 

Start your way from the top to the bottom. It works easier as there are lines waiting to get into the elevators. Go with the flow of the building leading you from the unusual to more contemporary pieces. 

If you want to see the fame like Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein, you will find it here. Love the UC Davis & Chuck Close pieces. All very well laid out and chosen to compliment eachother as you walk through the levels. Very well curated. 

But what captures my attention are pieces by lesser known artists and experimental mediums. In particular, there was an exhibit that displayed a large metallic 3D silver ball on the 7th floor. You walk into a small room with a strobe and you are confronted with what looks like a lucid metallic ball. You can walk around it and watch the ripples move as if you dipped your finger in a glass of water. It was fascinating and not like anything I have seen before. By far my favourite in the museum. So much so, my partner and I went back a couple of times to see it again. My only regret is that I did not take note of the artist name. So much talent! Very much the future of art. 

I did also love the living green wall. What a beautiful idea! I would love that on the side of my home. Check out the the gift store, they have designed a green living coffee table. Lovely! Also this gift store has a lot to offer and very well priced.
author: Anita D.

description: Expensive! But worth it, particularly when they have awesome special exhibits like Matisse. There are NO discounts for teachers or AAA, my two go-to discounts, so keep that in mind. They have a young person discount but I don't think I can pass for 18-24 anymore, so I didn't try it. The 7th floor is currently under construction until mid-July 2017. I suggest starting at the top and going down. if it's not too chilly, check out the living wall and the cafe. I would highly recommend this Museum to anyone in the vicinity of the Bay.
author: Samir K.

description:
The building is incredible. Is is a beautiful space to display art and to spend a few hours. 
There are truly a few world class pieces of art here! I particularly adored the Chuck Close, Andy Warhol and G Richter pieces.
But....... there are more than a few that make me wonder and question the definition of art. 
Seriously folks, a bag of cat liter is not art. 
A dirty blanket with filthy stuff animals on it is not art!  A t shirt that has the words print on it "blow me" is not art
Were these there to make me question the definition of art?
author: J C.

description: SFMoMa, I love what you've done to the place. The museum is just as gorgeous as ever. It was a long wait, but it was completely worth it. The museum feels more spacious and they moved the ticket counters inside. I came here over the weekend for the Diane Arbus exhibit and it wasn't too crowded. Also on the third floor, they have a cafe with Sightglass coffee.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
I Go to MoMA NY on the regular, and I have to say SFMoMA is giving MoMANY a good run for its money. 

It is spectacular. And I feel very fortunate to have gotten the chance to visit during my short SF visit. Completely worth it.

It is 7 floors. Building itself is modern and beautiful. Love their use of light and Windows. The pieces remind me of some in NY - meaning same vibe, not in mirror image. It's edgy, colorful, and spirited.

Came Saturday afternoon, and it was way crowded. Need to try to make another trip back on a weekday.
author: Heidi C.

description:
Fantastic, thought-provoking work -- there is a deep variety of exhibits that stimulate visually, aurally, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually. And when you don't understand a piece at all, it's totally acceptable to poke fun at it if you're there with a sarcastic friend. But keep an open mind!

The architecture of the renovated SFMOMA is spectacular, designed by Snøhetta (the company that designed the 9/11 Memorial in New York as well as the Times Square reconstruction). A pure, layered angled-cruiseship look that is out of the ordinary but still so pleasing to the eye. My favorite exhibit was Alexander Calder's hanging mobile structures. Simple, beautiful, balanced pieces. Don't miss it! 

Vast wall pieces make for great photo ops, and there's even a living wall outside on the 3rd floor. There are outdoor patios on a few of the floors, with a Sightglass coffee on 3rd, which makes for a nice break from the long hours of standing and shuffling. 

Tip #1: Be prepared for at least 3 hours at SFMOMA if you want to see everything. I spent 2+ hours there and there were still 2 floors I barely explored. Don't be afraid to take a break (or two, or many)! Cafe 5 is the best place to relax. 

Tip #2: Check out the museum shop! Lots of design, art, and SF-related books, apparel, and random fun accessories and household items. Truly a delight to look through!
author: Christine L.

description:
I can skip to this museum from my home/office in ten minutes flat, so I've adopted it as my extended living room and personal cathedral for inspiration.
