You can make art without inspiration, and a good artist must learn this. But it's also possible to live in a state of constant creative arousal. SFMOMA can help. It makes a difference to do your writing while sitting beside an 8-foot expressionist painting. It just does.

Here's how to write while sitting near art in a museum gallery:
1. Check as much of your stuff--purse, coat, etc.--as possible so you can be light and free-handed. A notebook and pen is really all you need.
2. Sit and contemplate the art.
3. Sketch the art.
4. Describe the art.
5. How does the art make you feel? Write about this.
6. Does the art remind you of anything? Write it out, the whole story.

In my previous review of SFMOMA, I offered thorough instructions for the wandering writer, including writing tips for both cafes, what to do if you didn't bring writing materials, and several pieces of art close enough to a bench for you to sit and write within glance-shot in the galleries.

But reading back, I'm ashamed to note that in the review I failed to feature even one piece of art created by a woman. I was inattentive, proving to myself that even if you're a feminist, even if the art museum is modern, the default is always men.

So, for Women's History Month, I give you 8 inspiring women artists with work located near benches on which to write or sketch at SFMOMA:

Second floor:
Look for Mathilde Vollmoeller-Purrmann's "Still Life with Fruit" near the red elevators. The placard says Vollmoeller-Purrmann's friends described her as "deadly serious" and said she "worked at a white heat." 

Continue to the bench in the "North and South of the Border" gallery, where you can admire Frida Kahlo's "Wedding Portrait," Georgia O'Keefe's "Black Place I," and Dorothea Tanning's "Self Portrait." This is a sedate, contemplative, and visually luxurious room in which to write.

The room with the Rothko has a fine bench facing his famous and impressive painting, but if you sit on the short end of the bench, you can write instead under the influence of Joan Mitchell, facing the large-format "Untitled" textured knot of rich blues and reds or glancing right for the smaller canvas by the door, perhaps a more pleasing distance for viewing her chaotic tangles of color. 

Third floor:
Now through 4/30/17, you can see the spectacular Diane Arbus exhibition. There are benches in these galleries, but they are all too far away from the small photographs to really be able to sit and write and glance up now and then for inspiration.

But take a walk through this show, even if you're here to write. If you feel like sitting down with the photos for some writing, follow the galleries to the very last room, where there's a nice big table with the several copies of the show catalog for your reference.

Fourth floor: 
Head down the long hallway to the farthest-back room, where you'll find the Agnes Martins. It's audacious for these paintings to hang in a museum, at least that's what museum goer reactions tell you. "It's just a grid," I hear people whispering to each other while I write in this room. But I love writing surrounded by these paintings.  

Sixth floor: 
Sit down on one of the hallway benches, where you can write in the shadow of Beverly Pepper's "Tarquinia Cone Column." Made of iron, it looks like a big rusty pen--the very picture of a focused writer.

Here's the thing. You are a beautiful genius. You have stories to tell and points to make, but all that stuff inside you needs lubricant if it's going to move out of you and into the world with ease and pleasure. Inspiration makes good lubrication, so exposing yourself to art while you create your own art will make writing easier and more natural.
author: Kristy L.

description: Always a joy coming here, got lucky and found a parking spot right out front this time. Would recommend coming on a tuesday it was very mellow.
author: Beatrice J.

description:
Was $19 worth it for these 7 floors? Hmm perhaps. I'd be more satisfied if SF parking wasn't so horrendous. You can park at the garage behind for a mere $26-28 (I forget) or the Moscone center for less. However, we lost our parking ticket and had to pay $29 anyways (that's after spending 30 minutes driving in circles trying to look for parking)- what a damper.

Best decision to go to the top and work our way down. We found the pieces at the top to be more engaging and fun than the ones at the bottom- but maybe because we were super tired and hungry by then. The museum strategically places a restaurant and cafe after some few floors but the lines seemed way too long for us to want to bear standing in.

Each floor is huuuge... it was a little confusing to figure out the best route to traverse through each floor since the weekends was way crowded with people going in all different directions. Every time we thought we were done with a floor there seemed to be another turn. Not a bad thing though because I love looking at art- however wasn't impressed with some of the pieces (but what do I know anyways). And I somehow missed the wooden maze circles? Tbh after a few floors I was just hungry and tired of walking... but had to push through due to hourly parking and the promise of food at the end.

Definitely recommend this place to all the art hoes out there. Come early so you can stay as long as you want and enjoy! But definitely eat before, speaking from experience.
author: Crystal N.

description:
Well did the tour today, my partner is from New York. We were both underwhelmed, very little thot provoking, nothing extrodinary. So at 25$ per, step it up, this is SF. We expect more, use the space, show some art. Should be more than 45 minutes of photos. Love art!
Steve s
author: Steve S.

description: Haven't been to SF MOMA for years. First day of reopening day justified a return. We were also fortunate to score some free tickets. However, paying for admission is well worth it. This place is huge. It took a good chunk of our day to complete this beast.
author: Gene B.

description:
Visiting San Francisco's new MOMA after seeing it in several earlier iterations is akin to watching that little neighbor kid grow up.  You knew him when, saw him through the awkward years, watched him grow into a shy young man, then suddenly he's abloom with confidence, a king of the world.  If you failed to visit MOMA when it was located at the Civic Center or prior to its closure a few years ago you have no idea of the significance of this transformation.  You'll just be drinking in the beauty that is now the largest modern art museum in America, appreciating the fact that there's more than enough here to keep you enthralled for more than one visit.  

The rest of us though?  We'll be marveling at this, certainly, but also at the cultural significance of San Francisco becoming a destination-worthy museum city.  That's a novel twist and a distinction we've not previously enjoyed.  What it says, I'll leave for cultural anthropologists and historians to discern but if I were to put it into my own words it would be something like this:  San Francisco has arrived.

And that's from someone who has long believed that San Francisco led the pack in so many, many categories.  

Thanks to the vast expansion and the inclusion of an ongoing, significant portion of the Fisher Collection (of Gap fame and $$$), the new MOMA is now being spoken of in the same breath as NYC's MOMA and London's Tate Modern.  The Fishers lobbied hard to keep their collection in San Francisco, hoping for a dedicated museum within the Presidio.  When that plan failed other cities were eager to compete for the opportunity to house this collection leaving San Francisco politicos scrambling.  The new MOMA is the result of this scrambling and it might restore your faith in city government.  

The new MOMA is 7 floors of art (2.5 times its previous size) and 2 museum shops.  It's a couple of cafes, one with outdoor seating and Sightglass coffee served in Heath ceramics.  It's a restaurant (coming in June) overseen by a chef with 3-Michelin star credentials.  It's also home to the world's largest living wall in the U.S.  It's oh so many things but it's really about the art, this collection, in this gorgeous, mostly new space.  

Visiting the museum has half inspired me to pen a thank you letter to the departed Fishers and the San Franciscans who saw a way then made it happen.  Let this suffice.  If you enjoy art and museums don't miss the rebirth/reincarnation of San Francisco's newest baby.  

And to think, I knew him when...
author: Tracey A.

description:
Forget Captain America or Star Wars... the new SFMOMA is this year's definitive summer blockbuster! 

The new museum is not so much a sequel as it is a reboot (kind of like what they did with the Daniel Craig/James Bond movies). And you know what? It totally works!

I'll be the first to admit that I'm no modern art aficionado. I could probably count on one hand the names and works of the artists on display. But that's what makes this museum so cool. Despite its regal setting and fancy architecture/interior, it's refreshingly unpretentious. This ain't your daddy's old, stuffy museum. This is a place for kids of all ages to come and experience an inspiring feast for the eyes and mind.

Be sure to wear comfortable walking shoes, because seven floors can eventually exhaust even the most avid art fan. 

If you're hungry or thirsty, they have a wonderful cafe on the 4th floor (featuring sandwiches, pastries, and Illy Coffee) with outdoor seating. Prices were surprisingly reasonable.
Make sure you take a few minutes to check out the verdant moss garden growing on the museum walls (I believe it's on the 3rd floor). This will impress any plant lover!

There's no question about it - the new & improved SFMOMA is a cultural destination. And I have no doubt that it will succeed in putting San Francisco right up there with Paris and New York as having one of the greatest modern museums in the world.

** Bonus - kids under 18 don't have to pay admission!
author: Kevin B.

description:
It's a world class museum, yup.  It cost more than the overpriced NYC museums which is annoying.  Im an artist and appreciate art and support the arts whenever I can but I really find it sad that prices like this that are needed to pay for renovations etc, are prohibitive and keep the audience limited to certain demographics and levels of income.  Discounts for the elderly and students are not impressive enough to make much difference also.  Because I wanted to see the Diebenkorn paintings which are featured this month, I had to pay a bit extra so it was $31 instead of the usual $25.  It's likely museums will be closer to $50 by ten years time, huh?
Yeah, I hope our country can find ways to support great institutions like this so finances don't limit the audience.

The museum is beautiful and I really love it... y'know, other than the price.
author: Mike G.

description: As someone who loves modern art, I had a wonderful time visiting this museum! The layout is well thought out, so visitors don't feel crowded or overwhelmed. Various incredible pieces by Munch, Lichtenstein, Warhol, Matisse, Rivera, and many others. You could spend a whole afternoon admiring the paintings here. It's a great place to stop into while in SF.
author: Nicole C.

description: Ehh it was pretty great to see all the art. The place is very clean and well lit and there's actually lots of benches and window seats for kids to sit if they're bored or tired. I came here with my friends on a Sunday and it wasn't that busy and I'm still really happy I got in for free (free if you're a teenage with SF residential ID!). There was even a Norwegian choir singing a free performance that day! Sadly the sculpture exhibits weren't open ( :( ) but the paintings were spectacular! It was a little boring on the first few floors where the only art was just lines on a canvas and paint splatters but I included pictures of my favorite paintings!
author: Morgan N.

description:
Gorgeous remodel. The wall garden is a must see. You can spend the entire day here and it's set-up for you to do just that, serving Sight Glass coffee (YUM!), snacks, and a proper sit-down on one of the many floors (have no clue which one, the place is big). 

7 floors in-all, unfortunately we arrived at 3:30pm (on a Saturday), and only had 1.5 hours to explore. Got through Floors 6 and 5. Assuming you spend at least 30 minutes per floor, give yourself at least 3 hours.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: They close at five on weekends? No wonder clientele all seems to be from the Geritol set. Fuck this small- town three-room art museum bullshit.
author: Patrick M.

description: So much art, such little time. Also, if you're 24 years young you still count as a "young adult" and get $5 off your ticket! Definitely a half-to-all-day experience. We spent 3 hours here and easily could have spent more! Also, if you want a good laugh check out the video rooms for an extra "what the heck is happening here" experience. Err, I mean a "wow what creativity" type of experience!
author: Afton N.

description: Today was the first time we have visit to moma and it did not disappoint. The museum itself is beautifully designed and the Magritte exhibit was incredible! Would definitely visit again given the opportunity!
author: Amelie B.

description:
Modern art is something that I think is very polarizing. You either love it or hate it. I, personally, pretend to love it because I think it makes me fancy but in reality I don't get it most of the time. That's why I always get the audio tour when I go to museums so somebody else can tell me what I'm supposed to think. I think as a museum I would only give this MOMA 4/5. Other MOMAs I've been to have more impressive and interesting collections (eg. Chicago and New York). But, the SFMOMA app is so impressive and smart I think SFMOMA deserves an extra star. 

It's weird to rate a museum based on an app but I honestly think it improved my experience so much. The GPS mapping is very accurate and the guided walks are very fun. Having an app that knows what's nearby is 100x better than reading a number on a plaque and entering it into an ancient device that weighs several pounds. Unfortunately, the app is only available on iOS so if you don't have an Apple device you have to purchase the audio tour, which is basically the app on an iPod, for $6. There are many cool features of the app like being able to take pictures and email the timeline of your MOMA experience to yourself; I think it's definitely worth it. The device battery doesn't last very long though but you can trade it in when it dies. If you're using the timeline be sure to email yourself before it dies because otherwise all your memories will be lost!

I did almost all the guided walks on the app and my favourites are: "I don't get it" and the one about Germany. I didn't really like the ESPN one but I'm not that into sports. The second floor had my favourite exhibits. I also had an oatmeal cherry cookie from the cafe on the 3rd floor and it was quite yummy.
We spent 5 hours here and still didn't even make it to the 7th (top) floor! I would come on Thursday if you can since they're open for an extra 4 hours. 

Also if you're 19-24 you are considered a "young adult" and tickets are $6 less than the regular adult price. Admission is free for teens and children. The tickets do have a time you're allowed to enter if you buy them online but I'm not sure how strict they are about it.

Overall, I had a great day at SFMOMA and will have to come back to see the rest!
author: Jenny L.

description:
I had never been to SFMOMA before its recent remodel. My first experience with the museum was figuring out how to gift a membership to a friend before it even opened. Shout-out to Anna in the membership department for helping me make this happen on such a short notice!

About a month after it opened, I went to visit with a friend and was shocked by how much there was to see! So much cool stuff! I could only stay for about two hours before becoming overwhelmed. The price of a day pass is totally worth it, and I would consider buying a membership just to see all the art that I didn't get a chance to see the first time. Plus there were a few exhibits not yet opened.

When you're planning your trip to SFMOMA, buy your tickets in advance and avoid the lines. I feel that the membership department has mastered the optimal price levels and membership benefits. Totally worthwhile. Makes a great gift too!
author: Stefanie C.

description: Today I am enjoying the Anthony Hernandez photography and Bruce Conner's assemblage and collage exhibits.  A visit to this museum is always an inspiring and thought provoking.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Awesome! Loved it. Near HRD, too. Went for the Mastisse exhibit. Was really great!
author: Erin J.

description:
"PUT AWAY YOUR WATER BOTTLE PLEASE."

This was the first thing that was barked at me when I walked through the museum doors. I definitely expected a warmer welcome and feel bad for those who are visiting SF or even California for their first time and had to be greeted in that way.

Other than that, everything else was great and well managed. The layout and floor plan of the museum was well designed so I wasn't running around in circles trying to figure out if I had covered each of the galleries.
author: Winnie Y.

description:
Wow! Since I decided to join SFMoma we got preview tix. Oh how we've missed you, MoMa, but you came back bigger, brighter and bolder than ever. As with the opening of the DeYoung, I was almost brought to tears....now we have another world class museum. Truly spectacular and worth waiting for!

My deepest admiration goes out to all who worked so hard and for so long to bring this to us locals, and to visitors to our fair city!
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Timing is everything. I happened to fly into SF on Wednesday evening and spent Thursday roaming this wonderful museum--bonus, they are open until late on Thursdays!

I spent hours upon hours just roaming each floor and marveling at the talent. I also marveled at different kinds of art--things I wouldn't think were art, family guy jokes of art, but all still art. Some of the photographs brought me to tears. 

I appreciated that there is a  Sight Glass inside as well as a restaurant so I was able to refuel and keep going. 

Bonus, 4 hours free wifi!
author: Melissa K.

description:
Great spot for a daytime hangout. 

I'd recommend coming here on a weekday to avoid the weekend rush. The artwork here is so unique and interesting. With 7 floors of art, there's plenty to see. The security is tight here, which I've expected at a museum anyways. 

They also have a restaurant and cafe here, which are a little pricey. Unless you want to treat yourself to a fancy meal at In Situ, I'd skip the cafe and eat elsewhere.
author: Helen C.

description:
My boyfriend was able to buy membership at a discounted rate, but even without it, $100 for the individual rate is a steal if you are an art lover or have friends frequently visiting the Bay. Membership grants unlimited free admission plus a guest, including special exhibitions! Single tickets are $25, which is already equivalent of 4 visits. 

The new museum renovation is beautiful. It has that new home feeling because everything looks shiny. With the expansion, the exhibits almost seem endless. The large vertical garden is gorgeous, although I wish more light came into the area. Overall, Snøhetta Architects did a wonderful job bringing life to a once stagnant museum. 

Make sure to visit the Richard Serra sculptures (my personal favorite), the Alexander Calder motion lab (the largest Calder collection I've seen in one room until 9/10/16), Typeface to Interface (until 10/23/16), and Pop, Minimal, and Figurative Art (with big names such as Chuck Close, Roy Lichtenstein, and Andy Warhol).

Reserve the whole day or get membership to visit as often as you want.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Add my name to the long list of fans waiting for the New SF MOMA to open. Ta da!
The best tip we got was start at the top and work your way down.  7 th floor Fabulous!

We did the abbreviated tour ( get a program and find Directors Picks) a smattering of Warhol, Ellsworth Kelly, Diane Arbus...
We had a Wonderful lunch - Rainbow Salad ( not the same as Burma Star - don't get excited) and it was superb. Huge bowl of fresh greens, very lightly dressed, shavings of blanched vegetables,
Best gift shop and tres cher.
author: Laurel G.

description:
I gotta say-- I've been to a LOT of art museums in my short lifetime, and while SFMOMA certainly doesn't have the best art collection out of the ones I've been to, they certainly know how to make the experience of an art museum easy and carefree. If you live in the city, the membership fee is also MOST DEFINITELY worth it as you can bring a friend for free (or if you're like me, and have a significant other-- you can bring two other people for free. If your partner somehow can't make it, you can go solo and bring THREE people with your membership,) and KIDS UNDER 18 ARE FREE! I don't really know anyone with kids or anyone who's under 18, but that's a pretty good deal. (I wonder if I can still pass as under 18.....)

There are 7 overwhelmingly large floors of art, and because it's been closed for three or four years at this point, our visits were crowded and kind of exhausting, to be frank. That may have ruined the experience of modern art for us. However, they do have a Sightglass on the 3rd floor, as well as a cafe/more casual eatery on the 5th adjacent to the Sculpture Garden, which is a little more affordably priced than In Situ, on the first floor (I'll write about that in a separate review though.) They have lots of space and cool exhibitions-- I can see this serving as a pretty nice place to study a bit too, as they have tables and couches around everywhere. 

The more 'fun' exhibits were the interactive ones-- like the HUGE giant sculptures such as Serra's Sequence which dominates the ground floor. There's also lots of public space to sit and relax amongst the art. 

SFMOMA has an extensive collection of works-- though not what I expected-- this is definitely worth the membership for the interactive people spaces. I am looking forward to the different exhibitions once they start rotating.
author: Christa Lei S.

description: Just went to the MOMA of SF today and had an amazing time. We spent about 3 hours here taking our time to look around and take everything in. There was so many wonderful art to see and observe. I'm 19 years old and my tickets was only $19, such a great deal! The parking garage is $4 per 30 minutes, it wasn't too bad. The only bad thing I have to say is that the 7th floor is currently closed off, but we'll definitely be back to explore that floor!
author: Roxana M.

description: I have been waiting for MOMA to reopen for while now and finally got the chance to visit two weeks ago! I loved everything about it from the pieces, to the architecture of the whole building. I have been to other major art museums, and what I liked about MOMA is that it had the perfect amount of art work. Not too little that you feel you didn't get your money's worth nor too much that it is overwhelming and you don't know where to start. Although there are a few nude pieces, this place is great for kids. Parking may be hard to find, it's best to either take über or public transportation. Gift shop is a bit pricey, but still neat to check out.
author: Christina P.

description: Visited the MOMA on my birthday. What a great museum. Andy Warhol exhibit and Calder. Wow! Amazing experience.
author: Just M.

description: I met with a girlfriend while I was in town. I have not been back in years. I loved the new floors added and the space after the reopening. It is beautiful, spacious and lots of exhibits to see! We bought our tix online to see the Matisse exhibit, exclusive to SF MoMa. It was a fun time and so glad we had an impromptu get together here. I took lots of photos on my recent visit two weeks ago.
author: Mika D.

description:
The art in this museum is so compelling, so provocative, and so beautiful. The seven floors of art can only be explored slowly, so make sure to give yourself at least three hours to explore! Children 18 years and younger are allowed in the museum for free (even to explore the special exhibit!). 
Phones are allowed in most galleries except where signs are posted explicitly stating they are not allowed.  
I love how this museum combines both interactive elements with purely spectator artwork. 
Giving this wonderful gem a 5 star rating!!! Go check it out!
author: Melodie D.

description:
I don't know where to begin. The entire building is a work of art. It's almost like it's breathing. The space is so grand, so thought out, so inviting that I could spend days wandering through the different wings/galleries. 

If you live in SF, definitely get the Membership. It's essentially worth it after 2-3 visits - which I could do in a matter of days. If you want to explore but don't necessarily want to see the whole museum, explore Richard Serra's installation - which is a lot of fun to walk through.
author: Alex L.

description:
My company gave me 2 free tickets to SF MoMA for the reopening. I spent a sunny Tuesday afternoon strolling through this gorgeous building surrounded by art, light, creativity, and color. 

I enjoyed taking the stairs further up and up, stopping at each and every open outdoor space on the way. The living wall, despite being filled with people, was a serene experience of sun, greenery and the gentlest breeze. This is just one of the prettiest and most peaceful spaces in San Francisco.

Wayne Thiebaud has been influential to me as an artist. I was excited to see 2 of his paintings on display and spent a considerable time enjoying taking in his nuanced use of color. 

For all the type nerds out there: Typeface to Interface is lovely, especially the custom typeface and identity for the museum. I spent time pouring over the history of graphic design and how it's changed with technology advancements. Really enjoyable! 

And of course, there is the light-filled bridge leading to the sculpture garden on the 5th floor. This has always been a sacred place to me. It was so moving to revisit this space after so much time has passed. I was filled with joy and contentment from my experience. 

When you visit (which you definitely should!) be sure to give yourself enough time to aimlessly wander and take in the beauty of each curated space, work of art, and plaque.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
This place evokes more questions than answers - "what is art?".

I do not have the definition of what art is.  Bill Evans once said "art should enrich the soul", and I am in agreement.  Evoking question is a cerebral response, not an enrichment of soul.  So, modern or not, to my eyes and soul, most items exhibited are not worthy of art.

The newly added section could use escalators.  
Because: 
(a) it is not practical to take an elevator, which there are many of, from one floor to the next, up or down;
(b) climbing stairs gets tiring when there are seven floors

Also, they should have allocated paid (they can charge market rate) parking spaces for handicapped.  Seven stories and no parking, how inconvenient is that?
author: Wesley S.

description:
I visited SFMOMA in 2012, ahead of their planned building expansion, and I remember the smaller, darker galleries. The art was still amazing and impressive (I'm looking at you, Number 14 by Rothko). Fast-forward to 2016--gone are the small dark galleries, and instead you'll find a beautiful building that allows natural light to enter the galleries, and enhance your art-viewing experience. 

There is so much to see, so I suggest starting at the top and working your way down. Take time to stop at Cafe 5 on the fifth floor for wine and snack. The Fisher Collection, donated by Doris and Donald Fisher (aka the founders of Gap) is impressive and sections are on view on many floors. I also enjoyed The Campaign for Art: Contemporary, which showcased contemporary works collected by the Museum, as this exhibition showed a much more diverse group of artists from the Museum's collection.

All in all, if you are visiting San Francisco, or if you live there and haven't been in a while, the new building is a must see, along with the storied collection inside. Spend an afternoon getting cultured--I'm sure you'll enjoy it!
author: Chey H.

description: I  renewed my membership with trepidation. Last time I was there after remodel I wasn't that impressed. I still believe they can add more Latin artist, female artist, current artist. It is a very Eurocentric male dominate museum but hey these crazy cats are the the only artist you read about in Art History 101 textbooks. And since we are still debating "Columbus Day" I don't think this ship is gonna turn around any time soon. So this time there was an "Edward Munch" exhibit, the fellow that did the "Scream" BTW it is not on display must be in Oslo,Norway. But not to worry his art was prolific for 19th century & his paintings are very biographical which are intriguing enough to sustain a viewers attention. More about the museum, I was there for 4 hrs. on Thursday it is open til 9pm, that's my style. 6 floors packed with modern art. A terrace with live plant wall, nice when you need fresh air but the museum is very spacious unless you're in a special exhibit,more crowded. A coffee area, a cafe for casual food(closed for private party)an over priced Michelin rated restaurant on the first floor, but that will be reviewed next. So in closing can't beat the atmosphere, culture, etc. What I do recommend is bring comfy shoes, a snack just in case, water. It's $25 entrance but membership has it privileges & if you have a Bank of America card first Sunday's are free.
author: Susan S.

description:
Beautiful exhibits and amazing lighting! This 7 story museum is enormous and every floor displays a huge variety of artwork. The architecture is sleek, the employees are polite, and every angle in this building had amazing lighting. I thought the bridge on the 5th floor, the grass wall on the second floor, and all the dark rooms were stunning. 

My girlfriend and I spent around two hours exploring the museum. Id recommend starting at the 7th floor and making your way down the stairs till the bottom. Happy exploring!
author: David H.

description:
PSA:  Don't wear heeled boots to this art gallery two days after leg day!

Let me just tell y'all... By the end of my trip, I was in literal tears (either from the excruciating pain I endured from working out my legs the day before or from the internal emotions I experienced looking at the amazing artwork displayed). There are 7 floors to the gallery, and of course, you can either utilize the stairs or elevators to get to each one. Be aware, the elevators get packed quickly due to the amount of traffic this place gets. (I can definitely see why--it's a must-see if you're ever in the city!)

I would say the most memorable artwork I viewed was "Melter 3-D" by Takeshi Murata... Super fascinating zoetrope, that looks like it's actually melting.
author: Nhu-y P.

description:
Beautiful museum!!! It's huge, and there's so much to look at. I had heard great things about the new moma from multiple people but never really paid much attention to this museum. One day, a friend who had season passes offered to take me, and off we went!

I was only here for an hour (!!!) but managed to cram as much in as possible. There's honestly so much to look at that I've already added this back on my revisit list. I think this museum needs a few hours to truly appreciate everything in it.

Can't wait to come back!
author: Michelle N.

description:
What makes good Modern Art and what makes bad Modern Art?  Modern Art definitely invites criticism. Therefore I want to point out some flaws of some of the exhibits. Starting with the rusty pipe statue on Level 3. I was wondering if the pieces of red gum stuck inside the pipe are part of the artists intent or was some kid so upset that the best exhibit in the place was some hanging rusty pipes  therefore stuck his chewing gum all over it.   A sentence with an incomplete set of quotation marks leaves you wondering if this was an intentional  mistake, and again with modern art you just never know.  The most distasteful peace was probably the c***** p****, a nude photo of 14 year old Brooke Shields standing in a provocative manner. 

 My favorite forms of Modern Art are surrealism and comic art which I felt there are very few examples of these at SFMOMA.
author: Ryan S.

description: I love the space of this building. It's light and airy and has little nooks and crannies for a bit of quiet now and then. I went for the Matisse exhibit (and was disappointed at the relatively small collection of Matisse and the overabundance of the Diebenkorn (in my opinion), However, I was impressed by the other exhibits of sculpture and digital media. It helped that while I was in line I was given a free ticket as a generous benefactor had donated them. Otherwise, admission would have been $31, which is still a fair price to pay for this gem.
author: JoAnn Y.

description:
While this museum doesn't have quite as many jaw dropping famous works that everybody recognizes as it's NYC counter part, it does have a vast collection of thought provoking exhibits that put it on par with lots of the great museums around the world.

It's been a long time since I last visited SFMOMA, so I can't speak about the changes quite as extensively as someone who comes to the space more often than I. What I can say is that it is a beautiful space that is filled with light and easy to navigate around.

Each of the floors has one or two exhibits so you never feel like there are too many things you're trying to look at in a space. Some museums seem to cram as much art as possible into a room and you're stuck with huge crowds all competing to look at the art. Here, everything is grouped thematically with usually just one or two artists work in a room. The space gives viewers the opportunity to stand and actually absorb a painting or sculpture, and look at it from different angles without jostling through a huge crowd.

There are some pieces that are clearly designed for the room they are in, Richard Sera has several that feel so organically part of the space that you couldn't imagine other things crowding into the same area. 

The collection itself seems to contain at least one piece from almost all of the modern masters, but as mentioned, it usually isn't their most famous piece, but is instead a work in the same style. This is actually a positive in my mind. We've become so familiar with the art of Matisse, Picasso, Klee, and others that it is nice to see works that we don't feel like we already "know." I think it invites us to look at them more carefully and to want to explore the artists changing style.

Like any great museum, I'd prefer to visit a floor or a wing at a time, to give each work the appropriate consideration. If I lived in San Francisco, this would be a museum that the year membership would be well worth it for repeated visits. As it is, I don't get down there as much as I'd like and had to enjoy as much of it as I could with just a few short hours before hopping back onto a plane.
author: Seneca G.

description:
I'm so glad I was able to get free tickets to the grand (re)opening of SFMOMA. My date and I had a great time exploring all seven floors of the galleries.

They offer a wide array of modern art, most of it very abstract. In fact, some of it got so abstract it blew my mind not once, but twice. There are some recognizable works, such as some from Andy Warhol, the leading figure of "pop art". Anyway, one of my favorite pieces is a short film in the Shirin Neshat Gallery, which houses an 11-minute short film depicting a funeral proceeding. I won't spoil it anymore here, but I loved how it all came together to unite in a common theme. Another favorite part of the museum is the Sculpture Terrace on the third floor, featuring the Living Wall. Not only is it the largest green wall of native plants in the nation, it also houses many different flora in different spots, and as the seasons progress, many flowers will bloom in various spots, offering an array of colors that only serve to enhance the experience. Or something like that. 

The Norwegian architecture firm commissioned to construct this wonderful building really did an exceptional job designing the floors so as to feel open and relaxed. There is a natural flow to viewing each piece on each floor, and even the staircases narrow slightly so as to invite you to come explore the next floor. 

Water is not allowed from floors 2-7, but on the 3rd floor, there's a Sightglass Coffee Bar, and their offerings are fantastic if they are consistent with their shop on 7th St. 

I'm so impressed with this museum that I'm already planning to come back during my lunch break tomorrow. Sure, I'll have to pay $25, but it's worth the price. Hell, I may even become a member!

5/17/2016 edit: I became a member. LOL
author: Viet N.

description:
I was disappointed that the 7th floor was close but I like the modern art displayed here.

On the third floor there is a coffee shop very nice where you can hang out alittle longer.

The outside art was really nice I liked the habitat out there.

You can spend all day or even just a few hours.
author: Toma C.

description:
There is so much to explore at the SFMOMA! Around every corner one will find something amazing. From the living plant wall on the second floor, to the wafting coffee aroma on the third floor and the infamous wax police man, the SFMOMA has something for everyone to look at. 

After having the pleasure to attend the pre-opening, I will be sure to recommend the museum to locals and visitors alike. Located in the heart of San Francisco, the SFMOMA is accessible to all. Its entertaining for hours with its 6 floors full of modern art pieces... some weird, some funny, and some totally out of this world! 

If you're looking to fill your afternoon with art, the SFMOMA is the place to go. Spend the day, stop for a snack on the beautiful outdoor patio and discover art in San Francisco!
author: Aletta B.

description:
7 floors of beautiful artwork and great design!

Spent about 2.5-3 hours here exploring every floor. It was pretty crowded on the weekend but still managed to get some good pictures of the new renovations. 

There is a parking garage in the back, but wasn't sure how much it was. Since I came on a Sunday public parking was free on the streets. 

Great exhibits. They have Sightglass coffee inside as well as a cafe. Expect typical pricing. There is A LOT of art here, so come prepared.

PS: Their white walls and perfect for those IGers hunters. Also please don't play pokemon go. PAY attention to where you are walking!
author: Brian L.

description: We are very part-time residents and I hated my junior high art class where I was made to feel like a failure. But SF Moma, which used to have free days, drew me back in.  I found myself relaxing and enjoying the wide variety of exhibits.  But free days were gone after the renovation and my last name is not Zuckerberg.  And did I say we are not full time residents.  But membership costs are reasonable with a $20 deduction for seniors. I had a birthday coming and now we are happily members.  Love love love this museum.
author: Vickie B.

description:
Went to preview day since I'm a member now. For the past two years I've been going to MOMA in nyc to make up for our lack of moma. I'm excited Living wall - gorgeous. One of the first things installed as it would take 1.5 years to grow the plants according to the very friendly employee in the elevator!

Much more space and many more things to see then the last time I was there. Be sure to see the pop minimalism exhibit. So much Warhol and Lichtenstein, I was in heaven. Welcome back SFMOMA!
author: Samantha D.

description:
Over the years, I have done nearly every conceivable touristy thing in San Francisco but had never been to the SFMOMA as it was undergoing renovations for what seemed like an age. I finally managed to visit on my last trip and it was well worth the wait.

The admission is a little pricey (c$20) but as the mother in law is a member I managed to get in for free. The building itself is great, with the outside area at the top offering a nice perspective of downtown San Francisco. In terms of the art, I'm not really a fan of the modern stuff but really enjoyed the Fisher collection. I only had 90 minutes there and felt that I needed another hour to do the place justice, therefore I'll be back on my next trip!
author: Matt B.

description: Love, Love, Love this place!  Every time I come here I feel everyday stress fade away as I become immersed in the serenity of the space and the banquet for the senses.  The special exhibits are fun I usually like to hit one of those first and then move on to other areas.  This is a wonderful treasure for the City and it deserves our support.
author: Jerry P.

description: Bring your walking shoes, you can complete 10,000 steps in one visit.  Loved the outdoor gardens.  This place is huge, the artwork are huge.  They feature B Patisserie bakery goods.  Cafe sends out some really good food. Serra sculpture is free to all, no need to pay admission to see that.  Can you imagine paying 25.00 entrance fee?  Wow.  The renovation and expansion made the space spectacular.  No need to be squished, every piece of art nicely presented.  Figure out you want from gound up or top down.  Either way there are so much to see.  Actual ticket sales are on the 2nd floor on both sides.
author: Helen L.

description: Blocks of color, big erasers, pictures of natural gas storage tanks and rotating installations. The highlight of my visit was the incredible "The Refusal of Time" installation by South African artist William Kentridge. It was a multimedia experience with sound, video and kinetic sculpture that lasted half an hour and was the most immersive and innovative work of visual art I have seen in quite a while. Admission is a little steep.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
The new museum space and art was truly wonderful...

BUT I have to give it one star because the Jackboot security apparatus aggressively insisted that my five-year-old daughter immediately put away her colored pencils and notebook and cease actively engaging the piece that she was inspired to draw. From 15' away on a bench with me sitting right next to her. 

Way to encourage deeper engagement, and the imagination, creativity, and love of art in children, SFMOMA.

(Like the renegades whose pictures hang on the wall, we drew pictures anyway)
author: Karen O.

description:
Holy s***. I finally was able to visit a MoMA. I just happened to be in town for the Guns n Roses show at AT&T Park and couldn't resist making a day trip out of it. 

First off, the process to get in is super simple. I purchased my tickets online in advance (as recommended by the museum). I walked in and without much problem figured out how to get to the beginning of the labyrinth of a museum this place is (a whopping 7 floors). 

As a film student, I've taken several different Art History courses and have become fascinated with the subject. Therefore a visit here was beyond question as I've said before. 

From collections consisting of works by Geometric Abstractionist Josef Albers to the Impressionist Matissé, the museum will not disappoint. They even have a whole gallery dedicated to Lichtenstein right now and it's quite wonderful. 

Seriously well worth the admission rate. 

**note** remember to select "young adult" when getting your tickets if applicable (it'll save you money!)
author: James C.

description: Not very impressing. I guess I had very high hopes. The thing that made me get on here and spend some valuable time writing a review was the simple fact that several of the main attractions were closed for, "private showings" and such. It's frustrating and i wish they would make that clear to the customers. So people, beware.
author: Angel T.

description:
This is a really nice museum with a variety of exhibits at all times. I'm a member. Cannot fault the curators or the collection. 
BUT: It has the worst signage in any museum I have ever been in. Humans should not have to ask for everything. What signage there is -- is sadly tiny letters on obscure walls. Elevator lights are recessed so you don't know which of the 4 is the next one unless you stand back 10 feet. The hubris of a sign which says "use the silver elevators" when the silver elevators are not visible at all from where you are standing AND they are not silver, just a washed out gray. Restroom male/female visual signs are too small to be seen from across the open space so, once again you have to ask. If you always have to ask you are forced to feel a bit incompetent when in fact this place should be a lesson, an example, if you will of BAD signage. Wonder how much they paid for a design firm to produce this travesty?
author: Jo B.

description:
Modern art is hard to describe so I'll just start with the overall venue. I'm extremely excited that after a year, they've finally reopened and the renovations are worth it! There are multiple floors so plan to spend half a day thoroughly going through the exhibits. My favorite one was the wall of people pictured in their homes and there are personal statements that they have written while staring at their own pictures. 

You'll be seeing a lot of everything, a lot of which I had no comment on.. because I don't understand modern art... and I definitely wasn't the only one but it's entertaining to look at and analyze it for what it is trying to be ^_^ 

Beautiful green terrace wall is ideal for pics and make sure to eat at the cafe: delicious food & tea!
author: Jovian C.

description:
Very nice exhibit. Most of the art was donated by GAP Corporation. That was a shock. I wish they would have a book to look at of where this art was displayed on their grounds. That would have been fascinating. 

Transportation: We took BART 

Food: They have a good selection in their café. Even the kids were happy with the selection. It is pricy, but due to the location you expect it.

Store: The gift shop is huge. A vast variety of things for yourself and friends. They also have a huge children's gift selection.

Ticketing: We arrived when it opened and the line was pretty quick. 

Getting in: Once you get your ticket you have to move to a separate line to get in. You have two choices stairs or elevator. Depending on the time of day the length of each line is different. We took the shorter elevator line to scan our tickets then walked around the group and went up the stairs.

Docent: Make sure you go to all of their tours. They make the museum come to life and it's free. 
Benches: They are lacking due to the crowd.
author: Melissa S.

description: First-class, world-class modern art museum, newly reopened in SOMA. Warhol, Twombly, Paschke, Calder and so many others are amply represented in a massive building that still manages to feel intimate.
author: Jeffrey M.

description:
This is an amazing and memorable experience. The art collections and the museum itself is world class. I feel it's totally worth the wait! A new place to hang out and appreciate modern art!

The living wall is my favorite corner of the museum. Feels it has been part of the city from long time ago. Standing next to it feels so different yet so pleasant. Wish we have it everywhere in the city.
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
Amazing renovations! Was here three years ago right before it was shut down and wasn't impressed. The new SFMOMA has been completely revamped! 

Came here with my best friend looking for something to do on our free day. 

Suggestions:
- Start at the top floor (go up the elevator) and walk down the exhibits.
- Know which pieces you definitely wanted to see and make sure you don't miss them. 
- Wear sensible shoes! I saw someone in five inch heels and they were shaky by the fourth floor! 
- Make sure you see the living wall- INSTA GAME CAN BE IMPROVED HERE 
- If you don't get it, read about it. Modern art seems random but it is very deliberate and meaningful. (But honestly, sometimes I really didn't get it.) 
- Sightglass coffee has super cool SELFIE BOOTH. It is interactive (you'll understand when you see). But they give you a print out of it and give you a link to a high quality online version. This feature in the museum is sure to attract the longest lines I assure you.
author: Caitlin H.

description: Modern art is hella weird. I would not come back, and it's not worth the money. Seriously I don't need to see urinals, a pile of rocks or some freaky frog Jesus and have that considered a work of art. Those 3 are real pieces of art here, I wasn't sure how I felt about modern art before this but now I'm sure that modern art is just plain weird. There was some very nice artwork sparsely scattered but the weird shit totally overpowered the good stuff. Take your time and money elsewhere if you're unsure about modern art.
author: Rohit S.

description:
To supervisor of school tours, 
My daughter's fifth grade class  recently went on a field trip to San Francisco and went to the MOMA for a tour. They are from Marylin Ave School in Livermore which is a low income mostly minority group of kids who probably have never and would never go to an art museum in their lives. I'm a public school teacher who happens to teach Art so I was hoping they'd have a memorable time. Instead, the tour guide ruined the visit by her attitude, delivery and conduct. Their sweet teacher was in a tour guided by a MOMA docent named Mary Ann who treated the teacher with disdain and an attitude of snobbery. She also spoke to the kids like they were idiots, with no humor, over-annunciation and rushed them from place to place. She insisted that my husband/ chaperone hold a bag for her of art supplies for the entire tour. She skipped at least 3 spots other groups got to see so that she could be "first" back to the classroom. When there was an Art activity, the teacher asked if she could do it too and Mary Ann said "No, it's only for the kids," despite having extra supplies. The group was hurried back to the classroom where they waited for the other groups to arrive for 10-15 mins instead of looking at art. It was a huge disappointment for everyone In her group and I heard all about it from my daughter, husband and her teacher separately because of what a horribly ill-suited docent Mary Ann is for groups of folks for whom the tour is their first impression of modern art and an art museum experience.
author: Christina C.

description:
I enjoy artsy things. Therefore, I like to drag my boyfriend to the Getty, the Broad, etc. 

We both really enjoyed our time at MOMA. First of all, THERE'S SO MANY STORIES. Each story is filled with unique art pieces, and a lady told us that each bathroom at each story is a different color (she said it was the #1 selfie people take). Make sure you eat beforehand or else you'll get hungry while exploring this museum! It'll probably take you a few hours. 

The lighting, art pieces, and vibe were just great. Definitely come! (And you can order your tickets online).
author: Ranice L.

description:
We decided to go here on a Sunday and it was super crowded. Maybe it was raining but the place was full of families and couples. Some exhibits were really interesting but others were mehh. One of the largest art museums I've been to and I had a blast. Definitely go here for a date, hangout, or family outing.


Tip: If there's a long line, don't wait in line, just buy the tickets online. It's better if you start from the 7th floor and move back down to the 1st.
author: My N.

description: Modern Art. Weird, colorful, interesting...similar to the MoMA in NY, which I also enjoyed. Im not much artistic so going to places like these is definitely not something I do all the time but its good to explore and try new things. I highly recommend it and expect to spend two to three hours.
author: Rafael M.

description:
Tried to buy tickets this morning when more were released at 9am. Added 3 tickets to my cart for 12pm admission. Upon checking out, the quantity had changed??????????????????
It was already in my cart! Went to pick a different time, the 2pm and guess what? Everything is sold out AND whatever was in my cart, IS GONE! Wow. Thats hardly fair. Please fix your website and ticket purchasing procedure!
author: Chris P.

description:
If you are into the arts and had only one spot to choose in San Francisco, then I suggest this place. This is a place you need to dedicate almost 5 hrs of your day too. 

It's not a place you can rush through as there some amazing pieces of art. They have various collections through out 7 floors. Sadly when we went the top floor was closed (opens early December) 

Note that most of it is contemporary, it may not be your cup of tea. We found ourselves needing a half way break as our legs got tiresome. Yes there are elevators throughout the floors.

Nice touch was the outdoor patio area that is surrounded by the city. Definitely worth the price, make sure to cross the walk way on the 6th floor. Awesome spot!
author: Enrique G.

description:
Single White Star On Brown Background
Digital

Mike D. (UK/USA, 1977-)

Using contemporary digital materials, this piece explores the sharp contrast between, on the one hand, the concepts of artistic merit, intellectual insight and creative talent; and on the other, the vapid works on display at the newly-reopened San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. 

Borrowing from iconography familiar to the social media scene of the early 21st century, the work invites the viewer to consider not so much the shape that is present, but the possibility of additional shapes that conspicuously are not.

The titular star, juxtaposed by four ghost-gray copies of itself to its right, stands isolated, and shamed by the turd-brown background upon which it stands. Thus, the artist uses a motif synonymous with merit to deliver not praise, but an iconoclastic critique of the affront to the viewer's sensibilities that the SF MoMA's seven floors of talentless, self-important pretension represent.
author: Mike D.

description:
I'm not really a fan of Modern Art.  However, I can appreciate the architecture and sheer collection of SF MOMA.  The renovation was a tremendous success.  The entrance fee ($25 for 18yo and older, free for those younger) is fair and you need to allocate several hours to take in the 5 or so floors.  A good pair of comfortable shoes will also come in handy.  MOMA has two areas where you can have a snack or coffee in between strolling among the exhibits.

You have to visit this place at least once!
author: Gene D.

description:
Pre-review info: my wife had been looking forward to the Matisse exhibit for months. Two weeks before our scheduled day to see it she sprained her knee....I borrowed a wheelchair so she could still go. So we went..... my stars are based on the following....
1. Customer service is not a good trait with most of the people working the exhibits.  Many of them never smiled...said hello or anything 


 and one at the front door glared at my wife and was totally annoyed..  (we did not see the button to push to open the doors for wheelchairs..so I just opened the door and went through) He then looked up and begrudgingly pushed it from the inside. There were about 3 employees that were engaging and looked happy to be there.
2. We go to the entrance to the line for the exhibit and the lady checks our tickets and we start maneuvering through the line. (They have baracades kind of like rides at Disney)  about halfway in another lady who works there sees us and says.. you should not have had to go through this in a wheelchair....you could have just gone to the front...Iam so sorry.  We said no worries and that no one told us.  She offered to remove the baracade but since we were already close to the entrance we said we were good.   She then went to the lady at the front of the the entrance and told her that wheel chairs should not go through the baracades .. that lady turned...looked at us with a NASTY look and said well they did not even ask!!!!  Omg we didn't know to ask and her attitude totally uncalled for!! This was our first visit to the museum and will probably be our last. That first impression will be a lasting one.
Exhibits were cool ..
author: M G.

description: I visited this museum a few days ago and I was not impressed at all. I was only impressed with the paintings on the second floor. All the art from floors 3-7 seemed like something 2 year old painted. Like seriously I can paint most of the those things. I don't know how that's art.
author: Anthony S.

description:
I love MOMA!. I'm a big fan of art and this museum exceeded my expectations. The permanent exhibition was amazing and also the temporary exhibition about Edvard Munch. 
Good location in Downtown. 
Nice building. 
If you need a break, the best idea is to pick up a delicious coffee in the cafe.  
I ended up in the museum shop, I bought almost all the stuff!. 
The only thing is the price: $33, a little expensive in my opinion but it's San Francisco!
author: Belen L.

description: I'm so glad that the SFMoma opened again. I have been here two times and both times were great. Each time, some pieces of art were new. So, it's good to know that it does change. The musuem, itself and the exhibitions inspired how art is in everything. I think if you stop, sit, stand, or ponder in silence and reflection, one can appreciate the art and design of the musuem itself and the choices of art displayed in the SFMoma. Art is subjective, so some people love one piece more than the other. While, others don't consider it to be art. This is the musuem of "modern" art. Feel free to think of what you want!
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description: Great day that turned into a disaster. I was really enjoying the SFMOMA and being there for the first time I was excited. Rene Magritte art work was fantastic. Some of the surrealism was mind blowing and I was mesmerized them. Then all of that experience shattered as if someone dropped a crystal on the floor. One of the picture was a tree growing out of tree trunk and wanted get little close to take a picture and suddenly a loud voice shouted "WHAT'S WRONG WITH YOU??!!" Was I think she said then she followed up with another louder voice saying, "DON'T YOU KNOW HOW TO STAY FAR AWAY FROM THE PICTURES??!!" Almost sounded confrontational and I was extremely embarrassed. I was in a great mood until then. It was my birthday and enjoying the museum until that point. I just wanted to hide but I had to stand up for myself so replied saying, "there's nothing wrong with me." Then I stepped away because she might've tried to kick me out or something. Treating patrons like that is not good in any environment and this needed to be addressed and I sincerely hope no one else is treated like that. Or am I born wrong race to be treated this way? Not sure but she sure ruined my birthday.
author: Sonny K.

description: absolutely stunning. whenever I go to this museum, I contemplate the pieces there. the artists shown are diverse, from mathematical sketches to artwork promoting social change. modern art is truly breathtaking, and the san francisco museum of modern art lets me see that.
author: Ashley K.

description: This was my first time back at the MOMA since they remodeled and expanded the museum.  Upon entering, I have to say that I missed the grand stair case that used to usher everyone to the second floor.  Although the line was long for tickets, it went quickly and the staff were quite delightful and helpful.  After recovering from the sticker shock of the $25 admission price, we had to strategize our visit as there was no way to see all of the seven floors of art in one day!   It was comforting to see some of the same pieces that were displayed in the original museum arranged in similar ways in the new one but also to be introduced to some of the new pieces.  Although I am more often found interfacing the art at the the deYoung and Legion, this was still a very interesting journey.  Focusing on the 2nd, 4th and 5th levels, we left plenty to return to on another trip!
author: Susan C.

description: So clean, pristine, huge, and well maintained. My friend has a membership so I was fortunate to visit moma for free. We grabbed Sightglass coffee inside and then explored the rest of the museum for hours. I could spend all day here. We came early in the morning, and I'm glad we did because it was busy/crowded by the time we left. Great rainy day activity. Wear comfortable shoes because you'll be doing a lot of walking!
author: Annie S.

description:
SFMOMA is exceptional. A beautiful museum and would be a totally amazing way to spend a day in SF - I only had half a day, so it was a bit rushed, but still amazing. 

It's $25 to get in which is pricey, but it's worth it. You can skip the queues by getting the app and buying your ticket there - they also have free wifi. I started on level 7 and worked my way down by then taking the stairs. There's such an interesting mix of art that you really could stay for a long time to take it all in. 

I also popped to the Sightglass Cafe on level 3 which is a great place for a re-engergizing coffee although they do need more seating. 

There's a bag drop on the ground floor and the shop is a must visit as it is totally amazing. I'll definitely be back each time I'm in SF as I enjoyed it so much.
author: Briony C.

description: I went to this museum to see what was the hype and I do not see musuems as the place to be but eh why not? tickets are fairly priced and the musuem was huge. what i remembered it was 4 levels of random art and sculptures. The art was okay i was expecting some cool original art but it was more like young artists showing thier amature work but it was cool to look at but majority of the art were not original. It also did not have like specfic art it was more like random art put into random spots in the musuem. This musuem was more for young teens to take pictures at then to go a sit back and admire for hours of originality and history which why its called MODERN art but i thought it was cool overall but would not reccomend to someone who really is into art.
author: Adriana M.

description: There are so many things to see! Definitely recommend spending a good day here. However it does get a bit crowded. I would recommend checking out the outdoor art pieces as well!
author: Kimberly G.

description: SF MOMA has been my favorite museum experience ever! Not only is this museum beautiful and has so much variety in the works they have, but their tours and spotlight exhibits are 100% worth checking out. The little tours are free and they are so informative and fun. MOMA is a great date idea or even a fun day for the friends and family :)
author: Jasmine V.

description: What a great choice we made to visit SFMOMA during a visit last month.  This was my first time here, but my boyfriend used to live in SF and mentioned there was a major renovation of the museum so it is now completely different from what he remembered.  So what an incredible upgrade this apparently was for those familiar with the former SFMOMA.  Some exhibits mirror what I saw at the Broad in LA (i.e. Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol, Jeff Koons etc.) but that didn't matter since there are 7 floors of exhibits offered for art enthusiasts.  Need a quick relaxing rest during your visit?  There's picturesque city views from the 7th floor as well as a really nice, open, breezy restaurant and cafe (so well designed with minimalist modern style) located within the museum.  The museum shop provides lots of opportunities to buy souvenirs and the entrance fee is $25 for adults.  A visit to SFMOMA could easily take an entire day but taking the time to come here is highly recommended and definitely time well spent.
author: Kelly P.

description:
A quarter of the museum exhibits are closed and the staff is very unfriendly.  The attitude that you should be so pleased to enter the doors and that you are not worthy to do is apparent from every staff member you encounter.  

Save your money and time and visit The Legion Of Honor.
author: J. B.

description:
Got to see the Edvard Munch exhibit while it was here. The dude was a morbid, depressive, alcoholic egomaniac with tumultuous personal relationships, so you know his art is dope! His painting are like post-impressionist interpretations of MCR lyrics, and I'm halfway surprised that emo girls didn't carry around lunchbox purses with "The Dance of Life" printed on them back in the day. None of his four Screams are on display here (one of them was stolen in 2004), but you won't miss them. You'll get to see self-portraits from his salad days to his decrepit deathbed, the deathbeds of his many loved ones who died young, and his personal take on the deathbed of Marat. See a theme here? There's also lots of portraits of nude women in anguish or despair, and people with storms and/or ominous shadows in the background. Welcome to his Black Parade!

Other standouts at the SF MOMA right now include Noguchi's Playscapes, as well as a floor dedicated to pop art that includes Lichtenstein, Warhol, Thiebaud, and other assorted usual/unusual suspects. There were also a few unexpectedly excellent exhibits, such as German Art After 1960. 

As a bonus, I'd never seen a Frida Kahlo painting in person until my visit here, where "Frieda and Diego Rivera" is on display until the end of the month. I would love to see a larger Kahlo exhibit travel here in the future!

If you love art, then a visit here is a no-brainer. Even if you're not a fan of "modern art," there will still be pieces and exhibits you'll enjoy; it's not all high abstraction!
author: Mike G.

description:
What an incredibly wonderful way to spend a rainy day in San Francisco. I don't typically seek out Modern Art museums, but after being told by others that this was a museum not to be missed, I decided that it was worth a visit.

My favorite exhibits were the ones where you sat in a room and the art was happening all around you, through video, music and speech. I probably could have spent the entire day engrossed in those exhibits! But I'm glad I forced myself to get up and see the Andy Warhol's as well as the lesser known artists.

This museum is very welcoming. Although busy, it never felt crowded. There's something for everyone in here. The one thing I wish I had done was to pack my earbuds, so that I could have used the free app that describes the art that you are viewing. Earbuds are available, but I didn't choose to grab a pair, as I have problems getting the generic kind to stay in my ears.

Put this museum on your list of things to do in SF. You'll be glad you did.
author: Roberta M.

description:
I enjoyed the new museum but was a bit disappointed by the lack of diversity in the Fisher collection. It is troubling that 60% of the museum will be curatorially restricted. 

The Fisher's undoubtedly have a stunning collection; however, im worried that the institution of sfmoma will suffer if it is limited.
author: Henry F.

description:
I love this museum a lot, especially after its renovation.

Check out their cafe for their desserts. Some of them were made just look like some of their buildings.
author: Natalia M.

description:
A nightmare!  The $22.00 for a Senior seemed to me to be outrageous expensive!
This is NOT NEW YHORK and the Metropolitan which suggests 25.00 but you an
pay what you want.  The space is newly opened and the collection on 7 floors
is HUGE, way way way too big and again, I had the feeling they were competing
with NYC AND trying to say :look what technological wealth and venture capital 
zillions can buy.  The location is good.  I could not tell if i went to check out
the "IN SITU restaurant or it was a cafeteria, and there was a second place, but
I was so tired and annoyed with all the '
more is more' philosophy that I did not ask.  I will not go back.
author: Ruth Z.

description: Such a great place for a date. They have really cool pieces and you're allowed to take photos. 18 and younger is free which is also a plus but besides that it's not very expensive and it's a really fun museum to go to while you're in SF.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Such an exceptional museum!!! I was honestly amazed at all the art pieces there were and how HUMONGOUS the museum actually is. I didn't expect to walk into a seven story tall museum with a variety of different art pieces organized on each level! 

As for the security guards, not sure why people are giving negative reviews about them. They may be staring at you when you get too close to the art pieces but that's understandable. The security guards started conversations with my friend and I and were super nice! Two of them offered to take pictures for us without us even asking! Another one saw us drinking bottled water on a bench (oops forgot the no drink policy) but he was really polite in redirecting us to the nearby cafe on the 3rd floor or to the outside area to eat/drink! Another security guard gave us a nice tip of starting to view the museum from top to bottom (SO TRUE, too bad we went through all the levels by then)! 

It costed me $19 to get in (18 & younger: Free admission, 19-24: $19, 25+ : $25). Felt like it was worth the price as I basically spent my whole afternoon here. On Thursdays, the museum closes later at 9pm too! On other days, they close at 5pm! Worth the visit!!
author: Eva C.

description: membership it worth it!! from isms to new media art. I much love Thursdays nights when the museum closed at 9pm, so you can have dinner at the restaurant beside the top garden terrace and then walk around mesmerising works of arts. Have fun joining exhibitions openings and performance events! Let's have party
author: Nicole M.

description:
Beautiful museum. The exterior is reminiscent of San Francisco's unique characteristics: rolling hills, calm ocean waves, and the distinctive fog. 

Well curated collection, wonderful staff, and well worth the visit.
author: James B.

description:
I love the remodel! Admission was $19 for young adults (ages 19-24 years old). I recommend everyone taking the elevators up to the 7th floor and working their way down and using the stairs. 

I would avoid going during the weekends because it does get a bit busy and it's no fun when there are giant mobs of people blocking your view of masterpieces. Also it is best to go in the morning because this museum is huge and would take you awhile to walk through and enjoy all the exhibits. There are tons of work from du Champ to Mondrian. The live wall is absolutely beautiful to admire.
author: Elisza T.

description:
After several years of construction on their expansion project, I am so glad that it is now open for everyone to enjoy modern art. I loved my experience. There are many different genres and there is a little something for everyone (who enjoys modern art). 
Beware of the people who are there to take hipster photos because you will run into them/ don't photobomb their pictures (or do, whatever floats your boat).
author: Kelly O.

description:
I'm sure my Humanities professor would like to think she had something to do with our decision to visit a museum while on vacation. That's probably true, but it was pretty handy that they opened right next door to the W San Francisco where Edward L. and I were staying last weekend.

You could easily spend a few hours here if you tried. Modern art is pretty easy to absorb, so if you don't have much time you'll still enjoy popping in. It seemed like I liked every other floor (i.e. 7th was better than the 6th & the 5th was cooler than the 4th). Parts of the collection were from artists that I easily recognized like Andy Warhol. Some of the other names were more obscure and everything was well put together. I literally laughed out loud when we passed a Palm Pilot that was actually part of an exhibit. Yes, Palm Pilots are so outdated that they're in a museum.
author: David K.

description: Definitely enjoyed the museum - it's in a great location, beautiful building. The photography section was one of my favorite parts.  There were a few too many far fetched video rooms for my liking, and it's not exactly like MoMA in NYC, but one of the closest comparable modern art museums to MoMA in NYC.  $25 for adult admission felt a little bit high, but everything in SF is expensive.  I still feel like I got my money's worth and would gladly visit again.
author: David B.

description: I love it. spent the day alone to absorb as much as I could. so many floors. beautifully done. places to watch videos or sit and reflect. a wonderful experience.
author: Margaret F.

description: The SF MoMA will never be able to compare to the Met or its New York counterpart, but it's great nonetheless. Start at the top, and work your way down. You'll see some really weird strobe lights, interpretive dance in a white box room, and basketballs floating in water. There is an exceptionally hilarious floor (I think it's the 7th) where you get to view live video footage of the whole building. It makes for a great way to spend some time and spy on other museum patrons. It's about $25 to walk around for a day and spend time downtown. You could do worse. I definitely recommend any outdoor space with sculptures as the views are fantastic, and you'll get to see some creepy stuff. Check out the bronze statues of "the meeting". You'll thank me later.
author: Danny C.

description: Free for teens... how can you beat that? Architecture alone us worth going in. Adult ticket at 25 is a little steep.
author: Kelly D.

description:
VERY disappointed with my FIRST viewing of the MOMA. This is as an artist who has not only visited museums in Paris (the Louvre), to opening receptions in New York and even here in California, so viewing fine and modern art alike in a public space is nothing new to me. Being openly embarrassed in a setting such as this, however, is very new, and not one that I will stand for.

After taking an hour trip and spending the $20 to attend Family Day with a few friends at MOMA, I was greeted by relatively pleasant 'receptionists' who were eager to answer questions I had. After waiting in line and trying to find entrance, I wandered momentarily off the side before abruptly and loudly being told 'The entrance is over THERE!' by a greeter and directed to the right place. ...Alright. While I do not like the idea of appearances playing a role, keep in mind that I am a 20 year old, 5'11 black male who wore a black zip-up jacket (with a hood), khaki pants, black shoes etc. 

A sign of things to come, the 'policies' here seem sharked/enforced by the guards who I had the utmost unpleasant experience with ex; I do NOT like the feeling of being watched and hawked, and nearly every moment I had glanced over at a guard, they were staring directly at me (which had occurred on all 7 floors). Not only do I feel discriminated against, but profiled as well. 

In addition to that, while viewing artwork on the 5th floor, I noticed a chair in a hallway inbetween exhibitions and decided to sit on it (it's just a random chair). There was no sign saying otherwise that sitting was not permitted... and lo and behold, a few seconds after sitting, I was approached by a guard who very loudly told me that I could 'go sit on the bench over there', away from the artwork, and that I 'could not sit there'. There was no reasoning provided. While getting up from the chair, the guard grabbed hold of the chair and snatched it out of my grip.. all while onlookers watched and the guests I were with remarked on his behavior. His response was a laugh and shake of the head. Disgusting.

 I felt completely humiliated in that situation and overall feel that the environment did not represent what the MOMA should feel as. While there was a lot of artwork to view and appreciate, I could not do so feeling like I had to constantly look over my shoulder. If these 'policies' are enforced in a way such as this, I don't think it's an environment suitable even for kids with that being said.
author: Justin J.

description:
We became members early on - so glad. A bargain. The New MOMA is Fabulous. As advertised: Seven Floors of Wow! From Caldar to Warhol - a visual feast.
Arrive early - stay late. Park at 4th and Mission. Lunch lines only look long - tables turn over quickly.
author: Miami S.

description:
SF MOMA is back! I was really worried about how the new building would fit into the MOMA I know and love and was so happy that my experience exceeded expectations. (Side note: I've been going to SF MOMA since I was a teenager when it was still on Van Ness - it was my first art museum and where I discovered that I really love modern art.)

The best way to view the museum is to start at the top and go down. The museum guide handout is more than a map - it highlights the best from each floor and is a great way to plan what you want to see. The first two floors (7th and 6th) are the new building. The opening installations are highlighting the art donated by the Fisher family. Their collection has amazing depth and the installations highlight specific artists and/or movements. When you get to the 5th floor, this is where the old and new building intersect and you have even more gallery space. I think they did a great job of making transitions from the two buildings seem natural. It will take several hours to see everything so be prepared to do some walking.

There are cafes on the 5th and 3rd floors - the 5th floor cafe has an outdoor seating area so if the weather is nice, this is good spot for a break.

Pro-tips: for the best wow moment view, walk through Yerba Buena Garden and cross the street. Public areas are open an hour before the museum opens so if you want some alone time with the Richard Serra installation, get there between 9-9.30 am.
author: Lyn P.

description:
I've been here twice.. once I believe in 2005 or 2006? and it was just ok to me.. but I went last week after the 2 year remodel and it was worth the wait.  Holy plethora of art!  7 floors of greatness... I couldn't believe it.  I came around 3PM and only had 2HRS to explore since it closed at 5PM.  I thought that would be ample time to see everything but nope...  I was pretty much rushing myself which sucks so I guess I have to come back here again (but I don't mind).

Everything was so overwhelming.  Give yourself 3-4HRS here... I promise you it's definitely worth it. :)
author: Criselle O.

description: Prepare to spend $62 for two tickets to see artwork you can see at any other contemporary art museum. Typical floor to ceiling textbook art paintings. Save yourself some money and see the textbook artwork at a more affordable museum like LACMA, MOCA, or the like. SFMOMA seems tailored to 1%ers and yuppies. Don't get me wrong, I would have loved to see the Paul Klee room, and perhaps that would've changed my opinion, but overall it was pretty disappointing to see a museum limit accessibility to people in such an extreme way; $31 admission prices, no student discounts, it's obvious who they want to keep out and who they want to invite in.
author: Marianne R.

description:
