I am not a modern art lover. Hubby really wanted to see the new museum so we went as corporate guests. There were lots of photography exhibits and the abstracts, oils, mixed medias, videos, etc. a rare Picasso sculpture, Matisse and others. I was bored to be truthful. The museum is huge with 7 floors and 3 places to eat. A cafe with coffee and pastries. An outdoor cafe on 5 and a restaurant on the ground floor where prices were more in the $20 range and the menu sounded more appropriate for dinner than lunch.  
It took us easily 3 hrs to walk thru. The gift shop is large. Mostly books. I did buy a regular sized postcard of the museum for $1.50 which is overpriced. 
The museum is pretty and room monitors are everywhere. Don't bring a backpack. They make you carry it in front of your body. There were not that many sculptures where your pack would hit if you made a quick turn but they make you take it off your back. I did like the Calder mobiles and the outside wall of greens.  
Don't plan to hurry back to visit again. I am more a fan of the old art works.
author: Ry T.

description:
Came here around when it just reopened in May and I gotta say, it was alright. Tickets are on the pricey side, but luckily I was able to go in for free since I was still 18.

There are 7 spacious floors, each one starkly contrasting the last with what they have on exhibit, and everything is clean, clearly detailed, and easy to get lost in with all the winding corridors. While most of the walls seemed barren and too spaced out to me, I enjoyed the beautiful architecture of the building and the outside pieces as it was tranquil and less hectic than indoors.

I will say that the elevators are regularly crowded, so what we did was rode it all the way up once to start at the top and let gravity do the work as we descend down each floor via stairs. The stairs themselves however are pretty narrow and steep, making it hard to traverse when everyone is bustling through. My other negative is that the employees are constantly on you, making it hard to enjoy each piece without feeling eyes on you assuming you're going to do something wrong. 

Was it worth seeing? Yes. Did it live up to the hype everyone was lauding it to be? Not really for my taste. If you're a huge fan of modern art and all things positively weird and interpretive, this place is for you! I'm personally more a fan of the de Young and the Legion of Honor, however, it was good to check this out while it was still newly opened, even if it was crowded and loud. 

Easily accessible from BART and you get Yerba Buena Gardens right across from it. Plus, their gift shop is huge! :)
author: Kyrie S.

description: I have been a member of MOMA for years and on a recent visit  there were several dogs present on long leashes, they were unkept and mangy.  As I tried to enjoy the artwork the dogs lunged towards me.  The owners were completely unaware that their dogs may make others uncomfortable or sick. They were not seeing eye dogs.  I am allergic to dogs  and also uncomfortable around dogs. I feel that my health was jeopardized and my rights were infringed upon.   I certainly could not enjoy my experience with the fear of an asthma attack or a dog bite.  I wonder if the museum has dog free days?  Or perhaps one day a week that  dogs are allowed?
author: mi m.

description:
A very nice three hour walk among great galleries with a diverse collection of contemporary art. Every artist of note is presented. We enjoyed a 30 minute discussion about Mark Rothko. 
Ate a terrific lunch at in Situ restaurant. Make a reservation because it is in demand. 
The Living Wall is worth the visit on its own.
author: Mike T.

description: The building is amazing... Just be warned that is definitely a place where one could get museum fatigue! It's huge... If I was going this way again I would cherry pick what exhibits i want to see and just go to those... one also has so much choice in SF. there is a sightglass coffee in the museum... excellent espresso hit for when the fatigue hits in... best exhibit when i was there was the American photography... it was amazing
author: Reg B.

description:
I'm glad I went, but even more glad that I had a free pass and didn't spend the $25 admission fee.  Art is subjective, is what I always say.  

Parked in the SFMOMA lot behind the museum at a pricey $26, but that's SF for ya.  The museum is beautiful inside, light, bright and open.  There are some lovely pieces, cool photography and sculptures, and some stuff that I could do better, and I'm not an artist.  Example:  Two urinals painted white.  OK, whatever.  Kermit on the cross a la Jesus.  That's just blasphemous.  No way could they get away with depictions of any other religion's beliefs, there would be a public outcry!

Definitely start at the 7th floor, and take the stairs down.  Even on a Monday the museum gets crowded, and the lines for the elevators can get long.  Also, don't bring backpack purses.  I learned my lesson from the Legion of Honor, and left my purse at home.  The museum makes you wear your backpack purse in front or over your shoulder, and it's just too damn uncomfortable.  The security is VERY picky:  don't stand too close, don't touch, don't look too long!  CHILL!
author: Marie B.

description:
I would like to give a straight 5 stars and actually it was a great debate if it was a 3 or 4 for me.  I got an offer for a membership and had been a member before--I waited about 2 months to get my card-- the cheque was cashed a few weeks after I sent it.  I had to work hard to get it-- a good customer experience is that you don't have to get something that you have paid for.  

The museums collections are large--the Fischer collection is divided out of the general collection which means you will see Ellsworth Kelly on a few floors as well as Gerhard Richter.  I think the collection should be unified for maximum viewer impact.  I am not sure it is philanthropy when long after the person who gave this Donald Fischer is in a way dictating where each of the collections should reside.  

The staff can be of the very appreciated and super friendly kind or the other kind is the not so very nice kind.  As example one staff member told me to place my small camera bag a certain way--I pointed out that I had been through a majority of the museum and I wasn't sure the reason why I also pointed out people with larger bags, backpacks, shopping bags did what they liked.  Very unprofessional and rude staff member.

I was very hungry and hoped to eat something but the food offerings is superbly limited and hence only had a beverage--the Tate Britain is a great role model - several levels of food service offerings.

The overall space is well designed and I think the Botta (original structure) was way too small even when it first opened -- not easy to get around especially with the tiny staircase.  Now Snøhetta fully optimised and made the space more accessible and logical.  Some of the angles in the staircase are very interesting--a bit too angled especially if a taller person is nearest the wall.  Glad to see SF MoMA reopened.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Finally made it to the SFMoma. Overall enjoyable but the conditions inside detract from the art. Dust bunnies gathering thought the stair cases. Floors in need of refinishing and the exterior of the building could use a big scrub down. The art was well displayed but the circulation was odd around the space. Areas cordoned off such as the terrace entrance in one location but not another makes it haphazard and confusing.
author: ben d.

description: Excellent museum.  Great collection.  Large selection.  Many contemporary art.  Totally worthwhile and should not be missed.
author: W G.

description:
This is a great expansion of the old museum (which was a great expansion of the even older museum near the civic center).  The architects did an almost seamless job combining Mario Botta's building with their (much larger) new one.  There is now plenty of space for the extensive collection of both modern and contemporary art.

Since what you enjoy about the collection is up to you, I am not going to highlight which portions I liked the best.  I will let you know that I enjoyed the multimedia works on the 7th floor which are not always appreciated by everyone. 

Why do I give it three stars?

1.  The audio guide is a disaster.  While it is trying to do unique things - allow groups to collaboratively enjoy the same content, use position information to tailor contents and provide walking tours, it doesn't work.  I traveled with a group of four.  During the course of our visit, each of our devices froze or crashed at least once.  In one case, it crashed three times.  The battery life was inadequate for a 2-1/2 hour visit.  We had to go downstairs back to the lobby to have it restarted with a pin.  We eventually found toothpicks in the cafe upstairs which allowed us to restart our audio guides.  Of course, each time it crashes, you lose your "association" with the people you are grouped with as well as your images and other personalization information.

The feature which provides "nearby" content when you walk into a gallery is too slow.  It is often a room behind.  I found myself walking into a gallery and then staring at it for 20-60 seconds while it updated.  In some cases it updated to a room I wasn't in.  I would have been perfectly happy with an old fashioned audio guide in which I punch a number into a device which is on a small sign next to a work of art.   It would have been quicker and probably would have worked.

2.  Food service was a mess.  It is not sized for the crowds.  Waits are too long.  When I was there (on a Sunday afternoon) they were out of most pastry and snack items.  The outdoor stand which was set up had a really strange configuration which assured that there would be long waits.  Pastries were in cabinets which required the staff to literally get on their hands and knees to pull them out.  It was impossibly slow and there was no way for them to know what they had in stock so each customer had to play question and answer with the staff to settle on something that they wanted and was in the cabinet.  Even stranger - they had representative food items on display that were not available.
author: Howard Z.

description: Wow!! The food at cafe 5 was excellent!!! I had the chicken sandwich and dessert with coffee. I was very satisfied! Staff was friendly and food came out fast. I got a membership so I will be back! Looking forward to exploring more of the museum and trying all the entrees at cafe 5
author: Vanessa C.

description: This place is a nice place to come visit when you are in the Bay Area. I've been here time and time again but I never found time to stop. This last trip, I made it a point to stop. I enjoyed it. Highly recommend it when in the are. At least take a stroll and walk around the pond and enjoy the turtles, geese who floats on the water enjoying the fame and attention all passerbys give it.
author: Rolando F.

description: The newly remodeled SFMOMA is Awesome!  The new entrance has a better flow.  I loved the new look and layout from the old wing.   Great layout and mixture of art exhibits! 7 wonderful floors of amazing art!   (*side note* Use the stairs -- much quicker than the elevator) This is well worth the admission price and kids under 18 get in free!  (My daughter loved this place!)  The bookstore is very nice also!  This is definitely a must see on any visit to SF!
author: Paul J.

description: Nice new spaces. More room for more art is good! But some of the galleries seem a bit cramped. And since I was a long time member of the previous incarnation, most of these pieces are not new to me. The whole thing left me a little underwhelmed. NYC MOMA is still the gold standard for me. Still, I am glad to have access to this museum again. I'm sure we will end up visiting more frequently, now that there will potentially be more to see.
author: Adam S.

description:
Because I'm too lazy to walk upstairs, I took the elevator to the top floor and walked down. It's probably not how the museum imagined visitors to see the collection because it's experienced (for-the-most-part) chronologically backwards, but it meant seeing the newest stuff, first. Considering SFMOMA has been very active with acquisitions, the most exciting new pieces (like by Mark Bradford and Lesley Vance) were on the top floors.

The 2016 expansion added plenty of galleries and the paintings have generous open space around them. This not only reduced crowding by other visitors that block the view, but created a better background for the art. Although there was more space for presenting art, there was more space allotted to less important things like gift shops and eateries.

I incorrectly assumed the top floor would be structurally different that the other floors, but it wasn't. Top museum floors often have higher ceilings to hold huge works, louvered skylights to allow natural light into the gallery, or skyline views with an outdoor sculpture garden. The new building had none of these. With only two sculptures, the outdoor Sculpture Terrace on the seventh floor wasn't noteworthy. Thankfully, the old sculpture garden across the skywalk and next to the café was still there and continues to be my favorite space of the building.

The old museum building wasn't outstanding and the new building isn't either. Considering how much they ripped through the old building, I'm puzzled why they didn't just start over from scratch instead of expanding with an addition that is wedged between other buildings like a book on a stuffed bookshelf.

The building's entrance has not moved and remains on Third Street. Don't use the new doors on Howard Street where the giant Richard Serra sculpture sits. Since the first floor is mostly dead space, go to the second floor to find ticketing and the entrance to the galleries. Allow at least 2 hours to visit.
author: Brian U.

description:
This place is huge and it is fantastic! I really enjoyed going through all these floors chock filled with art. We came on family day, and the place was filled with kids, really cool kids that love art and were so well behaved! My 11 year old daughter said "mom, I love this place, lets come here again" :-) Done and done, my baby! 

It took us several hours and we still were not able to see everything. But that's ok, there's always next time. In between looking at all this great thought provoking artwork, we shopped in the little museum shop and stopped in the cafe for lunch (which was nice). I am looking forward to going back and finishing the last 2 floors we did not get a chance to see!
author: Stacy A.

description: The building itself and all the detail that went into it is amazing. The art still sucks.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Love the new digs, but the Richard Prince's "Spiritual America"--the infamous "picture of a picture" of 10 year old nude, sexualized Brooke Shields--needs to go.  If not out of the museum, then at least behind a screen with a warning of some sort.

Consider that I'm walking through the museum with my daughter, age 6, and we just happen to walk into the photo.  Brooke was 10, and her mother signed over rights to a photographer so that he could take a nude photo of young Brooke, in a soapy tub, wearing makeup, with the intention of the photo appearing a Playboy-produced photo book.  It's disturbing to say the least.

Now consider that Brooke Shields has since litigated to regain the rights to the photo (so that she could remove the image of her nude 10-year-old self from the world's gaze), but lost that lawsuit on grounds that her mother then had the legal power to sign them away.

So here I am with my 6-year-old daughter, both of us faced with this shameful photo, one that Brooke herself has long sought to subvert, and the SFMOMA is thrusting it at us without any warning whatsoever.  It's in the middle of the room, eye level, couldn't miss it if you tried.

I get the artistic implications of the photo and what it represents.  But knowing that Brooke Shields doesn't want it there, and knowing that no parent wants their child splayed naked for the world to see is too much to bear.  I honor and appreciate everything that the MOMA does, but that photo needs to come down, or at least be put behind a screen that says BEHIND THIS SCREEN IS A NUDE PHOTO OF A 10-YO GIRL, REPRODUCED HERE AGAINST HER EXPRESS WISHES.  If you choose to go in and see it, that's on you.

Step up, MOMA.  There's art, and then there's exploitation.  By having that photo in the center of your museum you're shaming Brooke Shields and those of us who would rather not participate in that sort of gross objectification.
author: Cody V.

description:
I was here the final week before they closed, but purely by chance. I'd had no idea they were going to be closed for three long years.

But that's okay, my kids matured and now they can handle an hour and a half at the SFMOMA, up from an hour three years ago. So, yay? 

I love showing modern art to kids. It's vibrant and so open to interpretation and of course, there are many examples in which we all giggle and say, "I could paint that." Of course, it's not really a space for kids (particularly not a space for young kids or the stroller set) but certain well-behaved little ones might benefit from the exposure and some may think it's fun; others might be inspired. Data points for the future.

Beautiful space. Lightness and calm and yet buzzing with energy. 

Coffee bars aplenty. 

We bought a membership that let's me bring a guest. Kids under 18 are free so if my kid grows weary after an hour, it's no big deal. I order my tickets online (basically, it's just to tell them how many people to expect and I suspect the times are highly flexible).

I wish the SFMOMA would extend Friday and Saturday hours until 7pm. 5pm seems a tad too early to close.
author: Shannon M.

description: Very large exhibit - Quite a walk from most of the touristy hotels.  Would recommend you get a cab or uber.   If you're really a big of modern art you should enjoy the exhibits.
author: Annie H.

description: You'll need a few days to see everything. It's an absolute gem in San Francisco. 7 floors of beauty. Wear comfortable shoes. Put the SF MOMA app on your phone ahead of time to see A LOT of nifty tips and tricks & a map of exhibits that interest you. If you're under 24yrs old, show ID to save $5. The cafeteria food is pricey and mediocre but the ambiance is dope. My suggestion is probably eat at Super Duper burger across the street ahead of time. Not the best place for kids, but I did see all audiences. It's pretty quiet inside too. FYI, you'll see a massive amount of hipsters taking retro cool photos about every 100feet. I did dig how they took their pics so seriously :) I'll be returning just to slip away, wear headphones with Jazz & appreciate all the fine art MOMA has to offer!
author: Kristina M.

description: Lots of places to take ig pictures! So definitely a fan!
author: Kimberly S.

description:
New SF MOMA worth the wait.

Get the annual membership, go Thursday night (they're open later), explore/absorb one floor per visit, repeat three more times, and you got yourself a good deal; even better deal when you bring a guest for free; otherwise it's $25 per person per visit.
author: Inigo M.

description: Really wonderful time here as you get to browse the different artists and their styles. I enjoyed this on a rainy day, walking at my own pace as we visited from Orange County.
author: Jasmine S.

description: The museum itself is beyond 5 stars in architecture, choice of shows and artwork and amenities. -1 star for the food venues never being open. I have been to MOMA twice and both times the cafes were closed for private parties. That part of management seems to be run poorly as you would think after a full day looking at work, buying gifts one would also have the opportunity to enjoy a good meal on campus or at least a pop up for good measure
author: Sigorney S.

description:
Nice museum, but not world class collections so I don't know how they can charge
$25 each for a public museum that was built with public funds.  Priority tickets for the Louvre are $22.  Think about it. Actually I paid $31 each to see the Matise as well.

 The other reason I went was to
see the Diane Arbus and other photography exhibits but that section was closed and not
disclosed when purchasing tickets.
author: Bob L.

description: I could have spent an entire day here. I had so much fun wandering around and taking it all in. The new design is absolutely gorgeous, the architecture is an exhibit itself. I love the incorporation of the outdoor sculptures and the living wall, I just really can't say enough about this place. It was the highlight of my last trip to San Francisco and I can't wait to go back!
author: Joie S.

description: What else do you do during a rainy day? Go to SFMOMA, of course. If you like to take your time, I'd give yourself three hours to browse all seven floors. I wouldn't say it's my favorite modern art museum or that the collection blew my mind, but it's definitely worth a visit!
author: Selena L.

description: With the new building coming up on its first birthday you can feel the energy of the patrons. As a first time visitor I had high expectations and by far the space exceeded my expectations on many levels.  Thanks to natural light I didn't get a confined feeling moving from section to another.  Next time I plan on staying the day.
author: Michael S.

description:
It was an awesome  experience. Third floor was my favorite, so much history of San Francisco I didn't know. Photography were greatly appreciated with information. History itself shows how nowadays living so different and life being simple then to our tech world. 
Black and white photos gives a dramatic effect. 

Didn't quite understood most of the art simple color block.

The history of our old school typewriter to modern ipad. 

Place was super crowded on weekend, plus on the day we went, there was a festival at Yerba Buena. Best advice to go is weekday midday. You will appreciate you time and not feel rushed.

Will definitely go back and finish reading the history in detail.
author: Marlui A.

description:
Of course the art and the building is fantastic, but one of the workers really made our day.

Our group consisted of two Dads and three young girls. We were having a grand time discussing art and having mock debates about what is and is not art when one of the employees joined our conversation. She sat on the floor with our girls while we discussed an abstract sculpture and really engaged their young minds in ways that surprised me.

It's folks like this that can make or break an experience. Thank you SFMOMA for a great day.
author: Bo H.

description:
1. Give yourself 2.5hr minimum to roam.

2. Take an elevator to the seventh floor then make your way down. This way you don't have to wait around for elevators nor strain yourself walking upstairs.
author: Kimberly N.

description: I really like what they've done with the SF MOMA!  You can still see some elements of the way it used to be.  We started out on the top floor and worked our way down.  It's a lot to see!  I especially loved the outdoor garden area, and they were smart to put the café on the 2nd floor when you really need a break.  Modern art is so-so to me sometimes as I don't always "get it", but some of it was really cool.  You just have to give it a chance but skip along by the stuff that doesn't catch your eye.  It is definitely worth a visit!
author: Maile N.

description: What a wonderful showcase of modern art including photography. The Staff is refreshingly professional and courteous. Go!
author: Chris H.

description:
Great museum of course ! 
Interesting collections and variety of media. I applaud their  attempt to provide info on the art works thru an iPhone app (and their supplying earbuds for free) -but the number of individual works for which audio info is available is severely limited. Museum is definitely an asset to the city and surrounding area. Guards are pleasant but have no knowledge of works or locations within the museum. We found museum guides had info when asked but were consistently surly and acted as if simple questions were bothersome.  The 5th floor cafe is clean, bright,  and cheerful but the brochures were incorrect about hours of the 3rd floor coffee shop. On the day we were there the 3rd floor coffee shop refused to serve all customers after 4:30 -even though the servers agreed that the brochures say the cafe is open until 8:30.
author: Jay S.

description: It is such a great environment here. At times it is a little crowded but if you go on a good day and time it is so relaxing to stroll through the museum.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I'm not sure how to rate a museum but I'm glad we went! It's expensive at $25 a pop but a great way to spend time between breakfast and lunch. We started at the top and went down as one other reviewer recommended; good idea as we tuckered out after 3 floors and sat in front of the living wall to pull it together. I liked the floor with the modern advertising art; typewriters and history of the subway signs. I would recommend reading the signs that accompany the art as they are really insightful and not just a name and a date. I would set aside several hours so you can watch and absorb in order to process the artwork. If you go earlier than we did you can beat the crowds. By the time we hit 2pm, there were a good amount of kids who were being drug along and bored taking selfies with the artwork. Really odd to see people posing in front of paintings. Maybe it's just me.
author: Aleks K.

description: 1st time in this museum and was pleasantly surprised. I tend to prefer other types of art museums, but this was really really good!  My favorite part was the room where they had about 7 videos playing all at the same time - in a circle with one in the middle of the room so you have to move in an "O" - keep watching and moving until it ends.  It is beautiful music that ends up tying all the screens together - then there is a "pop" of surprise at the very end.  I was so glad I didn't just cruise quickly through - if you do, you will miss the point --you need to stick around and it sucks you in - trust me! Check it out!  The museum currently had many "sound" exhibits and they were all very well done and fun.  I'd go again in the next year or so when I'm there to see what's new!
author: Rhonda D.

description:
A must-visit in San Francisco. With 7 floors of art, SFMOMA is huge - set aside at least a few hours to slowly go through everything. My friends and I bought timed tickets online, so getting in was easy. Since all you need is a ticket and the sticker they give you, you can go in and out of the museum. For us it was nice to explore about half the museum, leave for lunch and drinks at the restaurants just across the street, then come back refreshed and ready to check out the second half. Otherwise, I probably would've been too drained to fully appreciate the upper floors. 

As for the art itself, there's a great variety of mediums, subject matter and artists, and (I think) something for everyone to connect to, appreciate, or just feel SOME kind of emotion from. 

Other notes:
-Free bag check
-I don't remember if they're on every floor, but good number of restrooms and water fountains
-If you do have a backpack, they'll make you carry it in front of you so it won't accidentally knock into anything
author: Connie C.

description: Recently was here on a trip and the art was incredible... The MoMa made my day! Not only did I get to see amazing, beautiful art and sculptures, but the people who work here are so friendly and helpful. The building is clean and well taken care of. The bathrooms are shocking. Picture included.
author: Jack L.

description: Though basically a beautiful, world-class museum, the new building (open for more than a year now) still feels not quite "ready for prime time". Volunteers and staff seem a little overwhelmed by the vast numbers of visitors.  Just today, I had to wait a full five minutes to leave my back-pack. Surely self-check lockers (which are common in most European and Japanese museums) would save time, money and frustration. Then another wait to have my home-printed ticket scanned. One would think that at the epicenter of the digital technology world we could build an auto-scanner (as supermarkets and other stores have had for years) which could speed up this process.  Once inside, I still encountered vast empty spaces and empty walls, just as at the "grand opening" a year ago - one wonders how long it will take the curators and other staff to learn to utilize the beautiful new building. In 1995, when the old "new" building opened, it was only a matter of months before the building started to feel "lived in", and easily navigable for new visitors and members alike. The current incarnation still has that Beijing airport feel of unarticulated vastness. Many wonders of modern art are tucked away at SFMOMA - good luck to the unwary visitor as he/she seeks to discover them!
author: Steve S.

description: I have been to SFMOMA many times in the past, and I loved it even back then when it was small. The new museum is now ten times bigger than before, and there is so much to see!  The vast collection of exhibits were so interesting and inspiring that even my three years old daughter could stroll with me for 3.5hrs without feeling bored at all (None of them was kid level stuff!)! I probably could have spent another 3 hours there if I were going there alone.  The Sculpture Terrace on 3rd and the Sculpture Garden on 5th were the places that I could spend hours to enjoy the oases in the city. The $25 ticket sounds expensive compared to other museums in the Bay Area, but it really worths every single penny.
author: Dominic L.

description:
I missed the SFMOMA so much when it was closed. The renovation/expansion is amazing and it is so wonderful to have the new gallery space and all of the new art on display. I especially enjoyed the Diane Arbus, the Jim Goldberg, the Gerhard Richter and the typography exhibit. I was also pleased that my favorite art from the permanent collection is back on display.

The new and old sections merge seamlessly. The living wall and sculpture gardens are great and I like the airy and light feeling in the new wing.

I do wish they would not allow photography of any kind in the galleries. There are too many people taking photos of the art (blocking the views) and too many people taking selfies and almost backing in to the paintings/sculptures. Enjoy the art and the experience first hand.
author: Rachel M.

description: I enjoyed the 7th floor soundtrack exhibit but my favorite was the living wall. Security was great and very helpful. The bathrooms are very colorful. I will definitely be coming back it was a beautiful museum and I enjoyed my visit.
author: Ana R.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE. I always come to visit every time I'm in the Bay. Since I go to Norcal every few months, the MOMA always has something new for me to see which is great. If I lived in the city, I would definitely get a membership pass. The place is always clean and the staff is always helpful.
author: June C.

description:
Don't rent the audio tour.  1. It is a rip-off for what they charge for the audio tour with only a few items featured. 2. I had to stand in line to rent the audio tour, then stand in a long line to return it. Frankly, their bad logistical planning which seriously inconveniences guests is not my "emergency" and is not any way to show respect for patrons.  
If you insist on going to SF MOMA, consider checking out their website on advance to view the galleries and also just do the free second floor. I went out of my way to accommodate their needs for smooth logistics, such as showing up at the opening time of 9:30 AM for my 10 AM ticket  However, paying $32 (admission plus special admission for the "blockbuster" show [Matisse] plus audio tour) to be treated so rudely takes the cake. My expressions of concern to the audio tour manager on duty fell on unsympathetic ears.  There are many other museums in the area that treat patrons with much more respect .  SF MOMA should be a museum that treats people as guests, not cattle.
author: Lorne M.

description: Came here with my daughter on a Thursday evening. Great educational trip for families. Admission is $25 but worth it for first-timers.
author: Briana L.

description: Let me start off by saying I LOVE museums, so my review might be biased. I came here on a Sunday morning around 10:30 AM and it was packed with people. I'm not used to a lot of people making lots of noise at a museum, so I was kind of worried that I wasn't going to be able to enjoy my time here. Admission was $19 per person (if you are 18-24 I believe?). There are seven floors to the museum - the first containing a gift shop and coat check and the rest filled with art collections. I would definitely say to start at the seventh floor and work your way down. I really enjoyed the figurines located on the balcony on the sixth or seventh floor. It was a really pretty day, so the lighting was perfect against the city skyline! I think the only gripe about this place was how anal the museum attendants were guarding the collections. They seemed to be mugging everyone that walked by. However the museum associates that sold us our tickets and gave us our entrance stickers were super pleasant!
author: Joanne Y.

description: New building smell. Lots of light. I'm obsessed with their staircases. Cafe has an amazing lunch menu, so check it out for some affordable edible art. Oh and the art itself... it's indeed modern :)
author: Dejana B.

description:
I loved a lot of the art but some is bordering on dull, so it left me a little underwhelmed. Overall, I don't think SF MOMA is as good as the Tate Modern in London. 

The staff were all excellent, helpful and friendly. 

The cafe 5 had good food, but no high chairs (a bit lame for a museum) and we sat inside in what was basically a wind tunnel, which was created by the doors. You'd think the architects would have realized and prevented that.

It was pretty good, but not amazing.
author: Chloe L.

description: Enjoyed myself although I found a hair in my soup in their cafe, they were nice about apologizing and replacing my meal. Besides that the art is wonderful and staff is friendly. I enjoyed exploring all the floors and will be returning soon.
author: Anna B.

description: Beautiful place and beautiful art works they have. I enjoy all art work they have, and they have special collections every season.
author: Dhwani T.

description: Had the best time with my husband at the SF MOMA. This is a must do if you come to visit the City. The Warhols were great to see, and Rothko #14 is a jaw dropper in person.
author: Gretchen L.

description: The New SFMoMA is delightful. I think I may like it more than the one in NYC. Oddly, my favorite thing about the new renovation was the bathrooms! In any case, a must see. :)
author: Laura D.

description:
It breaks my heart to give a bad review of this wonderful museum.
But our visit yesterday, memorial day and the last day of the Diebenkorn/Matisse exhibit, was very disappointing. Our group was 3 women and a baby. We were so excited to attend. 
We did everything right: we purchased tickets for the 1:30pm time slot and we arrived on time. WE enter the museum and  it's a mob scene: huge numbers of people milling around, no one knows where to go or what to do. Finally we figure out we need to go to the 4th floor for the exhibit. We get there and the line is a mile long. And just when you think you're getting to the front of the line, it curves around the corner and there's a whole new section of the line. We waited 1 hr and 20 minutes and we weren't even at the front of the line. 
Finally we asked an employee what the problem was. She said it was a sold out crowd and that many people who had morning reservations decided to come later. I said, if people miss their reservation time they should be out of luck. The employee said  "we want everyone to see the art". 
Well, We saw art but not Matisse or Diebenkorn: we finally had to give up - the mother and baby were tired - so we just left the line and took in other sections of the museum. 
SFMOMA: Please learn how to handle crowds and please do not let patrons in if they are late for their reservation!!
author: Suzan S.

description: Blah. I preferred the old one. They now let in WAY too many people - it's like being at IKEA, stumbling over one another, no rhyme or reason to the place. Disappointed.
author: K F.

description:
Get there when it opens.
Ticket price is steep.
The collection is sensational - thank you Fishers!  Guess I'll need to go back to shopping at the GAP!
Cafe food excellent.
Staff all cheerful and well trained.
The renovation was hugely underwhelming - unfriendly entrance with ugly staircase; didn't even notice the exterior; wasted uninteresting atrium; never saw how to get to the main special exhibit; easy to get lost in.  All minor observations since you're here for the ART!
author: catharine d.

description: Fantastic museum, easy to navigate with a stunning collection. If you are a member of the Whitney in NY, you get free admission!
author: Dana T.

description: Those two stars are for Matisse & Diebenkorn and all the art.... The facilities leave much to be desired, unless you enjoy waiting in ridiculous lines, climbing lots of stairs (only one elevator is available, and the wait was over 20 minutes), "vegan" salad with tuna in it, and hunting for hidden bathrooms... oh also, do not bring a purse/satchel larger than a postage stamp unless you feel like getting harassed by the guards if it is at all on your side (or *gasp* behind you), as opposed to directly in front of your body. Oh yeah, don't forget to go to the bathroom *before* entering the special exhibit, cause you only are allowed one entrance per ticket. Overall, it was a very unpleasant visit. I stupidly joined as a member prior to the visit, definitely regretting this. You would have to pay me to go back.
author: Kiss Y.

description: Being aware is more important than the evidence of awareness on a piece of paper. Being sensitive to what passes in front of you is more important than what passes into the camera. I always respect how artists instinctually understand how to create a close-knit culture. Design is used to sell things, explain things, make things look better, make people laugh, make people cry, and every once in a while change the world. SFMOMA shows humans how to be an artist in the middle of nowhere. How to think with your hands. How to have an idea. How to transcend style. How to be fashionably timeless, and how to convince people. The newly designed SFMOMA is filled with seven floors of artistic heaven. The museum showcases so much useful art: photography, interactive, video, experiential, and sculpture. Just go in and turn on the inspiration tap.
author: Saurabh S.

description: There's a lot to look at here! There's a lot of great exhibits and it's a fun way to spend your day. It's a little pricey but worth it if you're interested in the arts. Some sections were a little less interesting that we just spend through while others we spent hours in. If you don't like one part, just keep going and you'll find something you like.
author: Katie W.

description: The Matisse/Diebenkorn show is quantity over quality. Many, many minor pieces; maybe five or six worth seeing -- maybe. You may want to save your $30 for a better show.
author: Celine G.

description: Can definitely spend the whole day there with 7 floors - constantly changing exhibits keeps it fresh and makes you wanting to get a membership if you live in the bay!
author: Nina S.

description: People Keep Staring at My Gf's Ass And I Don't Get It, also very disorganized scatter art everywhere too stimulating for the eyes Shit Is Overrated and I Attend SFAI....and the elevators suck ass
author: Sophie Z.

description:
At least they have sightglass coffee inside. Thats what the one star is for. 

-the security guards staring at me and mugging me felt really uncomfortable
-hence, the reason i didnt get to enjoy looking at all the art. I was always thinking, am i doing something wrong? Why are they rolling their eyes at me when I made eye contact with a security guard after I stared at an art? Am I doing it wrong? What am I doing wrong?
-there was an atmosphere of arrogance i felt from guards. 
-not coming back again
-not worth my $25.
author: Niko B.

description: One of the best museums to visit in the city, especially since it's reopened earlier this year after being closed for renovations for a few years. The new SFMOMA is bigger and better than ever. Admission is $25 (less if you're a senior or under 24!) and gives you access to seven floors of colorful and amazing modern art. Wear comfortable shoes because you will be walking around A LOT. The tickets have timed entry and the museum recommends you buy your tickets in advance if you're coming on the weekend - I came on a Friday and no problem getting a ticket for right away. Sometimes I don't really get some of the modern art pieces that are there, but some are just so lovely with the bright use of colors. My favorites were the Ellsworth Kelly pieces (so geometric and so colorful - especially the rainbow Spectrum piece), the Beatles shirt from the typography exhibit, the Abe Lincoln piece by Ed Paschke, and the fun neon sculpture by Bruce Nauman. Oh and all of the Andy Warhols and all of the Alexander Calder mobiles and sculptures. Oh and the living wall. And the giant apple core sculpture. Ok - I guess I had a lot of favorites. You could spend hours here, so take your time and soak all the creativity in. You can take breaks at the museum's cafe, which has outdoor seating and outdoor sculptures, or at the Sightglass Coffee that inside! Don't forget to check out the museum store - lots of fun stuff to look at and you may just find the perfect gift for a friend there! Welcome back SFMOMA!
author: Sylvia K.

description: lovely place. extremely large and has much to explore. staff are polite, the exhibits are always interesting and you can't forget the famous neon light sign!
author: Elizabeth N.

description: We finally got to see the new museum after waiting three years for it to re-open, and BOY WAS IT WORTH THE WAIT!  I smiled all the way through the new building.  The exhibits and the building itself are so impressive.  This little town has a lot to be proud of now, with the largest modern art museum in the country.  San Francisco!  Who would have thought?!  Congratulations to all involved; it is truly spectacular.
author: Stephen K.

description: Phenomenal collections of art for every taste. Beautifully organized. Staff is wonderful. A bit expensive, IMO for adults ($25). But all under 18's are free. Parking is an issue, as it is anywhere in SF. If your can find street parking, great! Otherwise you're looking at $3/half hour, or a flat rate of $25-30. Hey ya gotta pay the price if ya wanna be cultured. Kids and I had a great day there. Learned so much and enjoyed everything from modern to classics. Go!
author: Lee K.

description: I had a chance to see a sneak preview of the new museum (opening soon) and I was blown away by the new SFMOMA. Beautifully designed spaces. They must have double the square footage. The Fisher Collection, among others, is nothing less than impressive. So happy the SFMOMA is officially re-opening soon, so I can spend even more time exploring. We're lucky to have a museum on par if not above what's out in the global market. Thank you San Francisco!
author: Brando F.

description: Charged me the full adult price when I said that I was in the young adult category. The ticket agent didn't bother to believe me and I was on a schedule.
author: Avery F.

description: There is so much amazing modern art circulating on the internet these days that takes your breath away, inspires, makes you think and wonder what incredible skills and effort went into the art piece - but none of it makes into establishments like MoMa... sad...
author: Eve J.

description: Great museum! I feel that it is hard for me to talk about modern art as i have no sense of critiqueing or analyzing these pieces and studying them. Would be cool if i could but maybe that is the impression you are supposed to have coming out of this museum.
author: William M.

description: Extraordinary experience, even more savvy art and those who are less reach an open mind and simply fall in love, just a breathtaking experience, I learned a lot and absolutely come back to visit as many other exhibitions! I enjoyed every minute really
author: Romy S.

description: So glad to finally get the chance to experience the new, larger SF MOMA. If you get the chance to visit San Francisco make some time for this museum! I visited with my sister we enjoyed it so much we are looking to purchase memberships.
author: Nikki L.

description: Great collection  and the layout never leaves you wondering if you missed something . It not easy to get lost in either.
author: Dan A.

description: At te renewed SFMOMA there's a little (or more) for everyone.  World class modern art, living wall, awesome book store, roof top, colorful restrooms - it's the San Francisco's Metropolitan!  I can't say a better word and would've given it five stars, if the admition price was more reasonable.
author: Sara N.

description: Really loves this museum! The employees were very kind and informative. The art work was suburb!! The new additions to the museum were beautiful. I didn't get a chance to get an expresso but it smelled delicious. I am attaching some photos of the artwork we saw which I hope you will enjoy.
author: Christine R.

description:
SFMOMA does not participate in "First Free Tuesdays" currently. I called to confirm.

I thought I should post this because this info is nowhere to be found on any website right now and theres tons of old websites saying that they do.
author: C S.

description: Cafe 5 in SF Moma.  Over priced crappy food.  Bahn Mi, YUK!  Great museum, upgrade the crappy food.!
author: Mike P.

description: Oh  how disappointing.  This review is for the remodeled space.  Why did MOMA not hire the original architect Mario Botto?  The remodel is a catastrophe!  The designers took a beautiful building and degraded the original beauty and integrity.  First off,  they painted over the lovely wood in the foyer with a cheap ugly paint.  They removed the original stairs which were interesting and replaced it with a boring staircase. Then, they used a different type of wood throughout the remodel with no continuity.  The remodel is tacky and pedestrian.  Everything feels cold and looks  institutionalized.  The permanent collection looks terrible and being off an entry way feels like an afterthought.  Visually from the outside the addition does not look at all like "sand and fog"- it looks like a big blob of an office building with shuttered windows.  Really bad.  The outdoor area with living garden is claustrophobic and so poorly designed it is embarrassing.  Water is dripping mid way and the over hang of the building is low and chops the space in half.  It feels like an after thought, as does much in the remodel.  It is unfortunate.  I don't think this addition will stand the test of time.  Perhaps this is what one gets when one hires a group rather than an individual.  The collective ideas combine to create a mess.  In a city where so much uninspired architecture is being built I expected MOMA to hire innovative forward thinking architects and build something creative and awe-inspiring.  The museum is already looking worn.  There was litter on the ground and paint chipping in areas.  I have been a member of MOMA for years and am saddened by this addition.  Fortunately,  there is much beautiful and innovative artwork to be displayed there,  still giving good reason to visit.
author: T H.

description:
Obviously, the collection is to die for.  I became a member, loved the works.  Staff were so helpful and kind.  Great Museum Store.  Here are my issues:

1) NO seating!  I am disabled, bad hip---there was NO PLACE TO SIT!  This is ridiculous!!!
I tried to get coffee and dessert, but they ran out of desserts by 2:00.  Can you believe this?  There were long lines and NOTHING TO EAT!!!  Amazing.  The toilets in the bathroom are so low---very hard for me to use.  This is a state-of-art museum...couldn't they make it more elderly/disabled friendly?  Or is this too much to ask of SFMOMA?

2) Definitely don't eat at their restaurant.  I had a lousy Caesar Salad...it was awful!  I will never eat there again.  It took over 30 minutes for my friend to get her awful salad as well.  For a 1st class museum--this was a major disappointment.  Go outside and get lunch--lots of nice, inexpensive places to eat.

3) Earphones...too high tech for me; had to constantly get help, could not get my photos...too much techie stuff, guess I'm too old for this.  SIGNAGE--it was impossible to know where an exhibit began or ended?  Is it asking too much for proper signage?  You might want to see what the MET does in NYC...I never had a problem there.

Enjoy the paintings/photos----these are worth all the aggravation...but no one should have to work this hard to enjoy art.
author: Mara A.

description: Super disappointed.....the art consisted of out of focus photographs mostly I'd say about 80% of it was that .....then a few painting that anyone could have done .....followed by a grand total of two actual modern art exhibits ......super uninspiring ....super generic.....lack of creativity.....and down right boring
author: Clint V.

description: Was great coming to the museum... have lived in the city for 20 odd years and never been down here but since the renovation its gotten great reviews so decided to come with my girlfriend and was amazed... a great way to spend the morning and early lunch seeing great art.
author: Anton P.

description: It is a pleasure to spend half day in the newly decorated MOMA in the weekends.  Even the design of the restaurant is full of art.  We bought a membership and plan to go there often.
author: Joanna K.

description: Pricey admission, but this is SF. Either way it's well worth it. I love this museum. Maybe my favorite ever. The building is gorgeous. The layout a pleasure to walk through. The collection is amazing. I could spend an entire day here and not get bored.
author: Dante R.

description: I was disappointed there was no Thomas Kinkade in their collection. I mean he is the painter of light. Rather was, RIP.
author: Mark C.

description:
Stunning.  I could spend days wandering through the revamped SFMOMA - the architecture alone is worth the visit, but the galleries are spacious and filled with incredible works from the most prominent names of modern art.  

Even if you're not a modern art fan, you'll wander across something familiar or something you'll discover you like - there is that much to look at within the collections on display.  Everything is fairly traditional/conservative - nothing too political or risque here, save for a video installation or two, so you can feel comfortable dragging along grandma or the kids...

First entry was worth hauling oneself out of bed early to beat the crowds; by lunchtime, even this capacious museum (apparently the largest art museum in the country, post-remodel!) was starting to feel packed.  Next time, I might try the audio tour - there were a number of folks wandering around with the tech-friendly self-guide.
author: Audrey L.

description: We spent a quite enjoyable afternoon at SF MOMA. The museum is massive- seven floors!- and full of interesting art. I liked that they had a wide range of media and styles, and that the exhibits were arranged thoughtfully. The layout of the museum is somewhat confusing, but not insurmountable. Coming from DC and Cleveland, I also had a bit of sticker shock, but this is definitely an enjoyable museum that one can spend hours in.
author: Lori S.

description: Such an incredible museum. The art selection is phenomenal, such a beautifully curated selection of awe inspiring artwork. I have been 3 times since it reopened and will be back many more times!
author: Allie S.

description: The SF MOMA has a pretty vast collection of contemporary art. 7 floors it. If you're up for seeing every exhibit this place has to offer, be prepared to be spending hours to see everything. I love myself some art, but by the end I was getting a little tired. If possible I would recommend going more than once to take time and really appreciate everything. There's plenty of works to see by many of the famous modern artists, but for some reason there were only a handful that really popped and resonated with me.
author: Elissa S.

description: Took the opportunity to finally visit Snohetta's SFMOMA addition. First, I was excited to see inspiration was taken from the SF Bay's waters rather than the region's seismic conditions. In contrast, I believe the de Young Museum by Herzog & de Meuron over-plays the regional importance of living in earthquake country. Second, I was less excited about the addition; I think it especially unfortunate so much of Mario Botta's design in the original building was erased with the removal of his central staircase. My favorite architectural feature of the addition are the massive picture windows.
author: Brad A.

description: Such a lovely and large place! Come early so you have enough time to see every inch of this amazing museum. Went with my fiancee last weekend and we are so glad we did!
author: Chris C.

description:
This is well worth the price of admission. They also have a coat check so you do not have to carry all of your things around.
You should plan at least 3-4 hours. You shouldn't miss the outdoor exhibits too.
I love B and W photos and they were awesome. Go!!!
author: Vicky F.

description: cool. i know i can't just put cool or else it'll register as only a top and not a review. but anyways, cool
author: Xavier L.

description: JUST RENOVATED and absolutely amazing. 7 floors packed full of art! Bring good walking shoes! Favorites included Wayne Thiebaud, Ai Wei Wei, and the propaganda/print exhibit. A must see for tourists and locals alike. Website strongly suggests to book tickets ahead of time to ensure you can go through the museum- they can sell more tickets per day then allowed people in the building.
author: Jordan S.

description:
My suggestion if you can is to take the stairs and not wait in line for the elevator for the museum.   There is a lot to see so maybe splitting viewing the galleries by a break for a snack or lunch will help with being able to remember and appreciate the exhibits.

We were glad to go and enjoyed the photograph and some of the large pieces with bold lines and color. I personally was challenged in looking at some of the pieces such as the statue made of washing machines "carefully crushed together."  

It is worth seeing.  I told my friend with a six-year old that she should take him and appreciate how he views all the different pieces.

Don't miss the film room.  I found the short video to be one of the best parts for us.
author: Summer D.

description: The German artists post 1960 is awesome! We found easy parking at Mosconne center. Wish we had more time. Beautiful building, easy to maneuver and seems kid friendly, at least for our boys!
author: Patrick P.

description: I had a great two hours there last week even though I had a Thursday late hour ticket until 8pm. Definitely go at 9am and get your ticket and stay in the Museum until the 10am Gallery opening line up. I definitely recommend spending the whole day. The Museum is full of Modern benches and seating and the German 1960's artwork is the highlight. Your ticket is valid all day with in and out privileges.
author: Kamal G.

description: I was thrilled to visit the MOMA this past weekend as I hadn't been since it's re-opening. It lived up to all the hype- such a gorgeous building with well curated art. I also appreciated that it wasn't overcrowded despite high demand. The museum organizers are clearly being thoughtful when selling tickets. The photography section is amazing and I was thoroughly impressed by the Gerhard Richter collection. I will definitely be visiting again. I am so happy that SF has stepped up their museum game.
author: Rachel R.

description: Exhibits are fantastic. Security staff is unprofessional and strange - following people around, interrupting art viewing to ask if you're doing ok, talking amongst each other loudly about taking breaks and other stuff. Never seen this kind of thing at a museum...
author: Cat L.

description: Beautiful museum. Attended the Matisse / Diebenkorn exhibit. Have always loved Matisse and had no idea that Deibenkorn was such a fan of Matisse. Quite interesting because Diebenkorn's early work comes across as more cold and calculating, without connection to nature. Every picture is numbered. Ocean Park #78, Ocean Park #127, etc. Matisse's work is warm, sensual, and in touch with nature. Yet, Diebenkorn collected books about Matisse's work, started to do figure studies, and over time even used several of the same decorative elements. Some of the museum exhibit writings really were a stretch, especially the one comparison of Matisse's Pink Nude to that of Deibenkorn's painting with a large orange rectangle insinuating a parallel. Get real.
author: Jenna J.

description: I know it's a Modern Art museum but some of the exhibits here are not "museum quality". There's some exhibits that really confused me as of why they were there instead of other talented paintings. For example, I saw blank canvases with an explanation for what it signified (?) and paint splattered on a wall. Now, the highlight of my visit was the Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo paintings. They're absolute classics. Overall, the experience here wasn't the most thought provoking but if you're into blank canvases and blurry pictures, go ahead.
author: Frida L.

description: If you enjoy modern art, this is your jam. 7 floors of curated abstract, minimalist, photography, and sculpture. Went with my mom on a girls trip, and spent 4 hours here. Get the audio guide, well worth the $5 and was such a great addition to the experience. Although, the audio guide was a little slow in picking up what was nearby when you walked into a room. It doesn't cover every piece of art, but the ones it did were great to here about, and in some cases even included audio interviews from the artist themselves.
author: Lyn A.

description:
I'm not an artist, but I appreciate art and this wasn't my taste at all. I felt almost insulted from the amateur art that was on display. Amateur as in a five year old could do it and please don't give anyone the "you just don't understand speech", because people understand..we understand it's garbage and not creative. There was a urinal next to an old blanket with two teddy bears? That's not art, it's garbage. What left me with a bad taste in my mouth were the pictures of General Sherman's campaign in Georgia. For all the non history buffs..the march was one of genius and controversy, it was full of action and destruction. The pictures posted on the wall showed none of this..I didn't understand why those pictures were up? After I looked at each one I realized that anyone who was interested in learning about his campaign through pictures would now become dumber on the subject.  The pictures depicted nothing of the campaign or showed the real torment it put people and soldiers through. 

There was a positive side to the experience, the art on the 2nd floor was amazing and it was easy for someone who isn't an artist to understand and appreciate. This art took time, dedication and talent to complete. Sadly, this floor wasn't able to make up for the hour and a half of utter non sense that was on display on almost every other floor.

Best advice I can give is to find another place to visit that has real art on display that can depict history and it also displays a real show of talent in the drawings.
author: John L.

description: Great museum.  Really a gem.  Terrific exhibits, and excellent permanent collection.  Great coffee shop on the third floor.  Museum cafe was crowded so went outside to eat (Oasis for falafel) and came back in.  Spent about 5 hours at museum.  LOTS to see.  Museum is 7 floors, I recommend starting at top and walking down.  Elevators take a long time.
author: Tom L.

description: Not for everyone. My wife and I were underwhelmed by our first visit. Some exhibits were interesting, but most were not. We recognize that modern art may not appeal to everyone, so it may just come down to personal taste. We were both surprised at how difficult it was to find stairways to move between floors. I don't know how they would deal with an emergency requiring a fast evacuation. We don't plan to join, even though we live in the area.
author: Bill N.

description: I grew up in the Bay Area, and visiting the MOMA is just as much a nostalgic experience as it is a cultural one. I came to see the new building and to commune with the art alone and as a meditation, as I usually do. While I love the space and the collections, the hostility of the members of security totally ruined the experience for me. I completely  understand and respect that art needs to be protected, and that security is there to this end, and I make every effort to obey the rules and respect the art, since what I am after is a peaceful and meditative experience. On this occasion, I had a backpack with me, and the backpack is constructed in such a way that it covers my face if I wear it forward-facing (which is a requirement if you're wearing a backpack at the MOMA) so I carried the pack sideways (the only way other than backwards-facing that I could carry it). Three times members of security talked to me about it and I explained the predicament - the first one super polite and understanding, and the other two on power trips. Again, I understand the importance of protecting the art, but why is it necessarily to berate, belittle and scream at the patrons who pay their paychecks and support the museum without provocation? Interacting with some of the security guards felt like interacting with prison guards. The irony of the authoritarian and oppressive nature of these interactions given the setting made me wonder if I was being punked. Of course I'll be back to the MOMA (without a backpack or anything remotely resembling one) but I'm pretty bummed out about today's experience.
author: J S.

description: I purchased two tickets online for today at 12:00pm. Due to illness, I was unable to make it. So, I called these guys at 3:30pm and asked if I could exchange my tickets for a later date. They said there was nothing they could do for me, since their system wouldn't allow them to exchange tickets past the ticket time. But, they told me I could drive all the way from Sacramento, while sick, to visit the museum for the remainder of the day! Cool. So glad I let these guys steal $40 from me. Definitely won't be coming to this museum any time soon. A word of advice, DON'T purchase your tickets online! Their website says you can exchange your tickets for a $5 dollar fee, but it says nothing about doing so by a certain time.
author: Courtney G.

description: Not worth the $50 for someone to tell you to not wear a backpack. And all the security guards got nothing to do but tell you to take your backpack off. Honestly, stick with de young museum. And no I'm not gonna bring my shit to coat check that's the purpose of bringing a bag. Just another way for these assholes to get you.
author: Gerline R.

description: I signed up for an annual Individual Membership ($100) a few months ago.  I immediately began getting bombarded by emails from the SFMOMA Museum Store (annoying--- I didn't sign up for these AND the unsubscribe link at the bottom of the email that I tried using many times didn't work).  I responded to one of Museum Store emails to ask that they remove me from the store email list, as I had no interest in them (wasted time).  After receiving no response, I again emailed with my request (more wasted time).  This time, I got a response, an apology and confirmation that they will remove me from the Museum Store email list (they specified it was only for the Museum Store).  Well, turns out they also removed from ALL communications from the museum, including invitations to member-only events.  So, I recently missed out on the Matisse members' party because I didn't know about it until a co-worker mentioned she was attending.  Huge bummer, as one of the reasons one joins a museum is to attend these events.  Maybe they don't value their Individual Members as much as their higher-paying members, but for $100, I expected more than this incompetence in response to what was a simple request.
author: Tanya A.

description: The New Moma is a poor bastardization of its original magnificent self.  The beautiful, elegant staircase, so perfectly matched with its carbon and grey marble exterior, floor, and interior is now gone.  In its place, is a vulgar wide-assed staircase reminiscent of similarly crude wide-assed, over-fed new California girls.  It opens up into a vast public space that's more appropriate for a Las Vegas convention showroom than a museum.  And that blue wavy mural -- straight out of Target!  But that's what Moma apparently wanted -- party space for the mindless minions who think that a pair of spectacles spoofing art is the real thing.  Fool me once, well you know the rest.  SF wouldn't know culture and class if it hit them between their eyes on a selfie in their iPhones.  For shame, SF, you may be rich and technically sophisticated, but this new Moma shows that you're really cheap boors.
author: V L.

description: Visited Friday 5/12/2017 for Matisse exhibits. Awful experience from moment we walked in. Like a Seinfeld episode. Slow elevators (one out of order on a busy Friday ?). Ticket counter agents were uninformed, slow and just not happy to be there. Exhibit itself was cramped into a badly designed maze. Hard to see anything because there was an uneasy flow to the movement of people. Ticket checkers at the lines were unprofessional and also uninformed. In Situ restaurant was also disappointing and unimpressive. I asked the waitress what was the soup and her exact response was: "If you want soup and salad type of lunch you should go to 5 th floor, we don't have soup here". This was wrong in so many levels: 1- she assumed what I was going to have, also wrongfully assuming we are not spending money there. 2- she was rude  and unprofessional. Building and architecture looks impressive, but nothing else there was worth seeing. It is now designed for retired people to go spend all day, so they have something to do. It is NOT by my account designed and made for promotion and education of the arts. I have visited museums all over the world, and none have been as terrible as SF MOMA. What a huge disappointment, Just shameful. A big painful eye-sore for Arts and city of San Francisco and MOMA org. I buy memberships in every museum I visit, not because I think I will use them again, because my husband and I support the Arts. I will not buy membership here and recommend against it until the board of directors get their act together and clean up the mess.
author: Haleh K.

description:
I'll start off by saying that I do enjoy the artwork on display and especially the Bruce Connor show. 

BUT...
For the expense and amount of time the SFMOMA was closed, I was expecting the renovation to be more awe inspiring. For starters, they opted to keep the 90s-esque black tile entrance, which now feels out of place and dated vs the aesthetic on the upper levels.  The addition and changes to the layout make the whole museum feel disjointed and poorly planned.  They seem to have designed the experience around the elevators. Because there's generally a wait and then the ride is overcrowded, I usually take the stairs.  But when taking the stairs, they dump you in the middle of each floor.  Which way do I go? I eventually have to retrace my steps to get back to the stairs. With seemingly bad flow throughout, I consistently wonder if I'm missing something. I've been back half a dozen times or so and see things I hadn't come across previously. Maybe this meandering experience is intentional? In the spirit of discovery? The ground level restaurant used to be decent, but we had a thoroughly unimpressive and extremely expensive lunch there. If we're dropping a hundred bucks on lunch, in a city that is packed to the brim with amazing restaurants, I don't want to feel disappointed and chapped. In hindsight the built in 20% gratuity is very telling. Also miss the Blue Bottle cafe at the rooftop deck. The spot they picked for Sightglass feels claustrophobic when packed with people, as it generally is. Lastly, the museum was filthy the last time we were there. We had a friend visiting from out of town and we all kept noticing giant dust bunnies everywhere- all over the floors and covering the Richard Serra installation, etc. They must have blown the budget on construction and can't afford a decent cleaning service. We visited the de Young museum the same weekend and couldn't help but think it a better experience overall. We opted to purchase a membership there and skip renewal at SFMOMA.
author: H.S. G.

description: Well worth a visit while in SF. Plan on spending most of a day as it is huge. Lots of galleries to wander through and a couple of excellent cafes for a quick nosh. Make sure to hit the main gift shop as its an experience as well!
author: David S.

description: I'm a Sacramento artist and I've been wanting to come here for the longest but trying to find time and money around my school and work schedule was ridiculous. I finally came and had an awesome experience! Michelle was the woman who helped us with purchasing our tickets at the front desk and she was phenomenal! Excellent customer service! And the entire experience was wonderful. We came an hour before closing yet we did not feel rushed out or intimidated, we were left to roam freely and explore all floors at our leisure. I am impressed by the staff and amazing art and we will definitely be coming back!
author: D S.

description: The husband and I went there today for a member preview day and it was definitely worth the wait.  We were determined to go before opening day because we figured it would be kind of insane after being closed for such a long time. There is SO MUCH to see, it's definitely worth the $100 bucks for unlimited visits for a year as a member.  They've also seemed to have expanded the store and have some truly awesome things in there.  Bring your comfy shoes because seriously...7 floors of art.  The graphic design exhibit they have right now is AMAZING and was the highlight of the visit for me.  The only reason I give 4 stars  is because I wish they would invoke some kind of no cellphone policy because people like to stand in front of exhibits with their stupid phones trying to get the perfect shot when hey, I'M TRYING TO LOOK AT THE ART DAMNIT.  I have no qualms with walking in front of them though so there's that.  One good thing is that they do ban selfie-sticks.  Thank you MOMA, I'll be back soon.
author: Jamey G.

description: What a beautiful building!!! This is my first visit since the remodel. They have some really interesting modern and contemporary art. The place gave me some great ideas to use with my students for art class. I really was intrigued by the "cobweb" art you can walk  through. The gift shop is incredible and carries loads of great stuff for yourself or to give as gifts. A must see in S.F.  The only negative is probably the admission price for adults ($25). Teens and kids are free and seniors are about $22. But, all museums in S.F. are expensive. I do have to say one thing I enjoy about going to the museums in LA is that they are free (Getty, ScienceCenter). Maybe more big companies in the bay area will help fund these museums to subsidize the cost. hmmm. Time to support the arts so all can enjoy.
author: Debi L.

description: There is a super rude African American woman on 6th floor, yelling at me it's closing at 5pm. She was standing right in front of me where I was taking a picture, I told her I just want to take a one picture before I go but without her shape, she kept standing right front of me. I said I don't want her in my picture, then she said she didn't want me either. Then just move away bitch! She called me " Witch" just because she is not allowed to say "Bitch". And she refused to give her name. Before I left, I dropped by at front desk and complained about her to one of museum personnel(his name was Jon), he couldn't tell her name because he believes she is one of security persons who worked for them but not museum workers. She technically destroyed my day at the end of visiting museum. You know what? It's shame to have people who doesn't know customer service, who doesn't know how to speak to customers at museums. Such a low level of manner and lack of intelligence to see proper way to deal with, it's her own fault that she has job she hates! I really hope she get fired. You don't deserve to work at the places like museums when you don't know what is proper attitude and you can't wear professional attitude. I won't go back this museum ever again.
author: Micky F.

description: We had a delicious lunch at Cafe 5, Museum of Modern Art, San Francisco. We were tired from our museum experience, and we were comped delicious desserts while we were waiting to order.The salmon and kale salad was excellent. The wait staff was very helpful and kind. Thank you Alonzo and Isabella. We will return.
author: Maureen N.

description: Amazingly awesome. This is definitely one of the best modern art museums in the U.S., as good or better than MOMA and the Whitney in NYC. If you love modern art and are in SF - and have at least a couple of hours to spare - don't miss this museum. The café is good as well - descent food at reasonable prices with excellent service.
author: Cynthia H.

description: As phenomenal this place is, beware NOT KID FRIENDLY! I love art and wanted to introduce this great place to my kids 6 & 8. Curators and everyone that works here; don't walk too close, don't touch that, don't do this, don't do that. Kids end up HATING the experience and never want to come back again.  Makes me sad!
author: Gemma Y.

description: I've never been a fan of museums and I consider them frivolous but I decided to check this place out since someone was treating. The only part I loved was the fisher collection because the the family knows how to spot amazing art pieces. The rest of the museum was meh.
author: Leslie M.

description: Better than I expected. A lot to see. Clean and organized. Finding and paying for parking was the damper. I wish they had some area for children.
author: K C.

description: Love Snohetta's work on the redesign.  But unfortunately, they were not able to restructure the museum's attitude.  The museum should consider adopting programs like the artist membership at NYC's MoMA, and stop harassing students whose school IDs are designed without semester imprints, to improve accessibility.
author: K K.

description:
Okay, I would give this place 5 stars if it was based solely off the artwork. However, the only reason I'm giving this place three stars is because of the jerkoff worker that my boyfriend and I had encountered. 
We came late to the Museum so were already on a time crunch, we managed to reach the 7th floor with about 10/15 minutes to spare. As we were looking around and reached the end of the gallery, there was the "America" sign that I REALLY wanted to get a photo of me and my boyfriend with since we didn't get any other photos to commemorate our visit to the museum. And right as were about to take our photo, these two workers (one apparently looked like he was training the other on how to start closing up the museum) turned off the light of the sign. I looked at him and asked him sincerely if he could turn it on real quick so I could just get ONE photo. (Keep in mind it literally is a switch that takes .2 seconds to turn on). And one of the workers (trainee) was about to go turn it on for us and the other worker (trainer) rudely said "no sorry" without even batting a eye in our direction. 
You see, I would've understood if it was past closing time, but we still had about 5/10 minutes left. My question is, why put a certain closing time if you're just going to close earlier than said. I had planned out my trip so that the last 5/10s I could go up there and take that photo. SO to the rude worker, thank you for ruining my trip for me!
author: Jamie T.

description: I LOVED THE MUSEUM. But this one lady didn't let me have my backpack and selfie stick even though I went up and I saw people with a backpack and selfie stick.
author: Alan F.

description: wow 7 floors. so freaken huge, like all museums in sf combined into one location. so much to see, will go back. it will take u more than 3 hours to read everything thoroughly. big museum store too!
author: Karen J.

description:
I like the new building on the outside. It looks like a cruise ship meets divinity fudge. The inside isn't very inviting, and it doesn't lead you from room to room. But that's not very different from the previous incarnation of the SFMOMA. It houses a nice collection of Art, and from an Art History perspective, it hits all of the landmarks, from the beginnings of Modern Art, through Dada, Abstract Expressionism to the California Figurative Movement, to the Conceptual Movement, Minimalism, Pop Art, Op Art, all the way up to Post Modernism and Conceptual and Video Art today. It goes chronologically, and as you move through the different floors and the different eras you really learn a lot about our culture. There wasn't enough time to see everything. And I did feel that a bit too much emphasis was placed on Koonz and his sculptures for my taste, but that's just me and many other people love his stuff. I'm more of a Post WWII mid-century fan myself, and as I got towards the top floors I got a bit less interested and excited. But I think it's a decent collection, and they did a pretty good job of housing it. I did feel bad for one very harried security guard whose job was to keep people from walking around a wrestling mat. There was TV in the corner of a small room, and the only way you could see it was to walk around the wrestling mat. It was an impossible situation, and I could see that he was going to be end up with an aneuryism by the end of the day.

One huge criticism is how they built a brand new museum, and yet completely failed to keep in mind how they were going to move people through it. So instead of building it with that in mind, they now have stanchions and people in t-shirts that have to herd guests around. During busy days, I can imagine those t-shirt wearing people get very harried trying to keep the visitors in line. Apparently when they hand out degrees in museum design it's not for people herding, it's only for the looks of the thing.
author: Abigail F.
