description: This was a wonderful outing. Buying tickets online was very easy. We thought it would be blocked out, due to popularity, but over Memorial Day weekend, almost all slots were open when we looked at the beginning of the weekend. You could buy tickets easily a day in advance, or even same day. The building is beautiful, with tons of natural light and light woodwork throughout. It was full, but the galleries didn't seem too crowded (no jostling). You could easily look at any piece in any gallery for as long as you wished without waiting or feeling like you were blocking someone. Each exhibit is coherent, though there isn't, in my opinion, much coherent flow between the galleries throughout (e.g. how NY MOMA is chronological). My favorite pieces were huge color photographs (wall-sized), of a dollar store, a Pyongyang political rally, and the Chicago mercantile exchange) and the lobby's massive curved metal sculpture, which you could walk through. The international crowd was large, bustling, but very civil. I bought a one-day non-member ticket, which I thought was a bit pricey ($25), but it was worth it, and I'll probably not visit more than once a year. The exhibits, though not spectacular, masterpiece-wise, were laid out well; each exhibit is thought-provoking. Well done, SF.
author: Ice Cream Truck I.

description:
SFMOMA should really be reviewed in two categories -- architecture and art. It nails the first category but falls slightly short in the curating of the second. Since this is a "user review," not a formal critique, I'll stick to just the practical information and suggestions. (Besides, some of the curating issues are the fault of that MajorBenefactorFamily the Fishers. But that is a discussion for another day and place.)

First, the new SFMOMA is enormous, so plan to be there half a day. Because the vast, new building sits on and envelops the previous one, the layout of the galleries can be confusing, and you can easily miss rooms if you aren't paying close attention. (Although evertything is well signed and easy to navigate, the signage is in small, subtle typeface.) I found the easiest way to approach this architectural behemoth is to take the elevator straight to the top floor (7th), and work your way down, using the stairs between floors. Be sure to allot some minutes to taking breaks on the sculpture terraces, to admire both the art and the city views (and the much-promoted "living wall" of lush greenery). I stopped for a coffee at the little cafe on (I believe) the third floor, where there was an audiovisual display showing interviews with artists featured in the galleries -- a nice detail. It was a good place to rest my feet for a few minutes.

The galleries are high-ceilinged and roomy, thankfully. I never felt overwhelmed by humans even though it was fairly crowded by mid-day (albeit on a weekday). Unfortunately, the ventilation system seems to be a work in progress, and some of the rooms felt airless and too warm, while the photography gallery was uncomfortably frigid. 

I saved the oh-so-famous Richard Serra spiral sculpture on the ground floor for last. There is some magical time warp or something happening in that gallery, which makes walking through the enormous, steel coil feel like a much longer journey thsn it is. Fascinating and not to be missed. Try to get there during a quieter time when kids aren't running through.

Parking is a luxury in the city, and is priced accordingly. I paid more for parking in the Minna Street garage ($26), for around four hours, than I did for my museum admission. Cheaper parking is almost always available at the 5th Street garage, if you don't mind a little walk. Better yet, if you are traveling in from the outer provinces to the south (like me), park at a BART station outside of SF and tske BART to the Montgomery Station, just a few short blocks away from SFMOMA. 

Finally, if the weather is fine, plan to spend some time across the street in the YBCA gardens. It's an absolutely lovely way to cap off your visit.

(Even though the timed tickets purchased online cannot be refunded or exchanged if your plans change, it is still worthwhile buying them that way: you can walk right in, line up at the elevators to have your ticket scanned and get your sticker, and you are on your way. The museum should encourage visitors to use this method by offering a small discount. After all, it saves them money in man hours and supplies.

Another BIG shortcoming that should be addressed: there are no recycling bins at the doors for used maps. How can this be in a city that was an early adopter of curbside recycling?)

author: Pheobe W.

description: I don't think I have ever felt less welcome at a museum. My backpack was the issue. I got through the front door (past a docent and a worker) bought a ticket (where there were a whole bunch of workers, and managed to get through all of the second and third floor galleries. On the fourth floor one of the docents told me my backpack wasn't allowed, that I either had to carry it in my hand or wear in on my chest (and she suggested that with a straight face) or they had a free bag check down on the first floor. I'm traveling right now and I like to hold on to my bag (in which I keep all my worldly possessions at the moment), but I probably would have just checked the damn thing if someone had said anything when I got there. At that point I didn't want to go all the way down and then come back up to find where I'd left off in the gallery so I just started carrying my bag. After a bit of that I put it back on and kept walking around-- the whole thing seemed real silly because there were ladies with big purses and guys with satchels all over the place. I figured it wasn't a big deal, but then another worker came up and told me to wear my backpack on my chest (for reals) but this guy also said it was okay if I just wore my bag with one strap, which makes sense (right?). So I started just one strapping it. At that point I was bit annoyed but still really enjoying the art. It was when I again got accosted by a worker who told me that I couldn't have my bag on my side like that- the only way I could have it was on my chest (I actually laughed at that one) or I could go check it. I left. I wish I'd asked for money back because I did not have a good experience. If you're going to make dumb rules, like banning bags with two straps (which I guess is the policy because, again, plenty of other people with bags around) maybe at least let people know what your policies are before they come in. It's pretty damn frustrating to be treated like a miscreant just for having a backpack, but it's really even more frustrating to have a nice museum experience ruined. I'll just find pictures of thief collection online and next time I want to spend my money I'll just catch a marvel movie-- that would have been easier.
author: Sean S.

description: Wow - I was SO looking forward to experiencing the NEW SFMMA! I remember when the REALLY paltry collection was house in the veteran's war memorial building. I guess that dates me... anyhoo - They have a nice collection of Agnes Martin, alas, it's housed in a very brightly lit room, and a small room at that. I felt the pieces, which are kind of quiet and contemplative, are way too close together. It's IMPOSSIBLE to view one without viewing the two adjacent to the piece you are trying to contemplate. What a miserable experience! And you have to traipse through room upon room of Ellsworth Kelly to get there.....Do I sound like an Agnes Martin fanatic? I"m not --- but I do hate Ellsworth Kelly. Important btw - did they finally get rid of the horrid roomful of Clifford Still? They (the Fisher's) have a nice selection of Chuck Close. The Richard Serra HUGE piece on the first floor is kind of wonderful - you walk into it. I think the motley SFMMA permanent collection has its own little area ---- it's a meager selection, dwarfed by the room upon room of Fisher collection. How the heck did they make so much money???? This is NOT a world class collection. It's a collection selected by these rich people - it's nice work, and it is a BETTER collection than the one poor SFMMA has been able to cobble together over all these years and years. Cheers!
